with three sails or masts, ὁλκάς Plu. Marc. 14; πλοῖον Luc. Nav. 14; ναύτης τῶν τ. Id. Pseudol. 27, cf. Philostr. VA 4.9.
= Lat. triumuiratus, D.C. 41.36.

the number three, triad, Ion Hist. 12 note, Pl. Phd. 104a, al.; on its significance in the Pythag. philosophy, v. Arist. Cael. 268a13, Metaph. 1081a34, b12; τρισσὴν . . ἐτέων τριάδα (sc. γεγονώς), i. e. nine years old, Syria 5.338 ( Sidon); τ. ἡ ἀκατονόμαστος, of the mystical Man from heaven ( θεός—ἄγγελος—ἄνθρωπος παθητός), Zos.Alch. p.230B.

three-pronged, Gloss.

a mortar, Suid. and Zonar. s.v. ἴγδη, Gloss.

experienced, [ ἰατρός] Gal. 15.582 ( Comp.); ἰατροὶ γέροντες Id. 8.155; ὁ περὶ ταῦτα τ. ὤν Id. 14.258; ‘old hand’, crafty fellow, Eust. 932.46.

definition: Τριβαλλοί (on the accent, v. Hdn.Gr. 1.158), οἱ,

children.definition: the Triballi, a people on the borders of Thrace (v. Hdt. 4.49): hence as a Comic name for barbarian gods, Ar. Av. 1529, 1533, 1627; ούδʼ ἐν Τριβαλλοῖς ταῦτά γʼ ἐστὶν ἔννομα Alex. 241; καὶ ποὺ μὲν καλὸν τὸν πατέρα θύειν, οἷον ἐν T. Arist. Top. 115b23:— Adj. Τρῐβαλλικός, ή, όν, Hdt. 4.49.

data.ref: Hdt. 4.49): hence as a Comic name for barbarian gods,

data.quote: ούδʼ ἐν Τριβαλλοῖς ταῦτά γʼ ἐστὶν ἔννομα

children.label: II
children.definition: young fellows who lounge about taverns, etc., like the ‘Mohocks’ of Addisonʼs time, D. 54.39:—hence the Comic exaggeration Τρῐβαλλο-ποπᾰνό-θρεπτα μειρακύλλια, tavern-bred Mohocks, Eub. 75.3 (Casaubon for Τριβαλλο-πανό-θρεπτα: Meineke suggests Τριβαλλο-μαμμό-θρεπτα, and Kock defends the Ms. reading).
Hsch.; a measure of capacity, = κοτύλη, τρυβλίον, Gal. 19.774, cf. POxy. 661v (ii/iii A. D.).
wear away, consume, Sm. Ps. 6.8.
Gal. Subf.Emp. 7p.50B., EM 765.48.
thrice-barbarous, Plu. Lib.educ. 2.14b.
a "masculine" lesbian, [LSJ Supp.] Man. 4.358, Ptol. Tetr. 171, Vett.Val. 111.7, Gloss.

flight of three steps, Inscr.Prien. 159.
thrice-dyed, i.e. of genuine dye, Lyd. Mag. 1.7 (s. v.l.).
three-pointed, δόρυ, of the trident, APl. 16.215 ( Phil.).
rubber, masseur, PCair.Zen. 675.1 (iii B. C.), PLond. ined. 2087 (iii B. C.), Str. 15.1.55.
pestle, Gal. 13.850, AB 239, Gloss.; = ἀλετρίβανος, EM 59.57.

rubbing:—mostly metaph.:

children.label: I
children.definition: rubbing down, wearing away, wasting, τριβᾷ βίου A. Ag. 465 (lyr.); κτεάνων τριβάς Id. Ch. 943 (lyr., sed leg. τριβᾶς); wear and tear of fixtures in a house, BGU 1116.26 (i B. C.).

children.label: II
children.definition: practice, opp. theory, Hp. Praec. 1, X. An. 5.6.15; study, τ. καὶ ἱστορία τῶν πόλεως πραγμάτων Metrod. Fr. 27, cf. Phld. Rh. 1.121 S., Po. 5.20, al.; also, mere practice, routine, opp. true art, οὐκ ἔστι τέχνη, ἀλλʼ ἄτεχνος τ. Pl. Phdr. 260e; τριβῇ καὶ ἐμπειρίᾳ, opp. τέχνῃ, ib. 270b, cf. Grg. 463b, Gal. 6.143; τριβῇ ζητεῖν, opp. μεθόδῳ, Arist. SE 184b2; τριβὴν ἔχειν τινός Damox. 1.10, D.S. 16.15; τ. ἐν τοῖς πολεμικοῖς ἔχειν Plb. 1.32.1; ἀρετὴν ἔχειν ἐν χρήσει καὶ τριβῇ Plu. Phil. 13; διὰ τῆς ἐν τοῖς ἔργοις σπουδαιοτέρας τριβῆς καὶ συγγυμνασίας Sor. 1.3.

occupation, μειράκιον . . οὐκέτι ἔπεμπες ἐπὶ τὰ διδασκαλεῖα καὶ τὰς προσηκούσας τοῖς νεανίαις τριβάς POxy. 471.115 (ii A. D.).

delay, ἐς τριβὰς ἐλᾷ seeks delays, S. OT 1160; πορίζεις τριβάς Ar. Ach. 385 (lyr.); and with the Verb omitted, μὴ τριβὰς ἔτι no more delays, S. Ant. 577; τριβῆς ἕνεκα καὶ ἀνοκωχῆς Th. 8.87; μετὰ τ. πάσης Pl. Ep. 344b; ὁ πόλεμος τριβὴν λαμβάνει Plb. 1.20.9.
tripod, Hdn.Gr. 1.16, 2.718.
δοῖδυξ), Hsch. (Mod. Gr. τριβίδιν, = δοῖδυξ.)
founded on practice, Crates Gramm. ap. S.E. M. 1.249; πεῖρα τ. test of theory in practice, Empiric t.t. ap. Gal. Sect.Intr. 2; tribica experientia, Id. Subf.Emp. 9p.55B.
an alembic with three receiving vessels, Maria ap. Zos.Alch. p.236B.
in coarse rude jests, Ar. Nu. 1003 (anap.).

definition: τρίβολος [ῐ], ὁ, name of various prickly plants,

children.definition: water-chestnut, Trapa natans, τ. ἔνυδρος Thphr. HP 4.9.1, Dsc. 4.15.

children.definition: caltrops, Tribulus terrestris, Ar. Lys. 576; τ. περικαρπιάκανθος, χερσαῖος, Thphr. HP 3.1.6, 6.1.3, Dsc. l.c.; ἄκανθαι καὶ τ. LXX Ge. 3.18; βάτοι καὶ τ. Ph. 1.680, cf. IG 14.1934f1 ( Rome):— Alc. 47 calls sour wine ὀξύτερος τριβόλων.

children.label: c
children.definition: τ. φυλλάκανθος, thorny trefoil, Fagonia cretica, Thphr. HP 6.5.3.

children.label: d

children.label: c

children.label: VI
children.definition: Adj., three-tiered, πυρὰ πυργοειδὴς τ. D.C. 74.5.

definition: τρίβος [ῐ], ἡ, but ὁ in E. Or. 1251, 1258, El. 103, Plu. Arat. 22: ( τρίβω):—

children.definition: worn or beaten track, ἐν τρίβῳ μάλιστα οἰκημένοι in the path (of the war), Hdt. 8.140.βʹ. (so ἐν τ. τοῦ πολέμου κείμενος D.H. 6.34, 11.54); τ. ἁμαξήρης E. Or. 1251; λεπτὴν τ. ἐξανύσαντες Theoc. 25.156; ἡ τ. τῆς ἀτραποῦ the track of the path, D.S. 17.49; διασχισθέντες [τῆς ὁδοῦ] τρίβῳ τινί by following a track, X. Cyr. 4.5.13.

path, h.Merc. 448; ποίην τις βιότοιο τάμοι τρίβον; AP 9.359 ( Posidipp.); βιότου τ. ὁδεύειν Anacreont. 38.2; ποίην τις πρὸς ἔρωτας ἴοι τρίβον; AP 5.301.1 ( Agath.); τῆς αἰτίας ἴχνος καὶ τ. track, Plu. QConv. 2.680f: pl., τρίβοι ἐρώτων A. Supp. 1042 (lyr.).

data.quote: ποίην τις πρὸς ἔρωτας ἴοι τρίβον;

children.label: II
children.definition: rubbing, attrition, Id. Ag. 391 (lyr.); τ. κρηπῖδος the rubbing of a shoe, Aret. SD 2.12.
socket, friction-joint, ἡ κεφαλὴ τοῦ βραχίονος . . τρίβον ἑωυτῇ πεποιημένη Hp. Art. 7, cf. 55; τὸ ἔθος τρίβον ποιεῖ Id. Mochl. 41; area of friction or pressure of a bandage, Id. Off. 8.

data.quote: ἡ κεφαλὴ τοῦ βραχίονος . . τρίβον ἑωυτῇ πεποιημένη

children.definition: delay, A. Ag. 197 (lyr.).

children.label: III
children.definition: bodily exercise, Nic. Al. 592 (pl.).
consisting of three short syllables, Heph. 3.2, al., Choerob. in Theod. 1.232 H.; in full, τ. πούς interpol. in D.H. Comp. 17.

data.ref: Choerob. in Theod. 1.232 H.; in full,

children.definition: prepared with a triple infusion, Dsc. 1.55.

definition: τριβυνάριον, τό, dub. sens., written τρηβυνάρην in a list of stageproperties, Pap. in Eos 32.30 (v/vi A. D.).

τρίβω [ῑ], Hes. Op. 251, etc.: Ep. impf. τρίβεσκον A.R. 2.480: fut. τρίψω S. Fr. 483, ( ἀπο-) Od. 17.232: aor. ἔτριψα Pherecr. 181; inf. τρῖψαι Od. 9.333, etc.: pf. τέτρῐφα M.Ant. 9.10, ( συν-) Eub. 62:— Med., fut. τρίψομαι ( προσ-) Antipho 4.2.8: aor. ἐτριψάμην Call. Lav.Pall. 25, A.D. Synt. 210.26:— Pass., fut. τριφθήσομαι App. BC 4.65, etc.; τρῐβήσομαι Plu. Dio 25, ( ἐκ-) S. OT 428, ( κατα-) X. HG 5.4.60; also τετρίψομαι ( ἐπι-) Ar. Pax 246; fut. Med. in pass. sense, Th. 6.18, 7.42: aor. ἐτρίφθην Id. 2.77, Hp. Epid. 5.6, Antiph. 102; ( δια-) D. 19.164: more freq. aor. 2 ἐτρίβην [ῐ] Arist. Pr. 893b40; ( δι-) Th. 1.125; ( ἐκ-) Hdt. 7.120; ( ἐπ-) freq. in Ar., Th. 557, al.; ( κατ-) Pl. Lg. 678d; ( συν-) Ar. Pax 71, etc.: pf. τέτριμμαι Pl. Phd. 116d; Ion. 3 pl. τετρίφᾰται Hdt. 2.93. [ ῐ only in pf. Act. and Pass., and fut. and aor. 2 Pass.]:—

children.definition: rub, τριβέμεναι κρῖ, i.e. thresh, thresh it out, because this was done by trampling under the feet of oxen, Il. 20.496; μοχλὸν τρῖψαι ἐν ὀφθαλμῷ work round the stake in his eye, Od. 9.333; χρυσὸν -όμενον βασάνῳ rubbed on a touchstone, so as to test its purity, Thgn. 450; τ. τὸ σκέλος rub the leg, Pl. Phd. 60b; τὰς τῆς ψώρας ἰάσεις τῷ τρίβειν Id. Phlb. 46a; τὸν ὀφθαλμόν Arist. Pr. 957a38; ἀμφορέως τὸν πύνδακα ib. 938a14; τ. τὴν κεφαλήν, in sign of perplexity, Aeschin. 2.49; ταῖς χερσὶ [τὰς τρίχας] τ. X. Eq. 5.5; τὸν πόδα μύροις τ. Eub. 108 (hex.); of a masseur, Gal. 6.151, 187; in blood-letting, Id. 15.784:— Med., χρηστηρίοις ἐν τοῖσδε . . τρίβεσθαι μύσος rub oneʼs pollution upon the shrines, pollute them with it, A. Eu. 195:— Pass., τετριμμένοι τὰ ἐπʼ ἀριστερὰ τῶν κεφαλέων Hdt. 2.93; ὕλη τριφθεῖσα ὑπʼ ἀνέμων πρὸς αὑτήν, so as to catch fire, Th. 2.77; ὀδόντες τριβόμενοι πρὸς ἀλλήλους Arist. PA 661b22.

data.quote: τὰς τῆς ψώρας ἰάσεις τῷ τρίβειν
τετριμμένοι τὰ ἐπʼ ἀριστερὰ τῶν κεφαλέων

children.definition: bruise, pound, knead, κεδρίδας, [κώνειον], Ar. Th. 486, Pl. Phd. 117b; ἑλλεβόρου ἅμαξαν Id. Euthd. 299b; ποίαν IG 42(1).122.121 ( Epid., iv B. C.); καταπλαυτόν, [μάζας], Ar. Pl. 717, Pax 8, 16; κάρυα καὶ ἀμύγδαλα εἰς θυείαν τ. Chrysipp.Tyan. ap. Ath. 14.648a, cf. Sor. 1.62, τὸ μέλαν grind, D. 18.258:— Pass., θυμιήματα τετριμμένα Hdt. 2.86; ἄρτοι σφόδρα τετριμμένοι Arist. Pr. 929a17, cf. b8; μηδὲν τετριμμένον, ἀλλὰ τεθλασμένων ὁ χυλός Diocl. Fr. 138.

data.quote: μηδὲν τετριμμένον, ἀλλὰ τεθλασμένων ὁ χυλός

children.definition: crush, βότρυν Arist. Fr. 571.

children.label: II
children.definition: wear out clothes (cf. τρίβων (A)), τῶν ὑποδημάτων τὰ τριβόμενα Plu. QConv. 2.680a; τελαμῶνες μὴ λίαν τετριμμένοι Sor. 1.83; of a road, wear or tread it smooth, ἀτραπὸς τετριμμένη ἡ διὰ θυείας, with a play on pounding in a mortar, Ar. Ra. 123; τὴν τετρ. ὥσπερ ὁδὸν ἐπὶ τὸν μακάριον βίον Phld. Rh. 1.260 S.; τρίβει οὐρανόν goes his way through heaven (cf. τρίβος), Arat. 231; τ. κύματα, of a ship, AP 9.34 ( Antiphil.); πόδας τρίβειν Theoc. 7.123.

data.quote: τὴν τετρ. ὥσπερ ὁδὸν ἐπὶ τὸν μακάριον βίον

children.definition: wear away, spend, δυστυχῆ τ. βίον S. El. 602; νησιώτην τ. βίον E. Heracl. 84; γεωργὸν βίον τ. Ar. Pax 589 (lyr.); ὀδυνηρότερον τρίψεις βίοτον Id. Pl. 526 (anap.); τ. πόλεμον prolong a war, Plb. 2.63.4: abs., waste time, tarry, A. Ag. 1056, D. 23.173 vulg. ( διατρ. cod. S):— Pass., ἐν τούτοις τρίβεται χρόνος ἐνίοτε μακρός Gal. 16.578; ἀμφισβήτησις . . τρειβομένη πολλῶν ἐτῶν prolonged, OGI 502.3 ( Aezani, ii A. D.).

data.quote: ἐν τούτοις τρίβεται χρόνος ἐνίοτε μακρός

children.definition: waste or ravage a country, E. Hec. 1142.

children.label: III
children.definition: wear out, σκολιῇσι δίκῃσι ἀλλήλους τρίβουσι Hes. Op. 251; τρίβεσθαι κακοῖσι to be worn out by ills, Il. 23.735; ἄλλην γενεὰν τρίβειν θανάτοις A. Ag. 1573 (anap.); τ. ἀμφοτέρους wear them both out, Th. 8.56, cf. 7.48, Plu. Caes. 40:— Med., τρίψεσθαι αὐτὴν περὶ αὑτήν wear itself out by internal struggles, Th. 6.18, cf. 7.42:— Pass., τριβόμενος λεώς oppressed, Hdt. 2.124; πολέμιοι τριφθησόμενοι ἐν σφίσιν App. l.c.; τρίβεσθαι μάτην τερὶ ( ἐπὶ codd.) τὴν δίωξιν Plu. Pomp. 41.
waste, squander it, οὔτε τι τῶν οἰκηΐων τρίβουσι οὔτε δαπανῶνται Hdt. 2.37.

data.quote: οὔτε τι τῶν οἰκηΐων τρίβουσι οὔτε δαπανῶνται

children.definition: use constantly, κατώμοσα . . μὴ πολὺν χρόνον θεοὺς ἔτι σκῆπτρα τἀμὰ τρίψειν Ar. Av. 636 (lyr.); κοινὰ ὀνόματα καὶ τετριμμένα D.H. Comp. 25; ἡ τετρ. καὶ κοινὴ διάλεκτος Id. Th. 23; τετρ. σχηματισμός in common use, A.D. Pron. 115.16, cf. S.E. M. 1.229.

data.quote: κατώμοσα . . μὴ πολὺν χρόνον θεοὺς ἔτι σκῆπτρα τἀμὰ τρίψειν

children.definition: Pass., to be much busied or engrossed with a thing, πολέμῳ Hdt. 3.134; ἀμφʼ ἀρετῇ τ. practise oneself in, use oneself to it, Thgn. 465; τρίβεσθαι περὶ τοὺς δυνατούς Philostr. VA 4.41: esp. in pf. part. Pass. τετριμμένος, practised, expert, ἔμπειροι καὶ τ. Phld. Rh. 2.281 S.; οἱ ἐν ποήμασι τ. Id. Po. 5.21; τ. ἀκοή a trained, expert ear, ib. 24; πολεμικὸς καὶ τετρ. διʼ ὅπλων Plu. Eum. 11; ἀνὴρ φιλοπόνως ἐπὶ τῶν ἔργων τετρ. Gal. 15.585, cf. 623.

data.quote: ἀνὴρ φιλοπόνως ἐπὶ τῶν ἔργων τετρ.

definition: τριβώλετερ, obscure word found only in Alc. 38: cited by Heph. 11.3, who attests its metrical form (--⏑⏑), and by Choerob. in Theod. 1.262 H., al., who says it is an Aeol. voc., proparox., and means εἶδος ἀκάνθης: the quantity is against Bergkʼs derivation from *τρῐβολολετηρ ‘caltrop-devourer’. [ τριβωλ- codd. Heph., τριβολ-, τρεβολ-, and τριβαλ- codd. Choerob.]

children.definition: threefold or triangular altar, IG 14.966.8 ( Rome).

definition: τρίβων (A) [ ῐ], ωνος, ὁ, but ἡ in PGiss. 76.2 (ii A. D.): ( τρίβω):—

children.definition: worn garment, threadbare cloak, E. Fr. 282.12, Ar. Ach. 184, 343 (troch.), al., PCair.Zen. 92.19, 519.11 (iii B. C.), Sammelb. 7451.149 (iii B. C.): worn by the Spartans, Λακωνίζειν καὶ τρίβωνας ἔχειν D. 54.34, cf. Duris 14J.; by Philosophers, as Socrates, Pl. Smp. 219b, Prt. 335d; esp. by the Cynics, Crates Theb. 16, Arr. Epict. 3.1.24, etc.; and the Stoics, Zeno Stoic. 1.63; πήρα καὶ τ. Plu. Alex. fort. 2.332a, cf. Luc. Peregr. 15, D.L. 6.13; οἱ τὴν χλαῖναν ἐν τῷ θέρει κατατρίψαντες ἐν τῷ τ. τὸν χειμῶνα διάγουσι Ath.Med. ap. Orib. inc. 21.17:— = στολή τις ἔχουσα σημεῖα ὡς γαμμάτια acc. to EM 766.6.

data.ref: Arr. Epict. 3.1.24, etc.; and the Stoics,

data.quote: οἱ τὴν χλαῖναν ἐν τῷ θέρει κατατρίψαντες ἐν τῷ τ. τὸν χειμῶνα διάγουσι

data.ref: Orib. inc. 21.17:— = στολή τις ἔχουσα σημεῖα ὡς γαμμάτια acc. to

definition: τρίβων (B) [ ῐ], ωνος, ὁ, ἡ, Adj.

children.definition: practised or skilled in a thing, used to it, c. gen., τρίβων αὐτῆς (sc. τῆς καννάβιος) Hdt. 4.74; τ. λόγων E. Ba. 717; τ. ἱππικῆς Ar. V. 1429; τῶν κρεμαθρῶν οὔπω τ. Id. Nu. 869; τῶν ἔργων τῆς ἰατρικῆς Gal. 15.169, cf. 18(2).35: c. acc., τρίβων τὰ τοιάδε E. Med. 686: abs., Id. El. 1127: Comp. -ότερος EM 766.4:— hence
Subst., ‘old hand’, rogue, Ar. Nu. 869, 870 (a pun).
small cloak, Clearch. 26, Arr. Epict. 3.22.47.
practise roguery, or put off, delay, Antipho Fr. 33.
in the fashion of a τρίβων (A), χλαῖναν ἀναβαλοῦ τ. Ar. V. 1132.

definition: τριβώνιον, τό, Dim. of τρίβων (A), Ar. V. 33, 116, Pl. 714, 842, al., Lys. 32.16, PSI 4.418.19 (iii B. C.), PCair.Zen. 659.20 (iii B. C.), Alciphr. 3.55; dub. in Is. 5.11.

children.definition: like a τριβώνιον, restored for τριβωνίδες in Hsch. s.v. λῃδιώδεις.
wear a τρίβων (A), Plu. Adul. 2.52e.
the wearing of a τρίβων (A), Plu. Adul. 2.52c, Isid. 352c (pl.).
wearing a τρίβων (A), Hsch., EM 766.6.
like a τρίβων (A), Phot. s.v. λῄδιον (fort. τριβωνιώδης).
thrice-married, with allusion to Helen, Stesich. 26, cf. Theoc. 12.5.
a third generation, εἰς τ. παραμένειν Str. 2.1.14; οἱ ἐκ τριγενείας στιγματίαι v.l. in Ph. 2.446; cf. τριγονία.

children.label: II
children.definition: threefold gender (implied in one form), A.D. Synt. 212.23; τὰ διὰ μιᾶς φωνῆς τριγένειαν ὑπαγορεύοντα Id. Adv. 141.22.

data.quote: τὰ διὰ μιᾶς φωνῆς τριγένειαν ὑπαγορεύοντα

children.label: III
children.definition: τ. ἀγαθῶν three kinds of goods, Stoic. ap. S.E. P. 3.181.
thrice-born, of the three stages in the life of moths and the like, Arist. GA 759a3.

children.label: II
children.definition: of threefold gender, Trypho ap. A.D. Pron. 61.18, cf. Pron. 105.23.

children.label: III
children.definition: of three kinds, ἀγγεῖα Gal. 14.698; threefold, triple, Anatolius ap. Theol.Ar. 35.
thrice-born, epith of Athena, Lyc. 519 (variously expld. by Sch.).
of thrice Gerenian age, i.e. thrice as old as Nestor, M.Ant. 4.50; cf. sq. [τριγέρων]
triply old, i.e. very old, τ. μῦθος τάδε φωνεῖ ʼtis a thrice-told tale, A. Ch. 314 (anap.); τ. Νέστωρ AP 7.144, cf. 157.
a triple ( i.e. huge) giant, Orph. A. 1351.

definition: Τριγκαῖος, cited without interpretation by Theognost. Can. 52.

children.definition: red mullet, Mullus barbatus, Epich. 64, Sophr. 50, Cratin. 58, 320, Philyll. 13, Diocl. Fr. 135, PCair.Zen. 83.2 (iii B. C.), Sor. 1.51, 94, Gal. 6.715; τ. μιλτοπάρηος Matro Conv. 27:—in later writers τρίγλᾰ or τρῖγλα prevailed, and is sts. found in codd. of earlier authors, as Arist. HA 543a5, 591b19; τρῖγλαν (v.l. τρίγλαν) ἀπʼ ἀνθρακιῆς AP 6.105 ( Apollonid.); τρίγλαν Corn. ND 34, Plu. QConv. 2.730b, Sollert. 977f, 983f; but only τρίγλη is recognized by Hdn.Gr. 1.255 note, 1.318, Ath. 7.324c.

Hom. as epith. of ear-rings, ἕρματα τρίγληνα Il. 14.183, Od. 18.298: ancient critics (cf. Sch. ad loc.) expld. it (1) from γλήνεα ( Il. 24.192), = ἀξιοθέατα, or (2) = τρίκοκκα, i. e. with three berry-shaped ornaments, or (3) = ἐκ τριῶν ζῳδίων συγκείμενα, or (4) = τριόφθαλμα, like Att. τριοττίδες; and in other ways. It is prob. formed from γλήνη as τρίκλινος fr. κλίνη, etc., but the sense remains uncertain.

data.ref: Od. 18.298: ancient critics (cf. Sch. ad loc.) expld. it (1) from
Il. 24.192), = ἀξιοθέατα, or (2) = τρίκοκκα, i. e. with three berry-shaped ornaments, or (3) = ἐκ τριῶν ζῳδίων συγκείμενα, or (4) = τριόφθαλμα, like

children.label: II
children.definition: three-eyed, of Hecate, Ath. 7.325a.
giggle, Hsch.

definition: τριγλίον, τό, = sq., PCair.Zen. 82.8 (iii B. C.), Gp. 20.46.1.
τριγλίς, ίδος, ἡ, Dim. of τρίγλη, Antiph. 68.15, Arist. Fr. 194, Dorio ap. Ath. 7.300f.
τριγλῖτις, ιδος, ἡ, a kind of ἀφύη,

children.definition: like the τρίγλη, Dorio ap. Ath. 7.285a.
casting (the net) at mullets, Plu. Sollert. 2.966a, prob. in 983e.
bearing mullets, τ. χιτών a net for catching them, AP 6.11 ( Satyrius).

definition: τριγλυφία, ἡ, in Dor. form τριγλοφία, = τρίγλυφος, ἡ, SIG 244 ii60 ( Delph., iv B. C.): hence τριγλοφίτης [φῑ], ου, ὁ (sc. λίθος), Delph. 3(5).23ii 60 (iv B. C.).

children.definition: thrice-cloven, αἰχμὴ τ. the trident, Opp. H. 5.377.

children.label: II
children.definition: Subst., τρίγλυφος, ἡ, in Doric architecture, the triglyph, a three-grooved tablet placed at equal distances along the frieze; it seems orig. to have been the end of the beam (the spaces between being at first open and then called ὀπαί, afterwards filled up and called μετόπαι) , παστάδων ὑπὲρ τέραμνα Δωρικάς τε τριγλύφους E. Or. 1372 (lyr.); πασσαλεῦσαι κρᾶτα τριγλύφοις Id. Ba. 1214; γεῖσα τριγλύφων (cj. Blomf. for γʼ ἔσω) the cornice of (i. e. above) the triglyphs, Id. IT 113; σὺν τῇ τ. IG 2(2).1668.30; τριγλύφων γωνιηιᾶν SIG 247 ii61 ( Delph., iv B. C.):—pl. τρίγλυφα, τά, Diph. 61.2.

data.quote: παστάδων ὑπὲρ τέραμνα Δωρικάς τε τριγλύφους

children.definition: three-barbed, ὀϊστός, ἰός, Il. 5.393, 11.507; τριγλώχινα (sc. Σικελίαν) Pi. Fr. 322; τ. ὑμένες tricuspid valves of the heart, Erasistratei ap. Gal. 5.548, Gal. UP 6.14: in later writers with a neut. Subst., ἄορι τ. Call. Del. 31; τ. τόξα Anon. ap. Suid.; βέλη τ. Paul.Aeg. 6.88.—The nom. form τριγλώχιν is cited from Simon. ( Fr. 248) and from Call. ( Fr. 382 ( = Aet. Oxy. 2079.36)) by Choerob. in Theod. 1.267 H.

data.ref: Gal. UP 6.14: in later writers with a neut.

children.definition: shrill cry, scream, of the partridge, τριγμὸν ἀφίησι Arist. HA 614a22; of some fish, τριγμοὺς ἀφιᾶσι ib. 535b16; φθέγγονται οἷον τρισμόν Thphr. CP 5.10.5 (but τριγμόν HP 4.14.5 cod. U); τρισμὸς μυός Plu. Marc. 5.
a grating, grinding, rasping, τρισμοὶ ὀδόντων Hp. Acut.(Sp.) 6 (4), cf. Sch. Ar. Av. 1520; τρισμοὶ πριόνων Plu. QConv. 2.654f; crepitation in bone-fractures, Zos.Alch. p.233B.
fish (cf. τρίγλη), Sophr. 50, 66, 67.
with three nails, or perh. firmly bolted, S. Fr. 315 (dub.).
to be in the third generation, τριγονήσαντα [τὰ ζῷα] συνεξομοιοῦται Thphr. CP 1.9.3, cf. 2.13.3.

the third generation, πονηρὸς ἐκ τριγονίας D. 58.17; ὁ ἐκ τ. ὢν μυροπώλης Hyp. Ath. 19; εἰ Ἀθηναῖοί εἰσιν ἑκατέρωθεν ἐκ τ. Poll. 8.85 citing Arist. (who does not use the word in Ath. 55.3); οἱ ἐκ τ. (v.l. τριγενείας) στιγματίαι Ph. 2.446; ἐκ τ. βασιλεύς Hdn. 1.7.4; εἰς τ. παραμένειν, προελθεῖν, Str. 11.10.1, 12.2.11, cf. Jul. Or. 4.131c; cf. τριγένεια.

data.quote: εἰ Ἀθηναῖοί εἰσιν ἑκατέρωθεν ἐκ τ.

children.definition: thrice-born, Διόνυσος Orph. H. 30.2.

children.label: II
children.definition: three, τέκνα τ. E. HF 1023; κόραι τ. Id. Ion 496 (both lyr.).
with or of three letters, Eust. 1878.59.
a piece of three γύαι, Tab.Heracl. 2.19, al.

definition: τριγχός, τριγχίον ( Eust. 1748.47), τρίγχωσις (Gloss.), late forms for θριγκός, etc.

children.definition: a game at ball (cf. Lat. trǐgon), Hdn.Gr. 1.23.
multiply by three, Plu. Def.orac. 2.416b ( Pass.).
represent as a triangular number, Nicom. Ar. 2.8 ( Pass.).

children.label: II
children.definition: to be triangular, νῆσος τριγωνίζουσα Hld. 10.5:— Pass., τετριγωνίσθαι assume triangular form, Plot. 2.6.2; ὁ ὀδοὺς -ίζεται Hippiatr. 95.

children.label: III
children.definition: to be in trine aspect, Ptol. Tetr. 115, Man. 4.266: c. acc., Ἑρμῆς Δία -ίζων Vett.Val. 73.26; Ζῆνα -ίζων Φαίνων Orph. Fr. 286.
triangular, Ptol. Tetr. 38, Iamb. in Nic. p.58P.; πυραμίδες, on triangular base, Nicom. Ar. 2.14. Adv. -κῶς An.Ox. 3.195.
disposition of numbers triangular-wise, Nicom. Ar. 2.8.
triangle-wise, Nicom. Ar. 2.8.
a woman who plays the τρίγωνον (τρίγωνος II.2), Luc. Lex. 8.
Cat.Cod.Astr. 2.187.
triangular-shaped, ῥαφαί Arist. HA 516a19; Ἰταλία τῷ σχήματι τ. Plb. 2.14.4; τ. δύναμις Theo Sm. p.37 H. Adv. -δῶς Eust. ad D.P. 242.
rule a zodiacal triangle, Cat.Cod.Astr. 6.6: hence τρῐγωνο-κρᾰτορία, ἡ, ib. 1.29.
ruler of a zodiacal triangle, Ps.- Ptol. Centil. 72, Paul.Al. O. 2.

three-cornered, triangular, τὴν τ. ἐς χθόνα Νειλῶτιν, of the Delta, A. Pr. 813; τ. ῥυθμοί Id. Fr. 78; βάσεις Pl. Ti. 55b; of the hearts of certain fish, Arist. Frr. 314, 330, 333; of Sicily, Plb. 1.42.3; of Britain, Str. 4.5.1.

ἀριθμοὶ τρίγωνοι, triangular numbers, are those whose units can be disposed in a triangle, as 3 [see print copy], 6 [see print copy], etc., being represented by the formula n (n + 1) / 2, Plu. QPlat. 2.1003f, cf. Nicom. Ar. 2.8; these numbers are also called triangles ( τρίγωνοι), Plu. QConv. 2.744b.

data.ref: 6 [see print copy], etc., being represented by the formula
Nicom. Ar. 2.8; these numbers are also called

children.definition: in triangular or trine aspect, of planets when there are three signs of the zodiac between them, so that they are at the apices of an equilateral triangle, S.E. M. 5.39, Plot. 2.3.4; τ. σχηματισμοί Ptol. Tetr. 35, cf. Man. 3.344.

children.label: II
children.definition: Subst., τρίγωνον, τό, triangle, Ti.Locr. 98a, Pl. Ti. 50b, etc.

a musical instrument of triangular form, with strings of equal thickness but unequal lengths, Eup. 77, Pl.Com. 69.13, Pl. R. 399c, Arist. Pol. 1341a41, Diog.Ath. 1.9; called τ. ψαλτήρια in Arist. Pr. 919b12:—also as masc., πολὺς δὲ Φρὺξ τρίγωνος S. Fr. 412, cf. Ath. 4.183e.
one of the Athenian law-courts, Din. Fr. 89.35, Lycurg. Fr. 10, Men. 1076, Paus. 1.28.8, Poll. 8.121.
Triangulum, Eudox. ap. Hipparch. 1.2.13.
τρίγωνος, ἡ, name of a lozenge, Orib. Syn. 3.183; as masc., Paul.Aeg. 7.12.
triangularity, Plot. 2.6.2, Porph. in Cat. 137.19.
eaten at three bites, of large oysters, Plin. HN 32.63.
= sq. ΙΙ, διάστημα S.E. M. 10.156, cf. Heliod. ap. Orib. 48.58.2, Gp. 7.15.17 ( -λαῖα), etc.
three-fingered or -toed, Arist. Fr. 354.

children.label: II
children.definition: three fingers long, broad, etc., εὖρος Hp. Art. 33, cf. 72; ξύλον D.Chr. 64.10, cf. Inscr.Délos 1443 C 116 (ii B. C.), Plb. 10.44.3, Dsc. 3.69, etc.; κατατέμνονται εἰς τριδάκτυλα Androm. ap. Gal. 13.22.

children.label: III
children.definition: τριδάκτυλον, τό, = ἄγνος I, Ps.- Dsc. 1.103.

children.label: IV
children.definition: having three dactyls, with a play on signf. 1, App.Anth. 7.23 ( Jul.).
three-necked, metaph. of Sicily, Lyc. 966.
with three masters, Sch. Lyc. 328.
thrice a slave, Ach.Tat. 8.1; by descent, οὐδʼ ἐὰν τρίτης . . μητρὸς φανῶ τ. S. OT 1063; as slave of a slaveʼs slave, Theopomp.Hist. 244.

data.quote: οὐδʼ ἐὰν τρίτης . . μητρὸς φανῶ τ.

children.label: II
children.definition: ζεῦγος τ. a leash of slaves, Ar. Fr. 576; cf. τριπάρθενος.
worth three drachmas, Ar. Pax 1202.

children.label: II
children.definition: τρίδραχμος, ἡ, the three-drachma tax, PRyl. 216.25, al. (ii/iii A. D.).

children.label: III
children.definition: τρίδραχμον, τό, three drachmas, Poll. 6.165.
threefold, τρίδυμα three born at a birth, Plu. 2.906b,c, Sor. 1.43, Artem. 5.12; τ. ἀδελφοί Demarat. ap. Stob. 3.39.32; παῖδες D.H. 3.22; λόγος Ph. 1.302; Τρίδυμος Πύλη, = Porta Trigemina, D.H. 1.32.
of three powers or faculties, ψυχή Hierocl. in CA 20p.463M., Ammon. in APr. 2.33; τὸ τ. Procl. in Prm. p.945 S.
measuring three palms, Milet. 7.57 ( Didyma).
trinepos, Gloss.
composed of three ingredients, ἔμπλαστρος Aët. 15.15: cf. ἑξάειδος, ἑπτάειδος, τετράειδος.

thrice coiled, ὄφις Orac. ap. Hdt. 6.77; Μαιάνδρου τ. ὕδωρ AP 6.110 ( Leon. or Mnasalc.); τ. ἰχνοπέδαν a noose of three threads, ib. 109 (Antip.); τ. νῆμα (of the Fates) ib. 7.14 (Antip. Sid.); τ. θώρακες, of three ‘crowʼs-nests’ (cf. θωράκια Moschio ap. Ath. 5.208e), App.Anth. 3.82.9 ( Archimelus).
triple wreath, Chaerem. 7 (dub.).
like three shipʼs beaks, Ar. Av. 1256.
within three years, Thphr. HP 4.11.5; three-year-old, βοῦς Orac. in IGRom. 4.360.32 ( Pergam., ii A. D.).
in three successive nights, ὄνειρος Luc. Somn. 17, Gall. 12.
τ. λέων, i. e. Heracles, who was begotten in a triple night, Lyc. 33; Subst., ἡ Ἡρακλέους τ. the triple night, Alciphr. 3.38.
Orph. H. 53.4.
in his third year, prob. = μικιζόμενος, IG 5(1).1120 (Geronthrae, v. B.C.).
belonging to a τριετηρίς, παντέλεια Plu. QConv. 2.671d; ἀγῶνες τ. IG 5(1).662.6 ( Laconia), cf. POxy. 2105.3 (ii A. D.).

triennial festival, i.e. celebrated every third year (inclusively), = in alternate years, Pi. N. 6.40, IG 2(2).1672.258,262, OGI 51.27 ( Egypt, iii B. C.), 299.17, 331.8 (both Pergam., ii B. C.), IG 12(1).730.15 ( Camirus, ii/i B. C.): pl., Hdt. 4.108, E. Ba. 133 (lyr.), Pl. Lg. 834e; in full, τ. θυσίαι D.S. 4.3; τ. ἑορταί Artem. 4.39.
περίοδος) cycle or period of three (two) years, h.Hom. 1.11, Arist. Pol. 1308b1, IG 12(1).155.50 ( Rhodes, ii B. C.), PGrenf. 2.69.22 (iii A. D.): so τ. ὧραι Orph. H. 54.3.
γυναῖκες τ. celebrating the triennial festival, Opp. C. 4.235.
three years old. Call. Dian. 72, Nonn. D. 45.294, AP 7.552 ( Agath.).

children.label: II
children.definition: triennial, IG 7.2727 (Acraeph.).

definition: τριέτης, ες, or τριετής, ές, ( ἔτος)

children.definition: of or for three years, τριέτεα χρόνον Hdt. 1.199; τ. φορά IG 42(1).121.9 ( Epid., iv B. C.); πλέον ἢ τ. ἐγένευ φίλος Theoc. 29.17, cf. BCH 48.518 ( Palestine); τ. προθεσμία Pl. Lg. 954d (in 793d τριʼ ἔτη is restored by Bekker): τρίετες as Adv., for three years, Od. 2.106, 13.377.

three years old, ἵππος Arist. HA 545b13; παιδίον Artem. 4.39: τρίετες, τό, the age of three years, ἀπὸ τριέτους μέχρι τῶν ἓξ ἐτῶν Pl. Lg. 794a, cf. Arist. HA 545b3:—fem. τρῐετ-έτις, Supp.Epigr. 6.125 ( Cotiaeum).

data.quote: ἀπὸ τριέτους μέχρι τῶν ἓξ ἐτῶν

children.label: II
children.definition: recurring every three years, κῶμος Orph. H. 53.5.
period of three years, Plu. CG 2; κατὰ τ. Thphr. CP 1.20.4, Arg. ii D. 22, cf. Dsc. 1 Prooem. 8, PAmh. 2.1co. 7 (ii/iii A. D.), etc.; ἐς τ. Luc. Alex. 41.
to be three years old, LXX 1 Ki. 1.24.

definition: τρίζυγος, ον ( η, ον S. Ichn. 168), and τρίζυξ, ῠγος, ὁ, ἡ,

children.definition: three-yoked, three in union, Χαρίτων τριζύγων S. Fr. 545; τρίζυγοι θεαί E. Hel. 357 (lyr.); τριζυγέες Χάριτες AP 11.27 ( Maced.); also τρίζυγες κασίγνητοι ib. 6.181 ( Arch.).
triple, τριζύγης οἵμου βάσιν S. Ichn. l.c.; τρίζυγον ἑβδομάδα Supp.Epigr. 3.216 ( Attica, ii/i B. C.).

definition: τρίζω, Od. 24.5, 7, Hp. Morb. 2.55, Arist. HA 504a19, al.; but pf. τέτριγα is more freq. in pres. sense, Ep. part. τετριγῶτες, for τετριγότες, Il. 2.314:—prop. of sounds uttered by animals (cf. τριγμός, τρύζω),

children.definition: utter a shrill cry, of young birds, Il. 2.314; of bats, Od. 24.7, cf. Hdt. 3.110; of the Τρωγοδύται, τετρίγασι κατά περ αἱ νυκτερίδες Id. 4.183; of partridges, Arist. HA 536b14; of the ἴυγξ, ib. 504a19; of locusts, Id. Mir. 844b26; of young swallows, Luc. Tim. 21; of the elephant, Id. Zeux. 10; of mice, Arat. 1132, Babr. 108.23, etc.; of the fish called σελάχη, Arist. HA 535b25: also applied to the noise made by ghosts, ‘squeak and gibber’, Il. 23.101, Od. 24.5, 9; ἔτριζον δίκην ἀσπίδων ( αἱ ψυχαί) Herm. ap. Stob. 1.49.44.

data.quote: Τρωγοδύται, τετρίγασι κατά περ αἱ νυκτερίδες

data.ref: Babr. 108.23, etc.; of the fish called
Arist. HA 535b25: also applied to the noise made by ghosts, ‘squeak and gibber’,

children.definition: τετρίγει ( Ep. plpf.) δʼ ἄρα νῶτα θρασειάων ἀπὸ χειρῶν the wrestlers’ backs creaked, Il. 23.714; so τρίζει, crepitates, of a broken collar-bone, Sor. Fract. 13; τέτριγε δʼ ὁ κυνόδων grinds, Epich. 21; τὸ τρίζειν ἀκουσίως involuntary gnashing, Gal. 7.150; τ. τοὺς ὀδόντας Ev.Marc. 9.18; τοῖς ὀδοῦσι Hippiatr. 86; of a musical string, give a crack, AP 6.54 ( Paul.Sil.); of an axle, creak, ἄξων τετριγὼς ὑπʼ ἄμαξαν Call. Hec. Fr. 260.68 Pf. [updated ref.]; so of a cart-wheel, Babr. 52.2; of a shoe, Philostr. Ep. 37 ( τρύζοι codd.); ἡ κοιλίη τ. Hp. Morb. 2.55; of singing in the ears, τὰ ὦτα τέτριγε ib. 15; of the hissing or crackling of a person burnt in the fire, Eup. 120.
the space of three signs, i.e. a quadrant of the zodiac, Vett.Val. 302.4, Paul.Al. A. 2, Procl. in R. 2.32K., Cat.Cod.Astr. 1.143.
three lives long, Hsch.

definition: τριηκάς, Ep. and Ion. for τριακάς (q. v.). τριήκοντα, τριηκόσιοι, etc., Ion. for τριακ-.

children.definition: period of three days, LXX Am. 4.4.
living for three days, M.Ant. 4.50: τριήμερον, τό, space of three days, Arist. HA 553a10.
one and a half artabae, PCair.Zen. 376.8 (iii B. C.).
and a half, Tab.Heracl. 2.29.
a measure of 1 1/2 cotylae, IG 1(2).842 D2, 11(2).287 A 54 ( Delos, iii B. C.).

a light undecked vessel of war, PLond. 1.106.3 (iii B. C.), Sammelb. 6261.20 (ii B. C.), Plb. 16.2.10, 3.4, 7.3, D.S. 20.93, IG 2(2).3218.9, 12(1).58.20 ( Rhodes), Supp.Epigr. 3.679 (ibid.), Ἀρχ.Ἐφ. 1913.10 ( Nisyros), Hsch., Phot. s.v. ἡμιολία; to be restored for τριηρημιολία in Ath. 5.203d. Cf. ἡμιόλιος III.
a cubit and a half long, Callix. 2.
a brick and a half, IG 2(2).463.43 (iv B. C.).

a foot and a half, X. Oec. 19.4, 5:—as Adj. τρῐημῐ-πόδιος, ον, a foot and a half long, IG 1(2).372.12, 373.15, 2(2).1668.28, 1682.9, 7.4255.20 ( Oropus); also τρῐημῐ-ποδιαῖος, α, ον, Inscr.Délos 1416 A i85 (ii B. C.).
one and a half, Schwyzer 644 ( Aegae, iv/iii B. C.).
a stater and a half, IG 2(2).1673.51 (fort. τρίʼ ἡμιστάτηρα).
a tone and a half: in Music, minor third, Cleonid. Harm. 3, Plu. E apud Delph. 2.389e, Def.orac. 430a:—hence τρῐημῐ-τονιαῖος, α, ον, διάστημα Gaud.Harm. 3, Theo Sm. p.54 H., cf. p.141H.
Alex.Eph. ap. Theon.Sm. p.140H.

definition: τριημιχοῖνιξ, ῐκος, ὁ, ἡ, f.l. for τρίʼ ἡμιχοίνικα in Thphr. HP 8.4.5.

children.definition: an obol and a half, Ar. Fr. 48.
command a trireme, Hdt. 8.46, Th. 4.11: c. gen., τ. νεός Hdt. 7.181; τῆς Παράλου Is. 5.42; τ. ἐς Κύπρον Lys. 19.25.

children.label: II
children.definition: to be trierarch, i.e. fit out a trireme for the public service, Ar. Eq. 912 (lyr.), Ra. 1065 (anap.); τ. πολλά Antipho 2.2.12; τριηραρχίας πολλὰς τ. Lys. 13.62; Γνώμη, . . ἧς ἐτριηράρχει Ἀπολλόδωρος IG 2(2).1627.250; εἰς τὴν ναῦν ἣν τριηραρχεῖ PCair.Zen. 36.5 (iii B. C.); οἶκος τριηραρχῶν a family wealthy enough for the trierarchy, Is. 7.32; ὅσοι . . τετριηραρχήκασι (at Teos and Lebedos) SIG 344.66 (iv B. C.):— Pass., τριηραρχοῦσιν οἱ πλούσιοι, ὁ δὲ δῆμος τριηραρχεῖται has trierarchs found it, X. Ath. 1.13.

data.quote: τριηραρχοῦσιν οἱ πλούσιοι, ὁ δὲ δῆμος τριηραρχεῖται

children.label: III
children.definition: equip the sacred ship, τριηραρχήσαντα ἱεροπρεπῶς LW 1143 ( Cius): cf. ναυβατέω, ναυαρχέω.
expense of the τριηραρχία, D. 50.1 ap. Harp. (codd. ἐπιτρ-).
PMich.Zen. 100.2, PCair.Zen. 12.47, al., PGrad. 6.3, PRev.Laws 94.3, PPetr. 3p.276, PHib. 1.104.3 (all iii B. C.).

children.label: II
children.definition: trierarchʼs crew of seamen, D. 50.44.
command of a trireme, Arist. Pol. 1322b4 (pl.).

children.label: II
children.definition: the fitting out of a trireme for the public service, Lys. 32.24, X. Ath. 1.13, Oec. 2.6, etc.: also at Priene, SIG 1003.29 (ii B. C.).
concerning the τριηραρχία, νόμος D. 18.312; τὸ τ., = τοὺς τριηραρχοῦντας, Decr. ap. eund. 18.105.

captain of a trireme, Hdt. 8.93, Ar. Th. 837 (troch.), Th. 4.11, 7.70, X. HG 1.1.25, OGI 773.5 ( Ios, iv B. C.), IG 2(2).1631.343 (iv B. C.), 884.11 (iii/ii B. C.), BGU 1744.11 (i B. C.), POxy. 1508.4 (ii A. D.), etc.

children.label: II
children.definition: trierarch, one who (singly or jointly with other citizens) had to fit out a trireme for the public service, Ar. Ach. 546, Th. 6.31, 7.13, IG 1(2).304.36, al., 2(2).1.27, 1609.57, 1612.133, 1629.3, 183, etc.— τρῐηραρχ-άρχης is a later form, meaning naval commander in general, Gal. Thras. 47.
flute-player who gave the time to the rowers in the trireme, D. 18.129, Phld. Mus. p.72 K., Poll. 1.96, 4.71.

definition: τριηρέτης, τρῐηρ-ετικός, ff. ll. for τριηριτ-.

τριήρης (sc. ναῦς), ἡ, gen. εος, Att. ους IG 2(2).1629.615, Ion. ευς Hippon. 49.2; acc. εα, Att. η IG 2(2).1610.30, 1623.113, 1632.235,338 (but τριήρην ib. 1628.35, 1629.862): nom. pl. εες, Att. εις; gen. τριήρων ib. 1627.397, etc., Ion. τριηρέων Hdt. 7.89; hence Choerob. in Theod. 1.411 H. prescribes as the contr. form τριηρῶν, not τριήρων, as in codd. of Th. 6.46, X. HG 1.4.11, D. 14.9, v. Hdn.Gr. 1.428; Thom.Mag. p.356R. prescribes sg. τριήρεος and pl. τριήρων ( τριήρεων γὰρ . . λέγομεν"), citing Aristid. 1.431 J.: gen. dual τριήροιν X. HG 1.5.19:—

children.definition: a trireme, i.e. prob. a galley with three men on each bench, each man rowing one oar, and three oars passing together through the παρεξειρεσία (cf. Tarn Hellenistic Military and Naval Developments, Cambridge 1930, pp. 122 sqq.), Hdt. 2.159, 7.36, Th. 1.13, 2.93, Arist. Mete. 369b10, HA 533b6, Rh. 1411a23, IG 2(2).1623.276, Gal. UP 1.24, etc.; τ. ἱππηγοί IG 2(2).1627.241.
a ship-shaped drinking-vessel, Antiph. 224.4, Epin. 2.8.
Adj., = τριώροφος, οἰκίαι Aristid. Or. 27(16).20.
D. 47.19; λιμήν Str. 14.2.15, cj. in 13.2.2; αὐλεῖν τὸ τ. (sc. μέλος) Ath. 12.535d; but τὸ τ. the class which serves in a trireme, Arist. Pol. 1291b23.
row in a trireme, Poll. 1.98.
one who goes in a trireme, esp. as a soldier or rower, Hdt. 5.85, Th. 6.46, X. An. 6.6.7; τριηρέτης is f. l. in Poll. 1.95.
of or like a trireme, ὑποζώματα IG 2(2).1629.70,100,134: for τριηρετικὰ σκεύη App. Praef. 10, Pun. 96, and -ρετικοὶ φάσηλοι Id. BC 5.95, τριηριτ- shd. be read.
Hsch.
of or for trireme-building, IG 2(2).1627.391 ( -ποιϊκ-), 1628.534 ( -ποιϊκ-), 1622.389 ( -ποϊκ-): cf. sq. [τριηροποιός]
building triremes, IG 1(2).93.4, 97.20, al., Arist. Ath. 46.1; but τῶν τριηροποι<ικ>ῶν ταμίας is prob. cj. in D. 22.17.
of three seas, touching on or connected with three seas, Ephor. 119 J.
λόχια, = πολυθαλῆ λοχεύματα, Antim. in PMilan. 17.33.
thrice-blooming: τριθαλές, τό, = ἀείζωον μικρόν, Plin. HN 25.160.

definition: τριθαλλίαι μεγάλως τοῦ θάλλειν αἰτίαι, Hsch.

children.definition: thrice-placed, thrice-folded, Eust. 1154.31.
three days ago, Herod. 3.24 ( τριτ- 6.21, and so τριτημέρᾳ, Gloss.)
nudiustertianus, Gloss.
building with three doors, Supp.Epigr. 4.446.15 ( Didyma, iii B. C.), cf. Gloss.
triga, Gloss.; also τριίππιν (i. e. -ιον), ib.
involving three reeds, ὀνειροθαυπτάνη (sic, v. ὀνειραυτοπτικός) τρικαλαμία PMag.Par. 1.3172.
EM 766.22, Phot.

the Three-headed, a satirical attack on three cities, Sparta, Athens, and Thebes, written by Anaximenes of Lampsacus ( Frr. 20 and 21 J.) and ascribed by him to Theopompus, Paus. 6.18.5, Luc. Pseudol. 29, Fug. 32; also a satire by Varro on the coalition of Caesar, Pompeius, and Crassus, App. BC 2.9.

definition: τρικάρηνος [ᾰ], Dor. τρῐ-κάρᾱνος, ον, poet. for τρικέφαλος,

children.definition: three-headed, Πτωΐου κευθμών Pi. Fr. 101 (codd. Str., -καράνου Bgk.), cf. Coluth. 14, etc.; τ. ὄφις Hdt. 9.81.
bearing fruit or crops thrice a year, ἄρουραι D.H. 1.37.

children.label: II
children.definition: Hsch.
spherical triangle, Hero *Stereom. 1.96.

definition: τρικεράμιον [ᾰ], τό, Dim. of sq., Sammelb. 6964.
τρικέραμον, τό, a liquid measure, ib. Sammelb. 6965, al.

children.definition: a threefold Cerberus, κύων Tz. H. 2.751.
three-headed, γῦπες Luc. VH 1.11, etc.:— ὁ T. a statue of Hermes at Athens, Is. Fr. 59, Philoch. 69, cf. Ar. Fr. 553. [Penult. in Poets sts. long, as Hes. Th. 287.]

data.ref: Ar. Fr. 553. [Penult. in Poets sts. long, as

definition: τρίκκος ὀρνιθάριον <ὁ> καὶ βασιλεὺς ὑπὸ Ἠλείων, Hsch.
τρικλαρία, ἁ, Dor. for *τρικληρία, epith. of Artemis in Achaea, Paus. 7.19.1, 7.22.11.

children.definition: directorship of feasts, BCH 11.385, 15.186, 204 ( Panamara).

definition: τρικλινιάρχης, ου, ὁ, in Lat. form

children.definition: tricliniarches, director of a feast, Petron. 22; title of an imperial official, CIL 3.536 ( Corinth).

data.ref: Petron. 22; title of an imperial official,

children.definition: for a τρίκλινος II, τρίποδες POsl. 60 (ii A. D.).
Theopomp.Com. 64.
with three couches, θάλαμοι Moschio ap. Ath. 5.207c; τ. οἶκοι Ath. 2.47f, cf. Poll. 6.7.

children.label: II
children.definition: Subst. τρίκλινος (sc. οἶκος), ὁ, AB 114, Eust. 1573.29, Gloss.; also τρίκλινον, τό, SIG 1097.29 ( Athens, iv B. C.), Anaxandr. 70, Arched. 2.12, Plb. 30.26.3, BGU 388 ii 21 (ii A. D.):— dining-room with three couches, συναγαγὼν τρεῖς ὄντας εἰς τ. Antiph. 299.
τ. συγγενείας a family party, Men. 923.1; ὅλον τ. (acc.) a whole dinner-party, Dsc. 5.71, cf. Anaxandr. l.c., Arched. l.c.
set of three couches, οὐχ ὑποστρώσεις τ.; Amphis 46, cf. SIG l.c., Plb. l.c., Plu. Caes. 55, POxy. 1277.7, 23 (iii A. D.).

children.label: III
children.definition: τρίκλινος ἤτοι ὡρεῖον a barn (?) or a granary, Hero *Stereom. 1.46.
thrice washed or cleansed, Ar. Fr. 875.
with or of three shoots, Sch. Theoc. 3.29.
thrice-spun, three-twisted, of a line, AP 6.109 ( Antip.).
with three κόγχαι or apses (v. κόγχη IV), τὸ τ. σῖγμα Princeton Exp.Inscr. 111 A No.561 (Syria, V A.D.).
terniones, tuberes, Gloss.
with three grains or berries, Sch. Il. 14.183:— τρίκοκκος, ὁ, = μέσπιλον, Dsc. 1.118; = ἡλιοτρόπιον τὸ μέγα, Plin. HN 22.60; ἡλιοτρόπιον τ. Aët. 12.63.
a three-κόλλυβος piece, Poll. 9.72, Hsch.
thrice-docked or cut short, πυραμίς Nicom. Ar. 2.14.
three-hilled, Orac. ap. Str. 6.1.5.
thrice deserving to be killed, Hsch.; cf. ἐπικονέω, κονή.
= sq., Αἴας E. Or. 1480 (lyr.).
with triple plume, Κορύβαντες E. Ba. 123 (lyr.).
three-pointed or -topped, φρούριον Str. 6.1.5; with three peaks, ὄρος Id. 9.2.34, Polyaen. 1.1.2.
thrice a crowʼs age, AP 11.69 ( Lucill.), Alciphr. 1.28, AP 5.288 ( Agath.).

definition: τρικοτυλιαῖος, α, ον, = sq. 1, Alex.Aphr. de An. 141.10.
τρικότυλος, ον ( η, ον Inscr.Délos 1432 Ab ii 30 (ii B. C.)),

children.definition: holding three κοτύλαι, Ar. Th. 743, Dionys.Com. 5, Men. 324.

children.label: II
children.definition: οἶνος τ. costing an obol for three κοτύλαι, Hsch.

definition: τρίκουρος ὁ ἐπὶ τρία ἔτη κεκ[αθ]αρμένος κριός, ὁμοίως καὶ ὁ μὴ κεκ[αθ]αρμένος, Hsch.

children.definition: three-headed, Ἅιδου σκύλαξ, of Cerberus, S. Tr. 1098, cf. E. HF 611, 1277; μήτηρ τ., of Rhea, prob. in CIG 4121 ( Galatia).
with triple border, Archim. Bov. 39.
three-cleft, δίκραν ἢ τρίκραν (fort. δικρᾶν ἢ τρικρᾶν) Thphr. HP 9.11.3; cf. δίκροος.
rowed with triple stroke, of a trireme, Aristid. Or. 25(43).4; sc. ναῦς, Sch. Ael. Tact. p.234K.-R.: cf. δίκροτος, μονόκροτος.
triply resounding, epith. of the Moon-goddess, PMag.Par. 1.2524, 2820.
holding three κύαθοι, Anacr. 32.
thrice-rolled, gloss on τρικαλίνδητος, EM 766.22, Phot.
easily influenced, Epicur. Fr. 125.

group of three waves, τὸ μέγιστον [κῦμα] τῆς τ. Pl. R. 472a; ἑτέραν περιμεῖναι χἀτέραν τ. Men. 536.8: then, a mighty wave or swell, E. Hipp. 1213, Tr. 83 (pl.), Id. ap. Satyr. Vit.Eur.Fr. 38 iii 14, Com.Adesp. in PSI 10.1176.11: metaph. κακῶν τ. A. Pr. 1015; σῶσαι ἐκ τῆς τ. τοῦ λόγου Pl. Euthd. 293a; ἐν ἁπάσαις τ. τῆς τύχης Luc. Dem.Enc. 33; αἱ τῶν βασάνων τ. LXX 4 Ma. 7.2.

data.quote: σῶσαι ἐκ τῆς τ. τοῦ λόγου

children.definition: three-limbed, i.e. three-pronged, ὀβελός SIG 1025.53 ( Cos, iv/iii B. C.).
three-membered, μερίοδος Hermog. Inv. 4.3, cf. Demetr. Eloc. 17: τρίκωλον, τό, a sentence of three clauses, D.H. Comp. 9, Quint. Inst. 9.3.77, cf. Donat. ad Ter. Hec. 291.
chief official of a τρικωμία, IG 2(2).1213.
group of three villages, IGRom. 4.1367 ( Lydia); as place-name in Egypt, PEnteux. 82.1 (iii B. C.), etc.
inhabitant of a τρικωμία, IG 2(2).1213.
holding three bottles, Stesich. 7, POxy. 741.12 (ii A. D.).
thrice said, gloss on τρίφατον, Sch. Nic. Th. 102.
of three threads: τὸ τ. necklace of three strings of pearls, Gloss.

definition: τρίλλιστος, ον, poet. for *τρίλιστος, ( λίτομαι, λίσσομαι)

children.definition: thrice, i.e. often or earnestly, prayed for, Il. 8.488. Adv. -τως AP 5.270 ( Maced.).
three-lobed, ἧπαρ [τοῦ σκάρου] Arist. Fr. 330.
use a word in three forms, Eust. 1798.25 ( Pass.).
trilogy, group of three dialogues, Ar.Byz. ap. D.L. 3.61; group of three tragedies, Aristarch. et Apollon. ap. Sch. Ar. Ra. 1155.
triple crest, Ar. Av. 94, Str. 3.3.6 (pl.), 10.4.6.

children.label: II
children.definition: three-crested helmet, Plu. Arat. 32.
with three crests, κράνος Polyaen. 8.59.

children.label: II
children.definition: with three peaks or points, Nonn. D. 6.124.
thrice-blest, AP 9.396 ( Paul.Sil.), 7.614 ( Agath.).
of three long syllables, Choerob. in Heph. p.217 C.

definition: τριμαστιγίας, ου, ὁ, in Lat. form

children.definition: trimastigia, = triverbero, Gloss.
measure of three μάτια (1/15 ἀρτάβη), Ostr. 1018 (i/ii A. D.).
Dsc. 4.46, Gloss. (but τρι<χο>μάχιον cj. Wellm. (in Dsc.) from tricamachion, v.l. in Apul. Herb. 39).
consisting of three μέλη, νόμος Plu. Mus. 2.1132d; v. τριμερής.
division into three parts, Sallust. 11, Procl. in Alc. p.216 C., Herm. in Phdr. p.157A.

tripartite, threefold, ἡ φυχή Arist. VV 1249a30, cf. Top. 133a31; ποταμός Agatharch. 95; of a country, Str. 11.2.18; ὧραι D.S. 1.11; στάσις J. BJ 5.1.1; φιλοσοφία Plu. 2.874e; δρᾶμα Gal. in Abh.Berl.Akad. 1925(1).38; νόμος τ. a piece of music in the three modes (Dorian, Phrygian, Lydian), Plu. Mus. 2.1134b (nisi leg. τριμελής). Adv. τριμερῶς Gloss.
divide into three parts, τὰ ὅρια τῆς γῆς LXX De. 19.3.

consisting of three μέτρα; i. e. in iambics, trochaics, and anapaestics, of three συζυγίαι (of two feet each); but in dactylics, etc., of three single feet: hence the iambic verse of six feet is called by the Greeks ἴαμβος τρίμετρος, Hdt. 1.12; so τόνος τ. trimeter verse, ib. 174; ἔπη τ. Pl. Lg. 810e; τρίμετρον, τό, Ar. Nu. 642, Arist. Po. 1447b11 (pl.).

children.label: II
children.definition: τρίμετρος, ὁ, a measure of capacity for oil, IG 14.422 iii 44 ( Tauromenium).
space of three months, PRev.Laws 22.1, 34.21 (iii B. C.).
κριθαί Hp. Mul. 1.44, cf. Thphr. CP 3.24.2, Dsc. 2.85; = τρίμηνος 2, D.L. 8.78; τριμηνιαία, ἡ, space of three months, Vett.Val. 98.23:— τριμηναῖος is a freq. f.l.

of three months, χρόνος S. Tr. 164; so ἡ τ. period of three months, Hdt. 2.124, IG 2(2).1358 ii 7, 11, al., PCair.Zen. 124.5, 440.4 (iii B. C.); τὸ τ. Plb. 1.38.6, etc.; τ. παιδία born after three months, Com.Adesp. 213: neut. as Adv., τρίμηνα ἐκτιτρώσκειν Hp. Aph. 5.45.
three months old, Arist. HA 562b28.
πυροὶ τ. wheat sown in spring, so as to ripen in three months, Philyll. 4, cf. Thphr. HP 8.1.4, CP 4.11.1, PCair.Zen. 155.6 (iii B. C.).
a coin worth 1/3 of the aureus, PSI 9.1073 (iv A. D.), PLond. 1.77.73 (vi A. D.), etc.
consisting of a mixture of three ingredients, τροχίσκος Heras ap. Gal. 13.544.

definition: τριμίσκον ἱμάτιον, Ἀσπένδιοι, Hsch. (Cf. τρίμιτος; fort. τριμιτίσκος.)

children.definition: maker of τρίμιτοι II, PLond. in Mém.Inst.Franc. 67.109 (iv A. D.); = triliciarius, Gloss.

definition: τριμίτινος, η, ον, = τρίμιτος 1, A. Fr. 365, Crates Com. 34.

children.definition: three-threaded, i. e. perh. made of drill, δελματικὴ . . τρίμιτος Edict.Diocl. 19.28, cf. IGRom. 3.228 ( Pessinus); but used of felt shoes (dub. sens.) in Lysipp. 3.

children.label: II
children.definition: Subst., τρίμιτος, ὁ, or τρίμιτον, τό, garment of drill or ticking, Cratin.Jun. 5, cf. Poll. 7.78: Dim. τριμίτιον, Id. 6.165; cf. τριμίσκον.
that which is rubbed: metaph., like τρίβων (B) 2, a practised knave, Ar. Nu. 260, Av. 431.

children.label: II
children.definition: a drink or brew prepared of pounded groats and spices, Alex. 188, Sotad.Com. 1.4, Axionic. 4.8 (anap.); τριμμάτων πλῆθος Diocl. Fr. 138; ὅπως λαβὼν παρ ἐμοῦ . . σησάμου τέταρτον τρίψῃ μοι . . τ. UPZ 62.21 (ii B. C.); = ἀρωματίζον τόμα ἐν γάμοις πινόμενον, Hsch.

data.quote: ὅπως λαβὼν παρ ἐμοῦ . . σησάμου τέταρτον τρίψῃ μοι . . τ.

children.definition: fragments, μοχλῶν IG 2(2).1672.303 ( τρινματα lapis), cf. 7.3073.165 ( Lebad., ii B. C.); scrapings, Hp. Nat.Mul. 32.

children.label: III
children.definition: abrasion, Gal. 13.181.

definition: τριμμάτιον, τό, Dim. of foreg. II.1, Sotad.Com. 1.17, Diph. 44.5.

children.definition: shampoo-powder, Archig. ap. Aët. 6.7.
smooth, polish, τὰς βάσεις ἐκ χλόης IG 7.3073.162 ( Lebad., ii B. C.).
beaten track, X. Cyn. 3.7, 4.3, Ael. Fr. 114, D.C. 56.20.
= sq., γόμφος SIG 246 ii 41 ( Delph., iv B. C.).
worth or weighing three minae, Poll. 6.165.
a three-mina piece, Phot., Suid.
triple pay, X. HG 6.1.6, Luc. Tim. 57.
arc of three degrees, Vett.Val. 139.15.
amounting to three-fourths, Apollod. Poliorc. 162.8 codd. ( τριτημοριαῖος Schneider).
a shipʼs officer receiving triple pay, Luc. JTr. 48.
threefold, triple, χλαῖνα A. Ag. 872; three parts to one, Antyll. ap. Orib. 10.13.13.
Orph. A. 1056 (dub.).

three-formed, Ἑκάτη τριοδῖτι, τρίμορφε, τριπρόσωπε Chariclid. 1, cf. Lyc. 1176, Corn. ND 34; τὸν τ. θεὸν ἔτι κυόμενον ἐν τῷ ᾠῷ Orph. Fr. 60; χαῖρε πάτερ κόσμου, χαῖρε τρίμορφε θεός CIG 4971 ( Egypt), Sammelb. 6128.

data.quote: τὸν τ. θεὸν ἔτι κυόμενον ἐν τῷ ᾠῷ
χαῖρε πάτερ κόσμου, χαῖρε τρίμορφε θεός

children.definition: three fates, A. Pr. 516.
with three wicks, Metag. 12, Inscr.Délos 1417 A i72 (ii B. C.), IG 7.2422 ( Thebes, ii/i B. C.), 3498.8 (Orop.).
Σικανία acc. to Th. 6.2; older than Θρινακία acc. to Str. 6.2.1:— Adj. Τρῑνάκριος, α, ον, Call. Fr. 18, etc.; fem. Τρῑνακρίς, ίδος, Opp. H. 3.627.—Also written Τρῑνᾰκίη, D.P. 467, Eust. ad loc.

children.label: II
children.definition: Τρῑναχία (sic Pap.), ἡ, triple, as epith. of the Moon-goddess, PMag.Par. 1.2525; written Θρινακία ib. 2822.
three-pronged mattock, AP 6.104 ( Phil.) [where ι is short].
lord of three islands, Tz. H. 2.328.
space of three nights, Gloss. (formed like τριήμερον).
gryllus, Gloss. (Cf. τρωξαλλίς).
three sextarii, one semicongium, Gloss.

definition: τριξός, ή, όν, Ion. for τρισσός, Hdt. 1.171, al.

children.definition: containing three sticks, or three ξύλα (v. ξύλον V) in length, δέσμαι Theb.Ostr. 144 (i A. D.).

definition: τριοβολιαῖος, τρῐ-ιμαῖος, ff.ll. for τριωβ- (q. v.): τριόβολον, τό,

children.definition: Sammelb. 7378.11 (ii A. D.).

definition: τρίογδον μέτρον τι παρὰ Ταραντίνοις, Hsch.

belonging to Hecate or Cybele (cf. τριοδῖτις), Cibeles triodeia signa, CIL 6.511 ( Rome, iv A. D.).
meeting of three roads, Lat. trivium, Gloss.

definition: τριόδιον, τό, = foreg., in gen. pl., AB 102.

children.label: II
children.definition: τριοδῖτις, ιδος, ἡ, epith. of Hecate, who was worshipped at the meeting of three ways, Chariclid. 1, cf. Corn. ND 34.

common, vulgar, Μοῦσα Tz. H. 12.513.
Pythag. name of 6, Anatol. ap. Theol.Ar. 37.
fishing with a trident or leister, Pl. Sph. 220e, Poll. 7.139.
Dim. of τριόδους II.1, Gloss.

a meeting of three roads, Thgn. 911, Pi. P. 11.38 (where the pl. [cj.] is used for the sg., cf. Mosch. 1.2, Epigr.Gr. 841 ( Thrace), IG 3.1418.2); τροχήλατος σχιστῆς κελεύθου τρίοδος A. Fr. 173, cf. E. Supp. 1212, Pherecr. 130.3 (anap., pl.), Ar. Fr. 204 (pl.), Pl. Grg. 524a, etc.

children.definition: [Ἑκάτη] ναίουσʼ ἱερὰς τ. S. Fr. 535 (anap.); ἁ θεὸς ἐν τριόδοισι Theoc. 2.36; the τρίοδοι were frequented by fortune-tellers and loungers, Thphr. Char. 16.5, 14, Aristid. Or. 22 ( 19). 10; φαρμακοπώλης ἐκτριόδου Gal. 9.823; ἐκτῆς τ. ἰατροί Id. 10.786: hence οἷα ἐκ τριόδου, i. e. vulgar, Luc. Hist.Conscr. 16, etc.; λοιδορίαι ἐξ ἐργαστηρίων καὶ τριόδων D.C. 46.4; of certain women, τρίοδοί τινες . . ἐγένοντο Clearch. 25 ( τριοδίτιδες cj. Lobeck).
ἐν τριόδῳ δʼ ἕστηκα Thgn. l.c.; στὰς . . , καθάπερ ἐν τ. γενόμενος Pl. Lg. 799c; ἐν τ. εἰμί Zen. 3.78, etc.
μέτρῳ τῷ καλουμένῳ BGU 920.21 (ii A. D.).
the ‘trivium’, Simp. in Cael. 131.28.
τὰς συμφωνούσας ἁρμονίας τ. Ion Eleg. 3.2.

children.label: II
children.definition: Chrysipp. ap. S.E. P. 1.69 (cf. Stoic. 2.206).
with three teeth, three-pronged, κρεάγρα LXX 1 Ki. 2.13.

children.label: II
children.definition: τριόδους, ὁ, as Subst., = τρίαινα, trident, Pi. O. 9.30, I. 8(7).37, Pae. 4.43; Ποσειδάνιος τ. B. Fr. 6; trident, leister, for spearing fish, Pl. Sph. 220c, Epicr. 7, Arist. Fr. 338, Thphr. Fr. 178, Inscr.Délos 1408 D 8 (ii B. C.), cf. AP 11.126.
τ. πλάγιος, of the letter E, Agatho 4.4, Theodect. 6.5.
triple in form, τὸ μεσότητι προσκεχρημένον τ. Pythag. ap. Porph. VP 51.
with three branches or boughs, Thphr. HP 1.1.8, al.
consisting of three Olympian goddesses, ἅρμα, of the goddesses judged by Paris (cf. τρίπωλος), S. Fr. 511 (lyr.).
team of three donkeys, BGU 15 ii 13 (ii A. D.), PFlor. 2.205, 211 (iii A. D.).

definition: Τριόπιον, τό, a headland of Caria, Hdt. 1.174, Th. 8.35; on which was a temple consecrated to the Dorian worship of Apollo, τὸ Τριοπικὸν ἱρόν, ὁ Τριόπιος Ἀπόλλων, Hdt. 1.144.

children.label: II
children.definition: Phot. (s. v. l.); ζῷον ὅμοιον ἀκρίδι, Hsch.
with three testicles: metaph., very lecherous, Timae. 145.

children.label: II
children.definition: buzzard, Buteo vulgaris, Ar. Av. 1181, cf. Arist. HA 592b3, 609a24, 620a17, Thphr. HP 9.8.7; τριόρχας αἰετούς Lyc. 148; παῖδες τ. (with pun on ὀρχέομαι) Ar. V. 1534 cod. B ( -οις codd. RV) (lyr.); v. τρίορχος.

children.label: III
children.definition: Plin. HN 25.69 (where triorchis, mistranslating Thphr. l.c.).
Aët. 15.13, Paul.Aeg. 4.25.
Semon. 9, Ar. Av. 1206, Com.Adesp. 592; gloss on μέρμνης, Hsch.; cf. μερμνάδαι· οἱ τ. παρὰ Λυδοῖς, Andron ap. Gloss.Oxy. 1802.46.

children.label: II
children.definition: v.l. for τριόρχης in Ar. V. 1534 (lyr.).

definition: τριοτό, a sound imitative of a birdʼs voice, Ar. Av. 243 (lyr.).

children.definition: three pendants like eyes (cf. τρίγληνος), Hdn.Gr. 1.104, Eust. 976.36; Dim. τριόττιον, τό, ibid.:— a form τριόττης, ὁ, is also cited in Phot. and EM 766.33; and τριοπίς or τρίοπις by Poll. 5.98, Sch.BT Il. 14.183, Hsch.
a weight of three unciae, IGRom. 1.667 (Tomi, written τρειουνκιν), Dacia 3/4.607 (ibid., τριουνκιν); = quadrans, Gloss.
triumvirum capitalem, Ephes. 3 No.35p.123.
containing three or the τριάς, μονάς Procl. ap. Lyd. Mens. 2.6, cf. Dam. Pr. 117.
three-eyed, Orac. ap. Apollod. 2.8.3, Plu. Curios. 2.520c, etc.
ὁ τ., name of a precious stone, Plin. HN 37.186.
page of three columns, Tz. H. 9.291.
having three children, Plu. Num. 10; τιμὰς διώκει τρίπαιδας, = Lat. jus trium liberorum ( τριπαιδίας cj. Doehner), Id. Am. prol. 2.493e.
long long ago, Ar. Eq. 1153, Luc. Lex. 2; cf. τετράπαλαι.
very old, Phryn. PS p.111 B.; cf. τριπάχυιος.
three hands broad, long, etc., Hdt. 1.50 (with v.l. -πάλαιστα), IG 1(2).373.10, 2(2).1672.156, Inscr.Délos 1432 Bb ii 22, al. (ii B. C.); τριπάλαιστος Heliod. ap. Orib. 48.57.1.
thrice-brandished: metaph., threefold, manifold, A. Th. 990 (lyr., dub. l.).
three-day festival, IG 5(2).3.8 ( Tegea, iv B. C.).
triply base, an arch-rogue, Ἔρως AP 12.57 ( Mel.).
ancestor in the sixth generation, Lat. tritavus, Gloss.
consisting of three virgins, ζεῦγος E. Fr. 357.
with triple entrance, ναῦς Moschio ap. Ath. 5.207c.
with three fathers, Lyc. 328.
having three fathers, name of Tritogeneia, AP 15.25.26 ( Besant.); of Orion, Nonn. D. 13.99.

children.label: II
children.definition: τριπάτορες, οἱ, = πρόπαπποι or οἱ πρῶτοι ἀρχηγέται, AB 307.

thrice-fattened, thrice-gorged, epith. of the δαίμων of the Atridae (perh. in allusion to the three visitations mentioned in A. Ch. 1065- 74), Ag. 1476 (lyr.):—the word is doubtful; Bamberger proposed τριπάχυντον, referring to Th. 771; Blomf. τριπάλαιον; Bamberger (olim) τριπαλαιστήν.

data.ref: Ag. 1476 (lyr.):—the word is doubtful; Bamberger proposed

children.definition: three feet long, διάμετρος Plb. 6.22.2; θριγκοί IG 7.3073.76 ( Lebad., ii B. C.).
a slave who has been often in fetters, Ar.Byz. ap. Hdn. Epim. 289, Eust. 725.30, 1542.49.

definition: τρίπεζαν τὴν τράπεζαν, Βοιωτοί, Hsch. (v. τράπεζα fin.).

children.definition: childish from age, Plu. Comm.not. 2.1071c: cf. πέμπελος.
consisting of three πενθημιμερῆ, Heph. 15.12.
years ago, a rather vulgar word acc. to Poll. 6.165.
three-leafed, or perh. three-branched, of Hermes’ wand, h.Merc. 530.

children.label: II
children.definition: Subst. τριπέτηλον, τό, = τρίφυλλον, Call. Dian. 165, Nic. Th. 522.

trot of a horse, Hippiatr. 34.

three cubits long or tall, ὕπερον τρίπηχυν Hes. Op. 423; εἴδωλον τρίπηχυ Hdt. 1.51; παλλάδιον τρίπηχυ Apollod. 3.12.3; ῥῖνα τρίπηχυν AP 11.267; κροκόδιλοι ὅσον τε τριπήχεες Hdt. 4.192; κλῳῷ τριπήχει E. Cyc. 235; τόξα τριπήχη X. An. 4.2.28; καταπάλτας τριπήχεις IG 2(2).1467.53, Plb. 5.88.7; ῥάβδους τριπήχεις Dsc. 1.100: metaph., ἔπη τριπήχη Crates Com. 19 ( ἐπεὶ codd. Ath.):—also τριπήχης, ες, Hdn.Gr. 1.82.
thrice or thoroughly apish, ῥύγχος AP 11.196 ( Lucill.).
wandered through by three, ποδηγία, of the three Gorgons, Lyc. 846.

definition: τριπλανήτης, ου, ὁ, in Dor. form τριπλανάτας,

triple, threefold, ἄντυξ Il. 18.480; cf. δίπλαξ.
to triple, take three times, Apollod. 2.4.8, Plu. An.procr. 2.1028b, Dam. Pr. 98:— Pass., Plu. Arist. 24:—hence τριπλᾰσῐ-ασμός, ὁ, a tripling, Id. An.procr. 2.1028c (pl.).

definition: τριπλασιεπιδιμερής, ές, τριπλᾰσῐ-επίπεμπτος, τριπλᾰσῐ-επιτέταρτος, τριπλᾰσῐ-επιτετρᾰμερής, τριπλᾰσῐ-επιτρῐμερής, τριπλᾰσῐ-επίτρῐτος, τριπλᾰσῐ-εφήμῐσυς,

thrice as many, thrice as much, thrice as great as, c. gen., ὄρνις τ. Κλεωνύμου Ar. Ach. 88, etc.; τριπλασίᾳ τῆς πρώτης ζημίας Pl. Lg. 756d; τριπλασίοις αὑτῶν Id. R. 422c; τριπλασίας τιμῆς ἢ πρότερον D. 42.31: abs., τ. δύναμιν εἶχε (sc. τῆς προτέρας) X. An. 7.4.21; τ. διαστήματα Pl. Ti. 36a; τριπλάσιον, opp. τριτημόριον, Arist. Metaph. 1020b27.
Adv., τριπλάσιον κεκράξομαί σου thrice as much as you, Ar. Eq. 285 (lyr.), cf. 718:— regul. Adv. -ίως Sch.B Il. 21.80, v.l. in LXX Si. 43.4.
triplicity, Nicom. Ar. 2.5.
Archim. Circ. 3, al., Arr. Tact. 16.12, Procl. Hyp. 4.101; λόγος Ph. 1.22.
three πλέθρα wide, Pl. Criti. 115d, X. An. 5.6.9, Inscr.Cret. 1. v 21 ( Arcades, ii B. C.).
thrice-plaited, threefold, τ. εἶναι ἡμῶν τὸ σῶμα Sor. 2.4; three-dimensional (?), σχῆμα Procl. Theol.Plat. 5.37.
three-sided, Str. 5.1.2; Astrol., trine, of aspect, Max. 52, 447, Cat.Cod.Astr. 1.146; facing three ways, of a column on the march, Arr. Tact. 28.4, 5, Ael. Tact. 36.4, 5.

children.definition: τρίπλευρα, τά, perh. part of a victim, SIG 982.22 ( Pergam., ii B. C.).
producing a triplet, dub. l. in Dam. Pr. 123bis.
triplicity, Dam. Pr. 117.
triplicity, threefold division, of ἀγγεῖα into νεῦρα φλέβες ἀρτηρίαι, Gal. 14.697 (prob. Erasistr.).
triplex, Gloss.

definition: τριπλόος, η, ον, contr. τριπλοῦς, ῆ, οῦν,

children.definition: triple, threefold, καλλίνικος ὁ τ., because this hymn of victory was thrice repeated, Pi. O. 9.2; ἐν τ. ἁμαξιτοῖς, = ἐν τριόδῳ, S. OT 716; τ. ζεῦγος, of persons, E. Fr. 773.61 (anap.); ὄνομα τ. compounded of three, Arist. Po. 1457a34; τριπλοῦν ἀποτινέτω PRev.Laws 19.14 (iii B. C.); εἰσπράξαντα τριπλῆν τὴν πρᾶξιν PMich.Zen. 71.7 (iii B. C.); χόριον τ. Sor. 1.58; Att. neut. pl. τριπλᾶ A. Pers. 1033 (lyr.), Ch. 792 (lyr.), etc. Adv. -πλῶς Procl. in Prm. p.656S.; gloss on τριχθά, Hdn. Epim. 134: but dat. fem. τριπλῇ is used as Adv. in Il. 1.128, Luc. Pseudol. 32.
multiply by three, triple, Sm. Ec. 4.12, Hdn. Gr. 1.448.
tripling, PLeid.X. 6, PHolm. 2.15.
three-legged stand, κάδον ἐπὶ -ου καθηλωμένον Inscr.Délos 1417 A ii 153 (ii B. C.).
three-footed, ἕδρη Call. Del. 90: poet. fem. τρῐποδηΐς, ΐδος, Nonn. D. 9.257.

children.label: II
children.definition: τριπόδειον, τό, part of a tripod, different from the πόδες, Inscr.Délos 1449 A ab ii 138.
three feet long, ὄλμον τριπόδην Hes. Op. 423; βαθύτερον τριπόδου X. Oec. 19.3.
bring a tripod, offer it as a sign of victory, esp. in dramatic contests, Str. 9.2.4:—also τριποδοφορέω, Sch. Pi. P. 11.5.
accompanying the carrying of a tripod in procession, μέλος Poll. 4.53, Procl. Chr. ap. Phot. Bibl. p.321B.
stamped with the device of a tripod, δραχμή Inscr.Délos 1439 A bc ii6, 1450.99 (ii B. C.).
metrical phrase of three feet, Aristid.Quint. 1.17, Sch. Ar. Nu. 651.
= Lat. tripedo, Gloss. (cf. tripedio = χορεύω ibid.; but perh. = trot, cf. τρίπηδος).

Dim. of τρίπους, Antiph. 249, Men. 250, CIG 3071 ( Teos), PTeb. 793 vi 8 (ii B. C.), Phld. Acad. Ind. p.44 M.; τ. Δελφικόν Inscr.Délos 442 B 39 (ii B. C.):—so τρῐποδίσκος, ὁ, IG 1(2).658,22.47.7, 7.303.65 ( Oropus), etc.; and τριποδίσκιον, τό, Suid. s.v. ἀνθράκιον.
three-footed, ἡμικάδια PCair.Zen. 14 ( a). 5 (iii B. C.).
tripod-shaped, Eust. 1312.28.
thrice ( i.e. much) longed for, ὦ τριπόθατε Bion 1.58, cf. Mosch. 3.51; εἶαρ τ. Bion Fr. 15.15; τ. Ἄδωνις Hymn. ap. Hippol. Haer. 5.9; also in late Prose, as Luc. Hist.Conscr. 31, etc.

committee representing three cities, Berl.Sitzb. 1927.170 ( Cyrene).
sea-starwort, Aster Tripolium, Thphr. HP 9.19.2 (citing Hes. and Musae.), Dsc. 4.132.

definition: τρίπολις, εως, Ion. ιος, ὁ, ἡ,

Τρίπολις, ἡ, league of three cities, as in Achaea, Plb. 4.81.7, etc.; in Arcadia, Paus. 8.27.4; in Phoenicia, D.S. 16.41, etc.

children.label: II
children.definition: Hsch.
thrice-told, τριπόλιστον οἶτον, of Oedipus, S. Ant. 858 (lyr.). (From *πολίζω = πολέω; cf. ἀναπολίζω = ἀναπολέω).

definition: τριπολιτικός, ὁ, title of a work of Dicaearchus, Cic. Att. 13.32.2, Ath. 4.141a.

children.definition: thrice turned up, thrice ploughed, νειός Il. 18.542, Od. 5.127, Hes. Th. 971; ἴκελον τὸ ξύμπαν τριπόλῳ νειῷ ( τοιποδονίῳ codd.), of an elephantʼs skin, Aret. SD 2.13.
threefold rivalry in toil, AP 6.286 ( Leon.).
thrice-sacked, Τευκρίς AP 15.26.18 ( Dosiad.).
threefold whoredom, by descent, Antiph.Jun. ap. Ath. 13.587b.
a whore in the third degree, Theopomp.Hist. Fr. 244.
Il. 22.164, Hes. Sc. 312, IG 4.801 ( Troezen, vi B. C.) (v. τρίπους fin.); acc. τρίπον AP 3.6 (Inscr. Cyzic.); neut. τρίπον ib. 14.64; gen. τρίπου EM 20.18.

definition: τρίπους [ῐ], ποδος, ὁ, ἡ, πουν, τό,

children.definition: three-footed, of or with three feet: and so,

children.label: I
children.definition: measuring three feet, τ. τὸ εὖρος Hdt. 3.60; τ. πλάτος IG 1(2).372.14, al.; ὅρους . . μὴ ἔλαττον ἢ τρίποδας ib. 2(2).2492.24; τ. [γραμμή] Pl. Men. 83e; ἡ τ. [δύναμις] the side of a square three feet in area, Id. Tht. 147d.

children.label: II
children.definition: going on three feet, prov. of an old man who leans on a staff, τρίποδι βροτῷ Hes. Op. 533 (but τρίποδι βροτοὶ ἶς οι is prob. cj.); τρίποδας ὁδοὺς στείχει A. Ag. 80 (anap.); cf. τριτοβάμων, and see the Sphinxʼs riddle in AP 14.64.

children.label: III
children.definition: three-legged, τ. λέβης A. Fr. 1; τράπεζα Ar. Fr. 530; ὑπόβασις Semus 15 :—but mostly

children.label: IV
children.definition: Subst., τρίπους, ὁ,

tripod, i.e. three-legged cauldron, Il. 18.344, Od. 8.434, etc.; τ. ἐμπυριβήτης Il. 23.702; ὑψίβατος τ. ἀμφίπυρος S. Aj. 1405 (anap.); ἄπυροι τ. tripods untouched by fire, i.e. new, unused, Il. 9.122, cf. Paus. 4.32.1; used as κρατῆρες, Semus l.c., Phylarch. 44J.; given as prizes, Il. 11.700, 23.264, al.; as gifts of honour, 8.290, Od. 13.13; in Crete used as currency, GDI 4969.130; placed as votive gifts in temples, esp. in that of Apollo at Delphi, Th. 1.132, SIG 697 L 3 ( Delph., ii B. C.), etc.; ἡ τοῦ τ. ἀνάθεσις Lys. 21.2; these were then called τ. ἀναθηματικοί, Δελφικοί, Apollon. Lex.; a street at Athens adorned with these gifts was called οἱ Τρίποδες, Paus. 1.20.1; or they were preserved in private houses, Pi. I. 1.19; they were mostly of bronze, Paus. 4.12.8, but sts. of precious metals, even of gold, Pi. P. 11.4, Hdt. 9.81, Ar. Pl. 9, Paus. 10.13.9; sts. of wood, ξύλινοι τ. Id. 4.12.8; from a tripod the Delphic Priestess delivered her oracles, E. Ion 91 (anap.), Or. 164 (lyr.), Orac. ap. Ar. Eq. 1016, etc.: metaph., ὁπόταν ἐν τῷ τ. τῆς Μούσης καθίζηται [ὁ ποιητής] Pl. Lg. 719c: prov., ἐκ τρίποδος λέγειν, i. e. authoritatively, Ath. 2.37f; τὰ ἀπὸ τ., τὰ ἐκ τ., Zen. 6.3, Diogenian. 8.21, cf. Plu. Dem. 29.

three-legged table, X. An. 7.3.21, Plu. Cleom. 13; κύκλος τρίποδος the circular top of . . , Artem. 5.20, cf. 1.74.
ear-ring, Poll. 5.97.
Ath. 14.637b. (The oldest nom. of stem τριποδ- is prob. τρίπος (q. v.), which comes from τριποδ-ς but was later regarded as an o-stem.)

one must rub or grind, Gal. 6.229, Gp. 5.51.2.

horse-trough, τριπτῆρες τέτταρες τὰ ζεύγη ποτίζειν ἐν τῇ ὁδῷ IG 2(2).1673.21.

bath-rubber, shampooer, Plu. Alex. 40.
Triptolemus, an Eleusinian, who spread the worship of Demeter, h.Cer. 153, etc.

with three case-forms, Choerob. in Theod. 1.335 H., Priscian Inst. 5.14.76, etc.

of or with three horses, ἅρματα D.H. 7.73; τ. ἅρμα δαιμόνων . . καλλιζυγές, of the three goddesses on Mount Ida, E. Andr. 277 (lyr.).
with three roots, ὀδόντες Gal. 2.753.

thrice, three times, τ. τόσσα thrice as much or many, Il. 1.213, cf. 5.136; δὶς καὶ τ. Thgn. 633, S. Aj. 433, etc.; δὶς ἢ τ. Ar. Pax 1181 (troch.); τ. τετράκι τε Pi. N. 7.104; ἐς τ. thrice, Id. O. 2.68, Hdt. 1.86, 5.105, GDI iv p.884 ( Erythrae, iv B. C.), Theoc. 1.25, 2.43; ἐπὶ τρίς thrice, Act. Ap. 10.16, 11.10, Dsc. Eup. 2.19; freq. used merely to intensify the notion, τ. λελουμένη Eub. 102, etc.; esp. in compds., such as τρισάθλιος, τρίσμακαρ, etc., cf. τρι-, τριάζω, τρικυμία; but such words may sts. be written divisim, τρὶς ἄθλιος, etc.: prov., τ. ἓξ βαλεῖν throw thrice six (the highest throw, there being three dice), A. Ag. 33, cf. Pl. Lg. 968e; τρὶς ἓξ νικητήριος βόλος App. Prov. 4.99; ἢ τ. ἓξ ἢ τρεῖς κύβοι Pherecr. 124. [ ῐ: in Hes. Op. 173 long by position before ( ϝ) έτεος.] (I.-E. tris, cf. Skt. tris, Lat. ter.)

AP 5.229 ( Paul.Sil.).

thrice-abominable, Suid. s.v. Διονυσίων σκωμμάτων.
the thrice-ninth ( = 27th) day in a month, Hes. Op. 814.
of three moons or nights, epith. of Heracles (cf. τριέσπερος), AP 9.441 ( Pall.), Nonn. D. 7.126; νύξ APl. 16.102.
πλάτος τ. of three moons in breadth, of the earthʼs shadow, Plu. Fac.lun. 2.923b.

thrice-accursed, strengthd. for ἐξώλης, Eust. 725.29.
thrice an ἔπαρχος, i.e. Praefectus Urbis, AP 9.697.
thrice-barbarous, Tz. H. 10.72.
thrice-happy, B. 3.10, Luc. Sacr. 2, Merc.Cond. 3, etc.

thrice-detested, Phryn. PS p.112B.

in three rows, Il. 10.473; τριστοιχεί, Hes. Th. 727, and many codd. of Il. l.c. (perh. rightly).
