children.definition: in three rows, ὀδόντες Od. 12.91, Ctes. ap. Arist. HA 501a27; κριθαί Thphr. HP 8.4.2; equipped with three rows (of teeth), χείλεα Opp. C. 3.413.

children.label: II
children.definition: threefold, triple, μαστός, βόθρος, AP 9.668.5 ( Marian.), Orph. A. 951; τ. κεφαλαί, of Cerberus, Hermesian. 7.12.
three-edged or three-pointed, αἰχμή AP 6.167 ( Agath.); τ. δόρυ, of the trident, Max.Tyr. 10.8; with three mouths, Ῥοδανός Str. 4.1.8.

children.label: II
children.definition: τρίστομον, τό, dub. sens., prob. place-name, in PTeb. 112.2, al. ( ii B. C., cf. ii p.405); σιτολόγοι Τριστόμου Ostr. 1097 (ii A. D.), cf. BGU 1072 iii 2 (ii A. D.), etc.
possessing a triple colonnade, IGRom. 4.662 ( Acmonia).
thrice-twisted, λίνον Meges ap. Orib. 44.24.12.
consisting of three strophes, Sch. Pi. O. 9.1.
consist of three syllables, Hdn.Gr. 2.927.
compass of three syllables, οὐχ ὑπερβαίνει τὴν τ. Sch.D.T. p.137 H.
trisyllabic, D.H. Comp. 17, A.D. Synt. 8.1, Heph. 3.2, Luc. Philops. 35. Adv. -βως A.D. Pron. 78.23.
compounded of three elements, Sch. D Il. 24.540.

definition: τρίσφυλλον, τό, poet. for τρίφυλλον, Nic. Th. 520.

children.definition: trischematisti dactylici, series of two dactyls and one spondee capable of being arranged in three orders, Sacerd. p. 506 K.
of triple form, An.Ox. 2.307.
cloven in three, Xenophon Medicus ap. Orib. 45.11.3, Antyll. ap. eund. 45.18.22. Adv. -δῶς Dosith. p.412 K.
of three thousand years, Hierocl. Prov. p.463 B., Simp. in Ph. 499.36.

definition: τρισχίλιοι [ χῑ], αι, α, Dor. τρισ-χήλιοι Abh. Berl.Akad. 1925 (5).25 ( Cyrene):—

children.definition: three thousand, Il. 20.221, Hdt. 7.97, etc.: in sg. with collective Subst., ἀσπὶς τρισχιλία Longus 3.1.

data.ref: Hdt. 7.97, etc.: in sg. with collective

children.label: II
children.definition: οἱ τ., at Athens, the 3000 nominated by the 30 Tyrants, X. HG 2.3.18.
three-thousandth, τ. ἔτει Pl. Phdr. 249a.
thirty-three thousand, Tz. H. 3.67.
holding three thousand (measures), ὁλκάδες D.H. 3.44.
cloven in three, Sch. Nic. Al. 347, An.Ox. 2.307:— τρι-σχίστη, ἡ, gloss on Αἰγυπτία στυπτηρία, Gal. 19.71.
three σχοῖνοι ong or broad, in neut., Str. 17.1.31, cf. Plin. HN 5.85.
three-bodied, of Geryon, A. Ag. 870; κύων, of Cerberus, E. HF 24; τ. ἀλκά, of the Chimaera, Id. Ion 204 (lyr.).
to be a τριταγωνιστής, D. 18.262, 265, etc.; τ. τινί play the third part to another, Plu. VOrat. 2.840a.

definition: τριταγωνιστής, οῦ, ὁ, on the stage,

children.definition: player who took the third part, name of a play by Antiphanes; applied by D. to Aeschines, 18.129,209.
have a tertian fever, Dsc. 4.60, Gal. 7.466.
belonging to a tertian fever ( τριταῖος πυρετός), like one, Dsc. Eup. 2.18, al. Adv. -κῶς Aët. 12.13.
produced by tertian fever, ἀλγήματα Hp. Coac. 120. Adv. -νῶς ib. 299.

on the third day, used with Verbs so as to agree with the subject, τριταῖοι ἐγένοντο ἐν τῇ Ἀττικῇ Hdt. 6.120, cf. Hp. Aph. 4.36, Th. 1.61, 3.3, etc.; τ. ἄνεμος which will blow in three days, Pi. N. 7.17; τριταίαν καρύσσουσιν θυσίαν E. El. 171 (lyr.); τ. ἐκφορά a funeral three days after death, Pl. Lg. 959a; ἐσβεβληκὼς . . τ. ἐς Μηλιέας three days before, Hdt. 7.196, cf. Plb. 15.33.11.

children.label: II
children.definition: three days old, ἰχθύδια τ. Ar. Fr. 387.9; ᾠὰ τ. ὄντα Arist. PA 665a35; φίλος τ. of three days’ standing, Theoc. 29.18; ἐπεὰν τ. γένωνται after being three days dead, Hdt. 2.89.
τριταῖος (sc. πυρετός), ὁ, tertian fever or ague, Hp. Aph. 3.21, Nat.Hom. 15, Pl. Ti. 86a; ὁ ἀκριβὴς τ. Gal. 18(2).246; οἱ τ. πυρετοί Id. 15.755; τ. ῥῖγος POxy. 1151.37 (v A. D.).

children.label: III
children.definition: third, τ. φέγγος, ἡμέρα, E. Hec. 32, Hipp. 275; ἐς τὴν τριταίην Hp. Coac. 225.
of the nature of a tertian fever, Hp. Epid. 1.3 (interpol.), 7, Coac. 26.
holding three talents, ἀγγεῖα Plu. Aem. 33; capable of throwing a weight of three talents, [ ὄργανον] Ph. Bel. 51.44.
of three talents, βάρος Ar. Lys. 338 (lyr.); λίθος τ. weighing three talents, Moschio ap. Ath. 5.208c.
worth three talents, οἶκος Is. 3.18, 49.

children.label: II
children.definition: τριτάλαντον, τό, sum of three talents, Poll. 6.165.
thrice-wretched, AP 7.373 ( Thall.), 583 ( Agath.), etc.
triply-stretched, very long, δόναξ AP 6.192 ( Arch.).
three quarters of an obol, Poll. 9.65.
τρίτος, like μέσσατος for μέσος, Il. 1.252, 14.117, E. Hipp. 135 (lyr.), A.R. 1.53; τριτάτην, abs., in the third place, IG 4.682.14 (Hermione: so Boeckh; τρίτατʼ ἦν Fraenkel).

definition: τριτάω, only in Ep. part., τριτόωσα σελήνη the moon

children.definition: when three days old, Arat. 796.
third prize or place (formed like πρωτεῖα, δευτερεῖα, ἀριστεῖα), Pl. Phlb. 22e: in sg., CIG 2758,2759 ( Aphrodisias).
office of τριτευτής, IGRom. 4.414 (Pergam.).
with triple wall, Choerob. in An.Ox. 2.265.
triad of gods, Ramsay Cities and Bishoprics i p.337.
third part of a μέδιμνος, IPE 12.32 A60 ( Olbia, iii B. C.), Poll. 4.168.
distributor of τριτεῖς, IGRom. 4.477, 1680 (Pergam.), Rev.Phil. 37.311 ( Thyatira, ii A. D.).
hold the office of τριτευτής, CIG 3491, IGRom. 4.1244 (both Thyatira), 414 (Pergam.); dub. sens. in PStrassb. 114.6 (ii B. C.).
= sq., δίεσις Aristid.Quint. 1.9, cf. Apollod. Poliorc. 162.8.

definition: τριτημόριος, α, ον ( ος, ον v. infr.),

children.definition: equal to a third part, c. gen., τριτημορίη ἡ Ἀσσυρίη τῆς ἄλλης Ἀσίης Hdt. 1.192; ἡ τριτημόριος [δίεσις] Cleonid. Harm. 7; λόγος τ. a ratio of 1:3, Theo Sm. p.76H.

data.quote: τριτημορίη ἡ Ἀσσυρίη τῆς ἄλλης Ἀσίης

children.label: II
children.definition: Subst., τριτημόριον, τό, third part, Hdt. 9.34, Th. 2.98, Pl. Phd. 105b, Euc. Sect.Can. 6, etc.
a coin, = τριταρτημόριον, Poll. 9.65.
Philem. 63, 74.
ἔφηβοι serving their third year, IG 5(1).1386 ( Thuria, ii B. C.).
forming a third foot, βάκτρον E. Tr. 275 (lyr.); cf. τρίπους II.

Trito-born, a name of Athena, Il. 4.515, 8.39, Od. 3.378, Hes. Th. 895, 924, IG 14.1389ii 1. (Variously expld. in antiquity, from the lake Τριτωνίς in Libya, from which an old legend represents the goddess to have been born, E. Ion 872 (anap.), cf. Hdt. 4.180; or from Triton, a torrent in Boeotia, Paus. 9.33.7, cf. Apollod. 1.3.6; or from a spring in Arcadia, Paus. 8.26.6; or from τριτώ, Aeol. word for κεφαλή (Sch. Ar. Nu. 985, Tz.ad Lyc. 519; Athamanian acc. to Nic. ( Fr. 145) ap. Hsch.), i.e. head-born; or, born on the third day of the month, Ister 26 (the 23rd, τρίτῃ φθίνοντος, Sch.BT Il. 8.39); or, the third child after Apollo and Artemis, Suid. s.v. τριτογενής; or, as representing Nature, born thrice in the year, D.S. 1.12; or because she was author of the three main bonds of social life, Democr. 1b, 2.)

data.ref: Hdt. 4.180; or from Triton, a torrent in Boeotia,
Apollod. 1.3.6; or from a spring in Arcadia,

children.label: II
children.definition: Ἀθηνᾶ τ. to the equilateral triangle, Plu. Isid. 2.381e; cf. τρεῖς, τριάς.

definition: Τριτογενής, έος, ἡ, collat. form of foreg., h.Hom. 28.4, Orac. ap. Hdt. 7.141, Ar. Eq. 1189, IG 1(2).529, al.

children.label: II
children.definition: παῖς μοι τριτογενὴς εἴη, μὴ τριτογένεια, apptly. of children born on the third or 23rd of the month (" ἀρρενώδεις γὰρ αἱ τοιαῦται γυναῖκες"), Sch.BT Il. 8.39, cf. Suid. s.v. τριτογένεια.
bear three times or three at a birth, AP 9.430 ( Crin.); Adj. τρῐ-τόκος in the Lemma.

definition: τριτοκούρη ᾗ πάντα συντετέλεσται τὰ εἰς γάμους· τινὲς δὲ γνησία παρθένος, Hsch.; cf. τρητοκουρήτας.

children.definition: have one third of oneʼs property confiscated, PGnom. 165 (ii A. D.).

definition: τριτομηνίς, ίδος, ἡ, for ἡ τρίτη τοῦ μηνός,

children.definition: the third of the month, at Athens sacred to Pallas, Lycurg. Fr. 49, Ister 26. (Proparox. in AB 308, Suid.)

thrice-cut, IG 1(2).314.108: τρίτομον, τό, a kind of tunny, Xenocr. ap. Orib. 2.58.139, Plin. HN 32.151; = tricodatum, Gloss.; also an object of value, used as a bribe (exact sense uncertain), UPZ 62.12 ( ii B. C., cf. Wilcken ad loc.).
of three tones: τρίτονον, τό, in Music, interval of three whole tones, Cleonid. Harm. 5, Bacch. Harm. 47.
ancestors, Berl.Sitzb. 1927.158 ( Cyrene).

divinities worshipped by γένη, ὅρος ἱεροῦ Τριτοπατρέων Ζακυαδῶν IG 2(2).2615, cf. 1358.32, 12.842 D7, 870: mythical ancestors of the human race acc. to Philoch. 2 (but Τριτοπάτρεις seems to be a mistake for Τριτοπάτορας).
great-grandfather, Arist. Fr. 415 (but perh. Ar.Byz.): v.l. τριπάτωρ.

children.label: II
children.definition: Τριτοπάτορες, οἱ, divinities worshipped at Athens, to whom prayers were offered ὑπὲρ γενέσεως παίδων (v. Τριτογενής II), Phanod. 4, cf. Clitodem. 19, etc.; wind-daemons acc. to Demon 2, cf. Orph. Fr. 318: sg., Τριτοπάτωρ Πυρρακιδῶν prob. the mythical ancestor of the P., Durrbach Choix dʼinscrr. de Délos No. 7 (v/iv B. C.). [The quantity of the ι is unknown.]

definition: τριτοπηλίς σκορόδων δέσμη, ἀπὸ τοῦ πεπιλῆσθαι καὶ συνεστράφθαι, Hsch. (v. τρόπαλις).
τρίτος [ῐ], Aeol. τέρτος (v. τέρτα) η, ον, ( τρεῖς)

children.definition: third, τοῖσι δʼ ἐπὶ τρίτος ἦλθε Od. 20.185, cf. 14.471; τρίτος αὐτός himself the third, i.e. with two others (v. αὐτός I.6) τ. ἡμίδραχμον two drachmae and a half, Din. Fr. 8.4; cf. ἡμιτάλαντον; τ. γενέσθαι to be third in a race, Isoc. 16.34, cf. Plu. Alc. 11:— the third freq. appears as completing the tale, e.g. the third and last libation was offered to Ζεὺς Σωτήρ, Διὸς σωτηρίου σπονδὴ τρίτου κρατῆρος S. Fr. 425, cf. A. Fr. 55; ἔγχει κἀπιβόα τρίτον παιῶνʼ, ὡς νόμος ἐστίν Pherecr. 131.5 (cf. τριτόσπονδος): metaph., Κράτος τε καὶ Δίκη σὺν τῷ τρίτῳ . . Ζηνί A. Ch. 244, cf. Eu. 759, Supp. 26 (anap.); τρίτην ἐπενδίδωμι (sc. πληγήν) the third and finishing stroke, Id. Ag. 1386; Ἐρινὺς . . αἷμα πίεται, τρίτην πόσιν, i. e. the blood of Clytemnestra and Aegisthus, the first being that of the children of Thyestes, the second that of Agamemnon, Id. Ch. 578, cf. 1066 (anap.).

data.quote: Ζεὺς Σωτήρ, Διὸς σωτηρίου σπονδὴ τρίτου κρατῆρος
ἔγχει κἀπιβόα τρίτον παιῶνʼ, ὡς νόμος ἐστίν
Κράτος τε καὶ Δίκη σὺν τῷ τρίτῳ . . Ζηνί

children.label: II
children.definition: τρίτη, with or without ἡμέρα, the day after tomorrow, ἐς τρίτην ἡμέραν Ar. Lys. 612; εἰς τρίτην Anaxandr. 4; τῇ τρίτῃ X. HG 3.1.17, etc.; τρίτῃ καὶ τετάρτῃ Id. An. 4.8.21, etc.; but ἐχθὲς καὶ τ. ἡμέραν yesterday and the day before, Id. Cyr. 6.3.11:— διὰ τρίτης two days later, Arist. Fr. 368; but, every other day, Hp. Fract. 48, Gal. 6.354.

ἡ τ. (sc. χορδή) the third string in the heptachord, = ἡ παραμέση, Arist. Pr. 920a16, Plu. Mus. 2.1137b:— ἡ τ. (sc. πληγή) the third blow, v. supr. 1:— ἡ τ. (sc. μερίς) the third part of a coin or weight, Hsch. s.v. ἕκτη, Phot. post Τριτοπάτορες; ἐγένετο ὁ μέδιμνος χρυσοῦ καὶ δύο τριτῶν IPE 12.32A63 ( Olbia, iii B. C.); third of a stater, Herod. 2.64.

data.quote: Τριτοπάτορες; ἐγένετο ὁ μέδιμνος χρυσοῦ καὶ δύο τριτῶν

children.label: III
children.definition: τρίτον as Adv., thirdly, S. Ant. 55, Fr. 380; a third time, E. Hel. 1417, Aristid. 2.182 J.; πρῶτον μὲν . . , δεύτερον δὲ . . , τ. δὲ . . Pl. R. 358c; τοῦτο τ. this third time, LXX Nu. 22.32, Ev.Jo. 21.14:—in Hom. always τὸ τρίτον, Il. 3.225, 6.186, al., cf. Hdt. 1.55, Ar. Ach. 997, Th. 6.5, etc.:—also ἐκ τρίτου in the third place, Pl. Ti. 54a (but = the third time, Ev.Matt. 26.44, Dsc. 5.32); ἐκ τρίτων E. Or. 1178, Pl. Grg. 500a:—regul. Adv. τρίτως in the third degree, Id. Ti. 56b.
τρίτον thrice, Syrian. in Metaph. 134.15, Gp. 2.39.7, al., Sch. Pi. O. 2.123; Elean ἐν τρίτον Schwyzer 412.4.

children.label: IV
children.definition: τὸ τ. μέρος Isoc. 12.177, etc.; τὸ τ. Luc. Tox. 46; τὸ τ. τοῦ ἀριθμοῦ Str. 7.7.4, cf. LXX Nu. 15.6; ἐπὶ τῷ τ. at the third signal, X. An. 2.2.4.

children.label: V
children.definition: τρίτα, τά,
ἱερά) a sacrifice offered the third day after the funeral, Ar. Lys. 613, Is. 2.37, Poll. 8.146.
τὰ τρίτα λέγειν τινί play the third part (like τριταγωνιστεῖν τινι), D. 19.246, cf. Men. 223.17.
πρῶτα δραμεῖν καὶ δεύτερα καὶ τ. win . . third place in the race, E. Epigr. 3 ( τρίτατα cj. Bgk.). (Cf. Skt. trtīyas, Lat. tertius, etc.)

definition: τριτόσπονδος, ον: —τ. παιῶνα (Hartung for αἰῶνα) paean

children.definition: accompanying the third libation (to Ζεὺς Σωτήρ), A. Ag. 246 (lyr.); cf. τρίτος I.
sown for the third time, τ. γονή the third generation, A. Pers. 818.
standing third (from the coryphaeus) in the chorus, Arist. Metaph. 1018b28, Poll. 4.106, Simp. in Ph. 1268.27:—fem. τρῐτο-στάτις, ιδος, Ar. Fr. 487.
three times the amount, Leg.Gort. 1.36, GDI 5000 i 18 (Gort.).

definition: τριττός, ή, όν, Att. for τρισσός.

children.definition: Epich. 187 (acc. to Eust., but he prob. wrote τρίκτοια like Sophr. infr.), Ister 34; acc. pl. τριττύας χρυσόκερως Porph. Abst. 2.60; also τρικτεύα or τρίκτευα, IG 2(2).1126.34 (Amphict. Delph., iv B. C.); τρίττοια βόαρχος χρυσόκερως ib. 12.76.37, 845.6, cf. Theognost. Can. 103; τρίττοα, IG 1(2).5.5 ( Eleusis, v B. C.); τρικτοι (sic cod. A Ath.) ἀλεξιφαρμάκων Sophr. 3 (perh. τρίκτοιʼ ἀλ. rather than τρικτὺς ἀλ. as Schweigh., Kaibel): Hsch. also cites τρίκτειρα ( = θυσία Ἐνυαλίῳ, θύεται δὲ πάντα τρία καὶ ἔνορχα).
to be head of a τριττύς III, Pl. R. 475a; so τρικτῠαρχέω, IG ΙΙ(2).287 B 96,97 ( Delos, iii B. C.), Inscr.Délos 442 B 19, 55, al. (ii B. C.).
chief of a τριττύς III, IG 2(2).641.31 (iii B. C.), Poll. 8.109; = tribunus, D.H. 2.7; of an officer in the army, Lib. Or. 25.58; τριττυάρχης, EM 768.13.

data.ref: D.H. 2.7; of an officer in the army,

definition: τριττύς, ύος, ἡ (written τριτύς in Tim. Lex., Hsch.), Att. acc. pl. τριττῦς Arist. Ath. 21.3, cf. Harp.:—

children.definition: the number three, Hsch., Phot.:— νικᾶν τριττύν win three victories, Philostr. Gym. 33.

children.label: II
children.definition: sacrifice of three animals, used specially on making solemn oaths,—boar, goat, and ram, Sch. Ar. Pl. 820; bull, boar, and ram, Call. Fr. 403; bull, goat, and boar, Ister 34; two sheep and an ox, Epich. 187 (v. τριττύα).

data.ref: Ar. Pl. 820; bull, boar, and ram,
Call. Fr. 403; bull, goat, and boar,
Ister 34; two sheep and an ox,

children.label: III
children.definition: a third of the φυλή, IG 1(2).190.7, 884, al., D. 14.23, Aeschin. 3.30, Arist. Ath. 21.3: in form τριπτύς, IG 12(5).594 ( Ceos, iv B. C.).
third part of the πρυτάνεις, Arist. Ath. 44.1.

children.label: II
children.definition: Τρῑτώ, οῦς, ἡ, = Τριτογένεια, AP 6.194.
to be tertiary (cf. δευτερῳδέομαι), Simp. in Ph. 499.35.
Triton, son of Poseidon and Amphitrite, Hes. Th. 931, Lyc. 887, Plb. 7.9.2:—later in pl. Τρίτωνες, Tritons, seagods with fishes’ or (sts.) with horses’ tails, Mosch. 2.123, Paus. 9.21.1, etc.

children.label: II
children.definition: A. Eu. 293, Hdt. 4.178, 191; ποταμὸς Τρίτων, = Νεῖλος, A.R. 4.269, cf. Lyc. 576, Plin. HN 5.53.

definition: Τριτωνιάς λίμνη, ἡ, the Libyan lake

children.definition: Tritonis, E. Ion 872 (anap.).
Tritonian, οῖδμα Orph. H. 24.6.
Tritonis, a lake in Libya famous in old Greek legends, Pi. P. 4.20, Hdt. 4.178; cf. Τριτογένεια.

children.label: II
children.definition: Τριτογένεια), A.R. 1.109.

children.label: III
children.definition: PPetr. 2p.54, prob. in 3p.113 (iii B. C.).
small figure of a Triton, on a sun-dial, Inscr.Délos 1417 A i140 (ii B. C.).
trinepos, Gloss.
with triple web, PGrenf. 2.111.38 (v/vi A. D.).
triple phalanx, i.e. army marching in three phalanxes, Plb. 6.40.11, Arr. Tact. 28.6, Ael. Tact. 36.6, etc.

definition: τριφάλεια, ἡ, f.l. for τρυφάλεια in Coluth. 30, where the best cod. has φαλαρειαν.
τριφάλης [ᾰ], ητος, ὁ, title of a Comedy of Ar., in which prob. Alcibiades was attacked. (Prob. from φάλης, φαλλός.)
τρίφαλλος, ὁ, ( φαλλός) title of Menippean Satire by Varro περὶ ἀρρενότητος, Non.p.191 L.

children.definition: triple, μουνομαχίη Hdt. 5.1.

children.label: II
children.definition: τρεῖς, Id. 1.95, 2.17, al.; cf. διφάσιος.

children.label: III
children.definition: Hsch.
thrice-told, triple, Nic. Th. 102.
a triple vowel-sound, Tz. H. 12.242: as Adj. τρίφθογγος, ον, having three voices, PMag.Par. 1.2820.
thrice-beloved, Ἄδωνις Theoc. 15.86.
bear thrice, esp. of fruit, Thphr. CP 2.9.13:— Pass., to be used in three forms, of words, e.g. μήν, μάν, μέν, Eust. 32.15.
bearing thrice, of fruit-trees, Thphr. paraphrased by Ath. 3.77e.
of threefold form, with three stems, of plants, Thphr. HP 2.6.9; of the psoas muscle, Gal. 2.308: generally, threefold, Orph. H. 52.5, Procl. in Prm. p.945S.

data.ref: Thphr. HP 2.6.9; of the psoas muscle,

children.definition: containing three watches, νύξ Sch. Il. 10.252.
committee representing three tribes, Berl.Sitzb. 1927.170 ( Cyrene).
οἶνος, ὁ, an Italian wine, Gal. 14.19; τριφολῖνος (v.l. -φαλ-) in Ath. 1.26e.

definition: τριφύλλιον, τό, Dim. of τρίφυλλον, Aret. CD 2.13.

children.definition: Dsc. Eup. 2.60 codd. ( -φύλλου Wellm.).
clover, Trifolium fragiferum, Hdt. 1.132, Pherecr. 109, PLips. 97 xxxiii 16, 24 (iv A. D.); τρίφυλλος, ἡ, Dsc. 2.147; cf. τρίσφυλλον.
treacle clover, Psoralea bituminosa, Id. 3.109.
Hsch.; also (in acc. -ον) = Ἀντιοχικὴ ἰσχάς, Str. 13.4.15.

children.label: II
children.definition: trefoil ornament, Inscr.Délos 1441 A i90 (ii B. C.); φύλλα τ. ib. 1442 A 36 (ii B. C.).
three-leaved, λωτός Dsc. 4.111; βοτάνη Hsch. s.v. βάλαρις.

children.label: II
children.definition: τρίφυλλα· πολύφυλλα, καὶ πόα δέ τις Μηδικὴ οὕτω καλουμένη, Id.
of three tribes, πόλις D.H. 4.14; τριφύλους ποιῆσαί τινας divide them into three tribes, Hdt. 4.161.
three-voiced, Hsch. s.v. τριφάσιοι.

in three parts or ways, διὰ τ. κοσμηθέντες Il. 2.655; τ. σφισὶν ἥνδανε βουλή Od. 8.506; c. gen., τ. νυκτὸς ἔην ‘twas in the third watch of the night, 12.312, 14.483; τ. σχίσαι τι Hdt. 4.67; διὰ γαῖαν τ. δασσάμενοι Pi. O. 7.75; τ. διῄρηται Arist. HA 503a27; cf. τριχθά; the common Prose form is τριχῆ (q. v.).

the threefold people, Δωριέες, so called from their three tribes ( Ὑλλῆς, Δυμᾶνες, Πάμφυλοι), Od. 19.177; πάντες δὲ τριχάϊκες καλέονται τρισσὴν οὕνεκα γαῖαν ἑκὰς πάτρης ἐδάσαντο Hes. Fr. 191. ( Apollon. ap. Sch. Od. l.c. compares κορυθάϊξ -ῑκος and explains it as ‘shaking the hair of their crestsʼ; others rendered it τρίλοφοι, and others ὀρχησταί: more prob. Hesiod is right as to the sense; the first part is τρίχα ( Adv.), the second not ἑκάς (as Hes. seems to suggest) but ϝῐκ- = Skt. viś- ‘village’, cogn. with ϝοῖκος; or ϝεικ-, another grade of the same root.)

data.quote: πάντες δὲ τριχάϊκες καλέονται τρισσὴν οὕνεκα γαῖαν ἑκὰς πάτρης ἐδάσαντο

thrice-jealous, Νέμεσις (with pun on θρίξ, λεπτός) AP 12.229 ( Strat.).
tax of three χαλκοῖ, PLille 16.2 ( iii B. C., abbrev.).

cloven in three, κῦμα τ., = τρικυμία, A. Th. 760 (lyr.).
plaited or woven of hair, ἀμπεχόναι Pherecr. 108.28.

divided in three places, πίναξ τ. ζώναις Ps.-Callisth. 1.4.
the song-thrush, Turdus musicus, Arist. HA 617a20.
capable of trisection, Anatol. ap. Theol.Ar. 35.
three-lipped, An.Ox. 2.291.
three-handed, Tz. H. 7.902.

Adv., common Prose form of τρίχα, τριχῇ δασάμενος τὴν πόλιν Hdt. 3.39 (though he also uses τρίχα, q. v.); τ. διείλοντο τὰς βασιλείας Isoc. 6.21, cf. Pl. Phdr. 253c, Str. 17.3.1; τ. διαστήσασθαι τῷ λόγῳ πόλιν, διανεῖμαι τὸ στράτευμα, Pl. R. 564c, Lg. 683d; τοὺς τοξότας τ. ἐποιήσαντο X. An. 4.8.15; νενεμημένων τῶν ἀγαθῶν τ. Arist. EN 1098b13.

children.label: II

threefold, Aesar. ap. Stob. 1.49.27, AP 5.243 ( Paul.Sil.), 259 ( Id.), 9.482.23 ( Agath.).
rope, PLond. 1.131*.2, al. (i A. D.).
one that is hairy, Poll. 4.148 sq.

a disease of the eyelids, when they are introverted, and the lashes irritate the eye (opp. ἐκτρόπιον), Gal. 19.437, Sever. ap. Aët. 7.68.

suffer from τριχίασις 1, Gal. 12.740.

definition: τρίχιον, τό, Dim. of θρίξ, Arist. Pr. 963b10, Plu. QConv. 2.727a (s. v.l.), M.Ant. 6.13.

eating hair: hence τριχόβρωτες, = σῆτες or θρῖπες, moths, Ar. Ach. 1111 ( τριχοβρῶτες Poll. 2.24; both accents admitted by Sch. Ar. l.c. (1110)).
hair-band, Hsch. s.v. ἄμπυξ.
like a hair, Hp. Nat.Hom. 14, Arist. HA 620b14; of the veins, capillary, Gal. 2.808; of nerves, ib. 355; ῥωγμή Sor. Fract. 2; στιγμαί, on reptiles, Aët. 13.23. Adv. -δῶς, πολιοῦσθαι Dsc. 4.96.

= foreg., Orib. Eup. 4.20, Gloss.; also τρῐχο-λάβον, τό, Hermes 38.283, Gloss.; dat. -λάβῳ Aët. 8.53.

thrice-detested, AP 9.168 ( Pall.).
fleecy, ὄϊς AP 9.150 (Antip.).

Archil. 196.
= sq., χύτρα Dsc. 2.76.12.
holding three χόες, Nicostr.Com. 11.

bristly, of pigs, Sch. Nic. Th. 98, Gloss.

growth of hair, Heliod. ap. Orib. 46.30.6, Gal. 12.433.

Aj. 1190 (lyr., v. ad fin.); Dor. Τρωΐα Pi. N. 2.14, 3.60, A. Ch. 363 (lyr.); contr. Τρῴα Pi. O. 2.81 (cj. Boeckh for Τροίας):—hence Τροίᾱθεν, Ion. -ηθεν, from Troy, Od. 3.257, etc.; ἀπὸ Τροίηθεν Il. 24.492; Dor. Τρωΐᾱθεν Pi. N. 7.41:— Τροίανδε, Ion. -ηνδε, to Troy, Il. 7.390, etc.; Dor. Τρῴανδε Pi. [ Zenod. and Aristarch. scanned Τροίη ( Troy) as disyll. everywhere in Hom., but Aristarch. scanned (and wrote) ( πόλιν) Τροΐην as trisyll. in Il. 1.129, Od. 11.510, understanding ‘a Trojan city (city of the Troad)ʼ, v. Sch. Il. l.c.; cf. Τρώϊος: Τροίη ( -ης -ῃ -ην) stands at the beginning of the line in the phrase Τροίῃ ἐν εὐρείῃ Il. 24.256, 494, Od. 1.62, 4.99, 5.307; in the other 82 occurrences the trisyll. form is admitted by the metre, but should perh. not be restored, as disyll. Τροίη ( -ης etc.) is almost inevitably so placed in a hexam.:—codd. Pi. (in contrast to codd. Hom.) have Τρωΐα N. 4.25, al., and Τροΐα ib. 2.14, al. (with either spelling the word may begin with ⏑⏑), cf. Eust. 65.22.]

Hom. uses both Act. and Med., but only in pres. and impf.; Ep. and Ion. τρομεοίατο for τρομέοιντο, Il. 10.492; Ion. part., ἤθη δεσποτῶν τρομευμένους Sol. 36.12.—Poet. word, used in trans. sense by A. Pr. 542 (lyr., Act.), Pers. 64 (anap., Med.); but never by S. or E.: aor. ἐτρόμησα only late, LXX 1 Ma. 2.24 (v.l. ἐτρόμασαν), POxy. 416.10 (iii A. D.).

trembling, quivering, τρομώδεις ἔθνῃσκον Str. 15.2.6; σάρξ Plu. QConv. 2.689c; of delirious persons, χεῖρες, γλῶσσαι, Hp. Acut. 42, Prorrh. 1.20; πυρετοί Id. Fract. 11. Adv. -δῶς Gal. 7.69, Steph. in Hp. 1.99D.

definition: τρόνα ἀγάλματα, ἢ ῥάμματα ἄνθινα, Hsch. (Cf. θρόνον I.) τρόνοι· στύππιοι, στήμων, ἁρπεδόνη, ἄτρακτος, Id.

children.definition: Adv. a game with the ἀστράγαλοι described by Poll. 9.103, τ. παίζειν Cratin. 170; ludit tropa nequiore talo (Brodaeus for rota or popa), Mart. 4.14.9.

an alternating wind, esp. one which blows back from sea to land, opp. ἀπογεία, Arist. Pr. 940b22, 945a6, Thphr. Vent. 31, 53; tropaei ( venti), Plin. HN 2.114; τ. is said to have meant ἡ ἐναντία πνοή in S. Fr. 1103 (where τριπαία, τρίπαια, τριπαῖα codd.).

children.label: II
children.definition: λήματος, φρενὸς τροπαία, a change in the spirit of oneʼs heart or mind, A. Th. 706, Ag. 219 (both lyr.); but τ. κακῶν a change from, release from . . , Id. Ch. 775.
amounting to 1 τροπαϊκόν per 100 denarii per month, τόκος IGRom. 4.1342 [TAM V,2 1345] ( Magn. Sip., ii A. D.).
a half-denarius, = 8 asses, Anon. ap. Hultsch Metrol. Script. ip.302.

definition: τρόπαιον, τό, old Att. τροπαῖον Hdn.Gr. 1.369:—

children.definition: trophy, i. e. a monument of the enemyʼs defeat (τροπή II), usu. made of wood ( D.S. 13.24), but sts. of bronze ( Plu. Alc. 29), or stone ( Paus. 1.33.2); τ. στῆσαι Th. 2.92, etc.: freq. with gen., στῆσαι τροπαῖα τῶν κακῶν E. Or. 713; τ. αὐτοῦ στήσομαι Id. Andr. 763; ὅταν τροπαῖα πολεμίων στήσῃ στρατός ib. 694; τ. ἂν στήσαιτο τῶν ταύτης τρόπων Ar. Pl. 453; τροπαῖα τῶν πολεμίων ἀποδεῖξαι And. 1.147; ἔστησαν τ. ὑπὲρ τῆς Ἑλλάδος τῶν βαρβάρων Lys. 2.25, cf. X. An. 7.6.36; also θήσειν τροπαῖα, θράσους θέσθαι τροπαῖον, A. Th. 277, Ar. Lys. 318; τροπαῖʼ ἱδρύεται E. Heracl. 786; τ. πῶς ἀναστήσεις Διί; Id. Ph. 572; τ. ἐγεῖραι Luc. Dem. Enc. 40; νίκης τ. S. Tr. 751; στῆσαι τ. τῆς τροπῆς, τῆς ἱππομαχίας, for, in memory of . . , Th. 2.92, 6.98; so τροπαῖʼ ἔστησε τῶν ἐμῶν χερῶν S. Tr. 1102; χορῶν . . νίκης ἔστησε τροπαῖα Ar. Eq. 521 (anap.); so στῆσαι τροπαῖα κατὰ or ἀπὸ τῶν πολεμίων, Lys. 18.3, Aeschin. 3.156, cf. Isoc. 5.148, D. 20.78.

data.quote: τ. ἂν στήσαιτο τῶν ταύτης τρόπων
ἔστησαν τ. ὑπὲρ τῆς Ἑλλάδος τῶν βαρβάρων

children.definition: of a turning or change (cf. τροπαία, ἡ).

children.label: II
children.definition: of or for defeat (τροπή ΙΙ), τροπαῖά τʼ ἐχθρῶν καὶ πόλει σωτήρια (sc. σφάγια) E. Heracl. 402; Ζεὺς Τ., as giver of victory, S. Ant. 143 (anap.), Tr. 303, E. Heracl. 867, IG 2(2).1028.27; hence στήσαιεν Ζηνὶ τροπαῖον ἕδος ib. 2.2717.
causing rout, appalling, Ἕκτορος ὄμμασι τροπαῖοι, i.e. terrible to the eyes of Hector, E. El. 469 (lyr.), cf. 1174.—Cf. τρόπαιον.

having or gaining trophies: Ζεὺς τ. the god to whom trophies are dedicated, Arist. Mu. 401a23, CIG 4340 f, g ( Pamphylia); = Lat. Jupiter Feretrius, D.H. 2.34, Plu. Par.min. 2.306c; as an epith. of Roman Emperors, OGI 723.2 ( Antinoopolis, iv A. D.), CIG 3992 ( Iconium), 4350 ( Pamphylia), SIG 906 B ( Magn. Mae., iv A. D., τροπε-), al.; Δᾶτις ὁ τ. Polem. Cyn. 41.

data.ref: Plu. Par.min. 2.306c; as an epith. of Roman Emperors,

children.definition: triumph, Ph. 2.34.
bearing of a trophy, Plu. Comp.Pel.Marc. 3.
bringing trophies, Κύπρι AP 5.293.24 ( Agath.); bearing a trophy or emblem of victory, Νίκη D.S. 18.26; Ζεὺς τ., = Lat. Jupiter Feretrius, Mon.Anc.Gr. 10.9; εἰκόνες Plu. Rom. 16.
Inscr.Délos 1439 Cb 1, 1443 A i 141 (ii B. C.).

children.label: II
children.definition: = Lat. triumphalis, πομπή D.H. 3.31, etc.; ἁψίς D.C. 49.15.

bundle, bunch, σκορόδων τ. a bunch of garlic, Ar. Ach. 813 (Megar.). ( Dor. for τρόπηλις, which is given with this accent by Hdn.Gr. 1.91; but in Ar. l.c. codd. RA Γ have τροπαλλίδος and Suid. τροφαλλίδος:—cf. τριοπηλίς and τριτοπηλίς.)

definition: τροπαλισμός μεταβολή, καὶ τὸ ἐκ συμβόλων ὑποδέχεσθαι, Hsch.
τροπαλόν τραχύ, Hsch. (i. e. τροχαλόν· ταχύ).
τροπάομαι, v.l. for τρωπ- in Il. 15.666, cf. Suid.

children.definition: turn, ἵπποι ἂψ ὄχεα τρόπεον Il. 18.224.
turn, turning:

children.label: I
children.definition: τροπαὶ ἠελίοιο:

children.label: a
children.definition: ὅθι τροπαὶ ἠελίοιο apparently denotes a point on the horizon, prob. the West or place where the sun sets (so Eust. 1787.20), Od. 15.404.

children.label: b
children.definition: the solstices, first in Hes., ἠελίοιο τροπῇς at the time of the (winter) solstice, Op. 479; μετὰ τροπὰς ἠελ. ib. 564, 663 (with Dor. acc. pl. in -ᾰς) ; πεδὰ τὰς τροπάς Alcm. 33.5:—later the two solstices were distinguished as τροπαὶ θεριναί and χειμεριναί, Hdt. 2.19, Th. 7.16, Pl. Lg. 767c, Arist. HA 542b4 sqq., Gal. 6.405, etc. (rarely in sg., τροπὴ θερινή Arist. Mete. 364b2, Gem. 1.13; τ. χειμερινή ib. 15); τροπαὶ νότιοι Arist. HA 542b11; τ. βόρειοι, νότιοι, Plu. Exil. 2.601a:—when τροπαί is used alone, it mostly refers to the winter solstice, but the sense is always determined by the context, v. Hes. ll. cc.; περὶ ἡλίου τροπάς (sc. χειμερινάς) Th. 8.39; εὐθὺς ἐκ τροπῶν Arist. HA 542b20:—sts. also of other heavenly bodies, Pl. Ti. 39d; περὶ Πλειάδος δύσιν καὶ τροπάς Arist. HA 542b23, etc.; ἄστρων ἐπιτολάς, δύσεις, τροπάς Alex. 30.5; τροπὰς τῶν ἐνδεδεμένων ἄστρων Arist. Cael. 296b4; τροπαὶ ἡλίου καὶ σελήνης Epicur. Ep. 2p.40U.:—sts. four in number (the two equinoxes and two solstices), S.E. M. 5.11, Gal. 17(1).22; so (on a sun-dial) θερινὴ τ., ἰσημερινὴ τ., χειμερινὴ τ., Ἀρχ. Δελτ. 12.236 ( Samos).

data.quote: θερινὴ τ., ἰσημερινὴ τ., χειμερινὴ τ.,

children.definition: turn, change, Arist. Pol. 1316a17; πλείους τραπόμενος τροπὰς τοῦ Εὐρίπου Aeschin. 3.90; τ. πρὸς τὸ βέλτιον turn for the better, Phld. Rh. 2.25S.; ὀξυτέρας τρεπόμενος τ. τοῦ χαμαιλέοντος Plu. Alc. 23; αἱ τοῦ κόλακος ὥσπερ πολύποδος τ. Id. Adul. 2.52f; αἱ τῶ αἵματος τ. καὶ ἀλλοιώσιες Ti.Locr. 102c; αἱ περὶ τὸν ἀέρα τ. changes in the air or weather, Plu. Frig. 2.946f; of wine, a turning sour, ib. Fac.lun. 939f (cf. τροπίας); going bad, of food, τ. καὶ διαφθορὰ τῶν παρακειμένων Gal. 19.208; of phonetic change in language, A.D. Adv. 210.4, Hdn.Gr. 2.932.

data.quote: αἱ τοῦ κόλακος ὥσπερ πολύποδος τ.
αἱ τῶ αἵματος τ. καὶ ἀλλοιώσιες

children.definition: τροπαὶ λέξεως a change of speech by figures or tropes ( τρόποι), Luc. Dem.Enc. 6, cf. Hermog. Inv. 4.10, al.
αἱ τροπαί, = αἱ τροπαῖαι, alternating winds, Arist. Pr. 940b16, 21, Thphr. CP 2.3.1, Vent. 26.

children.label: II
children.definition: the turning about of the enemy, putting to flight or routing him, τροπήν (or τροπάς) τινος ποιεῖν or ποιεῖσθαι put one to flight, Hdt. 1.30, Ar. Eq. 246 (troch.), Th. 2.19, 6.69, etc.; οἵαν ἂν τροπὴν Εὐρυσθέως θείμην ( θείην codd.) E. Heracl. 743; τροπὴ γινομένη Hdt. 7.167, cf. Th. 1.49, 50, etc.: poet., ἐν μάχης τροπῇ A. Ag. 1237; ἐν τροπῇ δορός in the rout caused by the spear, S. Aj. 1275, E. Rh. 82.

children.label: III
children.definition: Democr. for θέσις, position, Arist. Metaph. 985b17, 1042b14, cf. Plot. 4.5.2, 4.5.6.

children.label: IV
children.definition: a coin, Hsch.; cf. τροπαϊκόν.
press, Hippon. 57; cf. τραπέω.
the handle of an oar, an oar, Hsch.; cf. τράφηξ.
turned, i.e. sour, wine (cf. τρέπω II.3, τροπή I.2), Ar. Fr. 213; cf. ἐκτροπίας.
the keel, Pl. Lg. 803a; v.l. τροπίδια, cf. Poll. 1.85, Phot.
furnish with a keel, ναῦς ἱκανῶς τετροπισμένη Hp. Ep. 14.

of the solstice, ὁ τ. (sc. κύκλος) the tropic or solstice as marked on the sphere, Arist. Mete. 343a14 (with κύκλος, Jul. Or. 4.147c); τ. χειμερινός, θερινός, Porph. Antr. 21; ζῶναι Placit. 3.11.4; οἱ τ. (sc. κύκλοι) Arist. Mete. 345a6, 346a14, al., cf. Arat. 528, Plu. Def.orac. 2.429f; τὰ τ. ζῴδια the signs of the zodiac in which the solstices and the equinoxes are situated, S.E. M. 5.6; so τ. ζῷα Man. 2.382; and abs., τροπικά Id. 3.41, 6.359; but used of Cancer and Capricorn only, opp. ἰσημερινά (Aries and Libra), Ptol. Tetr. 31, etc.

data.ref: 6.359; but used of Cancer and Capricorn only, opp.

children.definition: of or at the solstice, αἱ τ. ἡμέραι, οἱ τ. μῆνες, Arist. HA 544a33, 558b14.

children.label: II
children.definition: tropical, figurative, τ. λέξις a figurative expression, D.H. Th. 23, etc.; τὸ ποιητικὸν καὶ τ. Phld. Rh. 1.157 S.; αἱ τ. tropes, Longin. 32.6. Adv. -κῶς Phld. Rh. 1.154 S., Ath. 3.76c.
τροπικόν = συνημμένον ἢ διεζευγμένον ἀξίωμα (v. συνάπτω A. III.3, διαζεύγνυμι 1), Stoic. 2.77, al., Arr. Epict. 1.29.40.

definition: τρόπις, ἡ, gen. τρόπεως Placit. 2.4.15, Hdn. Epim. 135; Ion. gen. τρόπιος Od. 19.278, Hdt. 2.96; τρόπιδος EM 811.21; dat. τρόπιδι A.R. 1.388; acc. τρόπιν Hippon. 50, Orph. A. 271: pl. τρόπεις, dat. τρόπισι D.C. 48.38: ( τρέπω):—

children.definition: shipʼs keel, Od. 5.130, 12.421, Hdt. l.c.; τ. νεός Od. 7.252, 19.278; πλοίου τ. Arist. Metaph. 1013a5; and poet. ship, S. Fr. 143; τρόπεις θέσθαι lay down keels for building ships, Plu. Demetr. 43; cf. τροπιδεῖον: metaph., λέγε νυν τὴν τ. τοῦ πράγματος Ar. V. 30.

data.quote: λέγε νυν τὴν τ. τοῦ πράγματος

children.definition: expound allegorically, Aristeas 150.
moralis intelligentia, Gloss.
reciter of select passages (?), MAMA 3.217, 452 ( Corycus).
supple cringing fellow—a word ridiculed by Luc. Pseudol. 24.
twisted leathern thong, with which the oar was fastened to the thole, τροποῖς ἐν δερματίνοισι Od. 4.782, 8.53; τροπὸν αὐτόν, ἐπαρτέα δεσμὸν ἐρετμοῦ Opp. H. 5.359; cf. τροπόω (B), τροπωτήρ.
turn, direction, way, διώρυχες παντοίους τρόπους ἔχουσαι Hdt. 2.108; διώρυχας τετραμμένας πάντα τ. Id. 1.189, cf. 199: but,

children.label: II
children.definition: way, manner, fashion, guise, τρόπῳ τῷ παρεόντι χρεώμενοι going on as we are, ib. 97; τ. ὑποδημάτων Κρητικός Hp. Art. 62; πᾶς τ. μορφῆς A. Eu. 192; τίς ὁ τ. τῆς ξυμφορᾶς; S. OT 99; ἀσκεῖν τὸν υἱὸν τὸν ἐπιχώριον τ. Ar. Pl. 47; ὁ αὐτός που τ. τέχνης ἰατρικῆς ὅσπερ καὶ ῥητορικῆς Pl. Phdr. 270b; tenor, of documents, PGen. 16.11 (iii A. D.), etc.: also in pl., κεχώρισται τοὺς τ. in its ways, in its kind, Hdt. 4.28; ψυχῆς τρποι Pl. R. 445c, etc.; οἱ περὶ τὴν ψυχὴν τ. Arist. HA 588a20:—in various adverbial usages:

data.quote: ἀσκεῖν τὸν υἱὸν τὸν ἐπιχώριον τ.
ὁ αὐτός που τ. τέχνης ἰατρικῆς ὅσπερ καὶ ῥητορικῆς

children.definition: τίνι τρόπῳ; how? A. Pers. 793, S. OT 10, E. Ba. 1294; τῷ τ.; S. El. 679, E. Hipp. 909, 1008; ποίῳ τ.; A. Pr. 763, etc.; τοιούτῳ τ., τ. τοιῷδε, Hdt. 1.94, 3.68; ἄλλῳ τ. Pl. Phdr. 232b, etc.; ἑνί γέ τῳ τ. in one way or other, Ar. Pl. 402, Pl. Men. 96d; παντὶ τ. by all means, A. Th. 301 (lyr.), Lys. 13.25; οὐδενὶ τ., μηδενὶ τ., in no wise, by no means, on no account, Hdt. 4.111, Th. 6.35, Pl. Cri. 49a, etc.; ἑκουσίῳ τ. willingly, E. Med. 751; τρόπῳ φρενός by way of intelligence, i.e. in lieu of the intelligence which is lacking to the child, A. Ch. 754 (s. v.l.): poet. in pl., τρόποισι ποίοις; S. OC 468; τρόποισιν οὐ τυραννικοῖς not after the fashion of . . , A. Ch. 479; ναυκλήρου τρόποις S. Ph. 128.

data.ref: A. Ch. 754 (s. v.l.): poet. in pl.,

children.definition: τίνα τρόπον; how? Ar. Nu. 170, Ra. 460; τ. τινά in a manner, E. Hipp. 1300, Pl. R. 432e; τοῦτον τὸν τ., τόνδε τὸν τ., Id. Smp. 199a, X. An. 1.1.9; ὃν τ. how, D.H. 3.8; as, LXX Ps. 41(42).1; τ. τὸν αὐτόν A. Ch. 274; πάντα τ. Ar. Nu. 700 (lyr.), etc.; μηδένα τ. X. Mem. 3.7.8; τὸν μέγαν τ., οὐ σμικρὸν τ., A. Th. 284, 465; τὸν Ἀργείων τ. Pi. I. 6(5).58; Σαμιακὸν τ. Cratin. 13; βάρβαρον τ. ( βρόμον ex Sch. Schütz) in barbarous guise or fashion, A. Th. 463; πίτυος τρόπον after the manner of a pine, Hdt. 6.37; ὄρνιθος τ. like a bird, Id. 2.57, cf. A. Ag. 49 (anap.), 390 (lyr.), etc.; later, ἐς ὄρνιθος τ. Luc. Halc. 1, cf. Bis Acc. 27: rarely in pl., πάντας τρόπους in all ways, Pl. Phd. 94d.

τὸν ἐγκώμιον ἀμφὶ τρόπον in way of praise, Pi. O. 10(11).77:— διʼ οὗ τρόπου Men. 539.6; διὰ τοιούτου τ. D.S. 1.66:— ἐς τὸν νῦν τ. Th. 1.6; εἰς τὸν αὐτὸν τ. μετασκευάσαι X. Cyr. 6.2.8; ἐς ὄρνιθος τ. (v. supr. 2):— ἐκ παντὸς τ. Id. An. 3.1.43, Isoc. 4.95, etc.; ἐξ ἑνός γέ του τ. Ar. Fr. 187, Th. 6.34; μηδὲ ἐξ ἑνὸς τ. Lys. 31.30; μηδʼ ἐξ ἑνὸς τ. Isoc. 5.3:— ἐν τῷ ἑαυτῶν τ. Th. 7.67, cf. 1.97, etc.; ἐν τρόπῳ βοσκήματος Pl. Lg. 807a: in pl., γυναικὸς ἐν τρόποις, ἐν τ. Ἰξίονος, A. Ag. 918, Eu. 441:— κατὰ τὸν αὐτὸν τ. X. Cyr. 8.2.5; κατὰ πάντα τ. Ar. Av. 451 (lyr.), X. An. 6.6.30, etc.; κατʼ οὐδένα τ. Plb. 4.84.8, etc.; κατʼ ἄλλον τ. Pl. Cra. 417b; κατὰ τὸν Ἑλληνικὸν τ. X. Cyr. 2.2.28: in pl., κατὰ πολλοὺς τ. ib. 8.1.46, etc.:— μετὰ ὁτουοῦν τ. in any manner whatever, Th. 8.27:— ἑνὶ σὺν τ. Pi. N. 7.14.
κατὰ τρόπον,

children.label: a
children.definition: according to custom, κατὰ τὸν τ. τῆς φύσεως Pl. Lg. 804b; opp. παρὰ τὸν τ. τὸν ἑαυτῶν Th. 5.63, cf. Antipho 3.2.1.

children.label: b
children.definition: fitly, duly, Epich. 283, Isoc. 2.6, Pl. Plt. 310c, etc.; οὐδαμῶς κατὰ τ. Id. Lg. 638c; opp. ἀπὸ τρόπου unreasonable, absurd, Id. Cra. 421d, Tht. 143c, etc.; so θαυμαστὸν οὐδὲν οὐδʼ ἀπὸ τοῦ ἀνθρωπείου τ. Th. 1.76.

data.quote: θαυμαστὸν οὐδὲν οὐδʼ ἀπὸ τοῦ ἀνθρωπείου τ.

children.definition: πρὸς τρόπου fitting, suitable, PCair.Zen. 309.5 (iii B. C.).

children.label: III
children.definition: a way of life, habit, custom, Pi. N. 1.29; μῶν ἡλιαστά; Answ. μἀλλὰ θατέρου τ. Ar. Av. 109; ἐγὼ δὲ τούτου τοῦ τ. πώς εἰμʼ ἀεί Id. Pl. 246, cf. 630.

data.quote: ἐγὼ δὲ τούτου τοῦ τ. πώς εἰμʼ ἀεί

children.definition: ways, habits, character, temper, ὀργὴν καὶ ῥυθμὸν καὶ τ. ὅστις ἂν ᾖ (v.l. ὅντινʼ ἔχει) Thgn. 964; τρόπου ἡσυχίου of a quiet temper, Hdt. 1.107, cf. 3.36; φιλανθρώπου τ. A. Pr. 11; γυναικὶ κόσμος ὁ τ., οὐ τὰ χρυσία Men. Mon. 92; οὐ τὸν τ., ἀλλὰ τὸν τόπον μόνον μετήλλαξεν Aeschin. 3.78; τρόπου προπέτεια, ἀναίδεια, D. 21.38, 45.71; ἀφιλάργυρος ὁ τ. Ep.Hebr. 13.5 :— οὐ τοὐμοῦ τ. Ar. V. 1002; σφόδρʼ ἐκ τοῦ σοῦ τ. quite of your sort, Id. Th. 93; ξυγγενεῖς τοὐμοῦ τ. ib. 574:— πρὸς τρόπου τινός agreeable to oneʼs temper, Pl. Phdr. 252d, cf. Lg. 655d; πρὸς τοῦ Κύρου τρόπου X. An. 1.2.11:—opp. ἀπὸ τρόπου Pl. Phdr. 278d, R. 470c:—after Adjs., διάφοροι ὄντες τὸν τ. Th. 8.96; σολοικότερος τῷ τ. X. Cyr. 8.3.21:—esp. in pl., Pi. P. 10.38, S. El. 397, 1051; σκληρός, ἀμνοὶ τοὺς τρόπους, Ar. Pax 350, 935; σφόδρα τοὺς τ. Βοιώτιος Eub. 39; πουλύπους ἐς τοὺς τ. Eup. 101; μεθάρμοσαι τ. νέους A. Pr. 311; τοὺς φιλάνορας τ. Id. Ag. 856; νέας βουλὰς νέοισιν ἐγκαταζεύξας τ. S. Aj. 736; τοῖς τρόποις ὑπηρετεῖν Ar. Ra. 1432; opp. νόμοι, Th. 2.39; ἤθη τε καὶ τ. Pl. Lg. 924d.

data.quote: γυναικὶ κόσμος ὁ τ., οὐ τὰ χρυσία
οὐ τὸν τ., ἀλλὰ τὸν τόπον μόνον μετήλλαξεν

children.label: IV
children.definition: mode, Λύδιος τ. Pi. O. 14.17; but more generally, style, νεοσίγαλος τ. ib. 3.4; ὁ ἀρχαῖος τ. Eup. 303; ᾠδῆς τρόπος, μουσικῆς τρόποι, Pl. R. 398c, 424c; διθυραμβικοὶ τ. (distd. fr. ἦθος) Phld. Mus. p.9K.; ὁ ἁρμονικὸς τῆς μουσικῆς τ. Aristid.Quint. 1.12, cf. 2.1; of art in general, πάντες τῆς εἰκαστικῆς τ. Phld. Po. 5.7.

children.label: V
children.definition: manner, style, ὁ τ. τῆς λέξεως Pl. R. 400d, cf. Isoc. 15.45: esp. in Rhet. in pl., tropes, Trypho Trop. tit., Cic. Brut. 17.69, Quint. Inst. 8.6.1.

data.ref: Isoc. 15.45: esp. in Rhet. in pl.,

children.label: VI
children.definition: mode or mood of a syllogism, Stoic. 3.269, cf. 1.108, 2.83: more generally, method of instruction or explanation, ὁ ἄνευ φθόγγων τ. Epicur. Ep. 1p.32U.; ὁ μοναχῇ τ. the method of the single cause, opp. ὁ πλεοναχὸς τ. the method of manifold causes, Id. Ep. 2p.41U.; mode of inference, ὁ κατὰ τὴν ὁμοιότητα τ., opp. ὁ κατʼ ἀνασκευὴν τ. τῆς σημειώσεως, Phld. Sign. 30, 31; αἰτιολογικὸς τ. Epicur. Nat. 143 G.

children.label: VII
children.definition: beam, Moschio ap. Ath. 5.208c (so in Mod.Gr., cf. Glotta 11.249).
bear with anotherʼs moods, Sch. Ar. Ra. 1479, Suid. s. vv. σκύμνος et οὐ χρή; τὸν τῦφόν μου Cic. Att. 13.29.1; v.l. for τροφο- in LXX De. 1.31, Act.Ap. 13.18.
make to turn, put to flight, LXX Jd. 4.23, 20.35 (v.l.), Wilcken Chr. 11 A40 (ii B. C.):—so in Med., LXX 2 Ki. 8.1, al., D.H. 2.50, Sammelb. 5829.2.

furnish the oar with its thong, in Med., ναυβάτης τʼ ἀνὴρ τροποῦτο κώπην σκαλμὸν ἀμφʼ εὐήρετμον fastened his oar by its thong round the thole, A. Pers. 376; τροπώσασθαι ναῦν Poll. 1.87:— Pass., of the oar, to be furnished with its thong, Ar. Ach. 553, Luc. Cat. 1.
Ar. Ach. 549, Th. 2.93:— φλεβὸς τ., v. φλέψ.
Gloss.; also cj. (as Boeot.) in Alex. 142.

definition: τρούεται ἰσχναίνεται, τήκεται, Hsch. (Prob. Lacon. for τρύεται.)

children.definition: ladle or cup, used as a liquid measure, Lat. trulla, BMus.Inscr. 980 ( Cyprus), Olymp.Hist.p.462 D., Gloss.; written τροῦλα in Hippiatr. 77:— Dim. τρούλλιον, τό, Lat. trulleum, Hero Spir. 1.8, Aët. 3.177, 16.136; written τρούλιον in BGU 814.10 (iii A. D.), Hippiatr. 74; cf. τρύλλιον.

definition: τροῦλλος, ὁ, a kind of vessel, ἐν τ. μεγάλῳ ὑελίνῳ περιπηλώσαντες Zos.Alch. p.164B.; οὐκ ἐῶντες καπνὸν διὰ τοῦ τ. ἀναδοθῆναι ibid.
τροῦροι δρόμοι, στάδιοι, Hsch. τρουφωνίδαι· εἶδος κροκωτοῦ, Id.
τροφάλιον [ᾰ], τό, Dim. of sq., Alex. 172.12.

children.definition: fresh cheese, Eup. 277, Antiph. 49 (troch.); τροφαλίδα τυροῦ Σικελικὴν κατεδήδοκεν a piece of Sicilian cheese, Ar. V. 838, cf. Herm.Hist. 2; whence the joke, καλεῖ . . τὴν . . Τυρὼ τροφαλίδα Com.Adesp. 393; τ. ὀβολιαῖαι Arist. HA 522a31.—The form τρυφαλίς is common in later writers, as Luc. Lex. 13, Hdn.Gr. 2.18 (rejected in favour of τροφαλίς Id. 1.91), Hsch.; τὰς δέκα στρυʼ φαλιδας (sic cod. A, ν superscr. A1) τοῦ γάλακτος LXX 1 Ki. 17.18; a form τροφαλλίς occurs in codd. of Eust. 1535.22 (in citation of Com.Adesp. l.c.); Hsch. also cites τραφαλλίς, τραφαλλος. (From τρέφω I acc. to Hdn.Gr. 1.91, but the spelling τρυφ-, which he mentions, remains, unexplained: oxyt. acc. to Hdn.Gr. ll. cc., so that the accus. τρόφαλιν in Erot. s.v. τεθραμμένον must be an error.)
service as wet-nurse, BGU 1058.14, 1106.35, al. (i B. C.).

pay for rearing and bringing up, wages of a nurse, θανὼν τ. πληρώσει χθονί A. Th. 477; [ πορσῦναι] E. El. 626; ἀποδοῦναι, ἐκτίνειν, Id. Ion 852, Pl. R. 520b; prov., κριὸς τὰ τ. (sc. ἀπέτεισεν) Men. 905; ἀνταποδοῦναι Lys. 6.49, cf. IG 5(2).345.7 (Orchom. Arc., ii/i B. C.), POxy. 37.10 (i A. D.); πράξασθαι D.S. 9.13.

children.label: II
children.definition: βίου τ. oneʼs living, food, S. OC 341; τ. ματρός motherʼs milk, E. Ion 1493 (lyr.).

children.label: III
children.definition: fodder, BGU 912.19 (i A. D.), PAmh. 2.143.5 (iv A. D.).

children.label: IV
children.definition: maintenance, board, paid in money or kind, PEleph. 3.2, al. (iii B. C.), PMich.Teb. 121v vii 7, al. (i A. D.), PRyl. 153.4 (ii A. D.); paid to a wet-nurse, BGU 1106.38, 47 (i B. C.), PGrenf. 2.75.5 (iv A. D.).
Suid.

one who brings up, foster-father, S. Ph. 344, E. El. 16, Ph. 45, Theophil. 1; tutor, βασιλέως OGI 148.2 ( Cyprus, ii B. C.), 256.1 ( Delos, ii B. C.), cf. Sammelb. 1568.1 (ii B. C.), Gal. 14.664, M.Ant. 5.31; of a woman, nurse, A. Ch. 760 ( στροφεύς codd.).
S. Aj. 863, Ajax addresses the plains and fountains of Troy, χαίρετʼ ὦ τροφῆς ἐμοί ye who have fed me, or with whom I have lived; so τροφέας παρέδωκε τὴν γῆν καὶ τὴν θάλασσαν Antipho 4.1.2.

data.ref: S. Aj. 863, Ajax addresses the plains and fountains of Troy,

data.quote: τροφέας παρέδωκε τὴν γῆν καὶ τὴν θάλασσαν

children.definition: rearer, breeder, ἵππων Pl. Lg. 735b; ἅρματος τ. one who keeps a chariot, ib. 834b; πάσης κακίας one who fosters all wickedness, Id. R. 580a.
one who gives free meals to the people, IGRom. 3.89 ( Amastris, i A. D.), 4.1680 (Pergam.).
personal attendant, slave, Aristid. Or. 49(25).3, 15, 20, 50(26).103.

serve as a wet-nurse, suckle, LXX Ex. 2.7, Ph. 2.83, BGU 297.16 (i A. D.), etc.: c. gen., τ. δουλικοῦ ἐγγόνου PSI 10.1131.26 (i A. D.), cf. 1065.11 (ii A. D.):—so τροφ-έω, BGU 1111.10 ( i B. C., Pass.), 859.4 (iv A. D.); τροφέοντο ( τροφόεντο cod., corr. Porson) was read by Aristarch. in Od. 3.290, and τροφέοντα is v.l. in Il. 15.621.

nourishment, food, Hdt. 3.48, S. Ph. 32, 953, Th. 1.5, Ev.Matt. 3.4, Gal. 6.35, Iamb. VP 3.16, etc.; ἡ καθʼ ἡμέραν ἀναγκαία τ. Th. 1.2; the means of maintaining an army, provisions, forage, τροφὴν παρέχειν Id. 8.57, cf. 6.93: pl., OGI 56.70 ( Canopus, iii B. C.), etc.

βίου τροφαί way of life, livelihood, living, S. OC 338, 446; τροφή alone, δουλίαν ἕξειν τροφήν Id. Aj. 499, cf. OC 362; φεῦ τῆς ἀνύμφου . . σῆς τροφῆς Id. El. 1183; τὰς ἐκ γῆς τ. ηὕρετο Pl. Prt. 322a: then, simply, mode of life, δίκην τίνουσαι τῆς προτέρας τ. Id. Phd. 81d, cf. 84b; βώμιοι τ. E. Ion 52.
that which provides or procures sustenance, as the bow of Philoctetes, χερὶ πάλλων τὰν ἐμὰν μελέου τροφάν S. Ph. 1126 (lyr.).

data.quote: χερὶ πάλλων τὰν ἐμὰν μελέου τροφάν

children.definition: a meal, τροφαῖς τέτταρσιν ἐχρῶντο Philem.Gloss. ap. Ath. 1.11d.

children.label: II
children.definition: nurture, rearing, παιδία . . τρέφειν . . τροφήν τινα τοιήνδε Hdt. 2.2, cf. 3; χάριν τροφᾶς ἀμείβων v.l. in A. Ag. 729 (lyr.); νέας τροφῆς στερηθείς S. Aj. 511; μητρὸς τ. E. Ion 1377: freq. in pl., ἐν τροφαῖσιν while in the nursery, opp. ἐφηβήσας, A. Th. 665; ἠνυτόμαν τροφαῖς Id. Ag. 1159 (lyr.); ὦ δυσάθλιαι τ. S. OC 330; αἱ ἐμαὶ τ. E. Tr. 1187; τ. δημόσιαι Arist. Rh. 1361a36; ἐκτίνων τροφάς, much like τροφεῖα, A. Th. 548; οἷς ὀδύνας ἀντὶ τροφῶν ἔλιπον IG 12(5).973 ( Tenos).
education, E. Hec. 599 (pl.); τ. τε καὶ παιδεία Pl. Alc. 1.122b, cf. Arist. EN 1179b34, 1180a26, al.
rearing or keeping of animals, Hdt. 2.65; τροφαῖς ἵππων Pi. O. 4.16.

children.label: III
children.definition: θρέμμα, brood, νέα τ. a new generation, S. OT 1, cf. A. Th. 786 (lyr.); of animals, ἀρνῶν τροφαί, i.e. young lambs, E. Cyc. 189.

children.label: IV
children.definition: place in which animals are reared, ἰβίων τροφαί PTeb. 5.70, cf. 62.19, al. (ii B. C.), PPetr. 3p.221 (iii B. C.), etc.

definition: τρόφημα, ατος, τό, f.l. for ῥυφ-, Hp. Fist. 7; for ῥοφ-, Cael.Aur. TP 4.8 (both pl.).

children.definition: concerning maintenance, CPR 109.11 (iii A. D.).
Erot. s.v. τροφιωδέων.
brought up in the house, stall-fed, τ. ἵπποι, opp. φορβάδες, Arist. HA 604a29; βοῦς τροφίας (acc. pl.) IG 2(2).1028.16, cf. Plu. Aem. 33; κῶθον τροφίην ( Ion. form) Numen. ap. Ath. 7.304e.
nursing, tending, ἡ -κή (sc. τέχνη) Poll. 7.209; τὰ τ. ὄργανα the alimentary organs, Gal. 9.392.
reared at home: αἱ τ. the daughters of the house, Ph. 2.443 (v.l. for τροφίμαις).

definition: τρόφιμος, ον, also ος, η, ον, v. infr.:—

children.definition: nourishing, nutritious, γάλα -ώτατον Arist. HA 523a11, cf. Pr. 927a22 ( Comp.), Phld. Sign. 27, Sor. 1.94, al., Gal. 6.382; opp. ἄτροφος, Thphr. CP 6.4.5: c. gen., γᾶ τρόφιμε τῶν ἐμῶν τέκνων E. Tr. 1302 (lyr.), cf. Ion 235 (lyr.); also ὕδωρ τὸ περὶ κηπείας τ. Pl. Lg. 845d; τ. κλυστῆρες nutritive enemata, Lycus ap. Orib. 8.34tit.

children.label: II
children.definition: Subst. τρόφιμος, ὁ, a slaveʼs young master, ὁ τ. σου Men. Epit.Fr. 1, cf. Epit. 160, Pk. 74, al., Com.Adesp. 24.20, 25.41 D.; rendered erilis filius by Ter. Andr. 602, Eun. 289, Phorm. 39, v. Donat. ad locc.: metaph., ἡ βουλὴ τὸν ἑαυτῆς τ. καὶ εὐεργέτην SIG 879.10 ( Erythrae, iii A. D.): ἡ τροφίμη the mistress, Poll. 3.73.

data.quote: ἡ βουλὴ τὸν ἑαυτῆς τ. καὶ εὐεργέτην

children.definition: τρόφιμον, τό, maintenance, sustenance, BGU 297.21 (i A. D.); τ. δουλικόν PMich.Teb. 121vi18, al. (i A. D.): esp. food-supply of Alexandria, Just. Edict. 13.26, PKlein.Form. 328.4 ( vi A. D., cf. Arch.Pap. 5.294): τροφίμη σύνταξις contract for board, AP 9.175 ( Pall.).

children.label: III
children.definition: Pass., nursling, foster-child, παῖς τ. τίνος; E. Ion 684 (lyr.), cf. Archipp. 23, Pl. Plt. 272b; ὁ τ., freq. in Inscrr., IG 2(2).3969,3.3396, etc., and Pap., POxy. 1491.10 (iv A. D.), etc.; τ. ἀδελφός PCair.Preis. 42.6 (iii/iv A. D.); fem. τροφίμη POxy. 903.6 (iv A. D.): οἱ τ. our nurslings, pupils, Pl. R. 520d, cf. Lg. 804a; τ. τῆς ἀρετῆς Luc. Bis Acc. 6, cf. AP 10.52 ( Pall.) :—at Sparta, οἱ τ. were young persons too poor to pay their quota to the φιλίτια, and brought up as companions of the richer class, who paid for them, X. HG 5.3.9 :— also τ. κύνες dogs kept in the house, Ael. NA 11.13, 16.31.
healthy, strong, well-nourished, Hp. Aër. 20 ( Comp.); of plants, flourishing, luxuriant, Thphr. CP 1.15.4 ( Comp.).
τ. κύημα viable, capable of life, opp. ἀνεμιαῖον, Poll. 2.6.
nutritiousness, Eust. 742.24.
aliment, maintenance, Sammelb. 5349 (ii A. D.).
diet, Sor. ap. Gal. 12.415: as Adj., ἐδάφη τ. pastures for the Hathor-cow, prob. in BGU 1216.113 (ii B. C.).

children.label: II
children.definition: circular pad to prevent sores, Gal. 18(2).457.

definition: τρόφις, ὁ, ἡ, τρόφι, τό, gen. ιος, ( τρέφω)

children.definition: well-fed, stout, large, τ. κῦμα κυλίνδεται a huge, swollen wave, Il. 11.307 (cf. τροφόεις); of men, ἐπεὰν γένωνται τρόφιες [οἱ παῖδες] when the children grow big, Hdt. 4.9.

children.label: II
children.definition: nursling, Lyc. 264; τρόφις Ἐννοσιγαίου nursling of the earth-shaker, epith. of the dolphin, Opp. H. 2.634 (v.l. τρόχις).

providing for aliment, PTeb. 51.8, 776.8 (both ii B. C.), PMich.Teb. 121vi6, al. (i A. D.); γυνὴ τ. either a wet-nurse (so POxy. 37.9 (i A. D.)), or a wife married according to a συγγραφὴ τ., PGiss. 37 ii 13, cf. 36.13 (ii B. C.).
τ. γῆ dub. sens. in CPR 244.13 (iii A. D.).

containing coagulated matter, οὖρα Hp. Epid. 7.120; ἐκ τροφιώδεος . . ὑποπέλιον Id. Coac. 567; and so prob. ἐκ τροφιωδέων should be restored for ἐκ στροφωδέων in Id. Prorrh. 1.156 :—cf. Gal. ad loc. (16.819K.): a different expl. is given by Erot., τροφιωδέων· σποδιωδῶν, τροφιὰ γὰρ ἡ σποδιὰ λέγεται; cf. ἐκ τροφωλέων σποδοειδῶν, Hsch. Cf. τροφώδης II.
well-fed, stout, large, big, κύματά τε τροφόεντα Il. 15.621, Od. 3.290 (v. τροφέω).
rearing, bringing up, ὀρνίθων Man. 4.244.

feeder, rearer, Hom. only in Od. and always fem. of a nurse, φίλη τ. Εὐρύκλεια 2.361, al., cf. Hdt. 2.156, 6.61, LXX Ge. 35.8, PCair.Zen. 292.157 (iii B. C.), Glotta 16.274 ( Egypt), Sor. 1.105, al., Gal. 6.36, etc.; ἡ τ. βασιλέως Sammelb. 4980 (i B. C.); of a mother, S. Aj. 849.—The masc. was usu. τροφεύς (q. v.); but τροφός as masc. occurs in E. HF 45, El. 409, Pl. Plt. 268a, 268c.

Συράκοσαι, ἀνδρῶν ἵππων τε δαιμόνιαι τροφοί Pi. P. 2.2; Γῇ τε μητρί, φιλτάτῃ τροφῷ A. Th. 16; αἵματʼ ἐκποθένθʼ ὑπὸ χθονὸς τροφοῦ Id. Ch. 66 (lyr.), cf. S. OT 1092 (lyr.), OC 760; μήτηρ ἁπάντων γαῖα καὶ κοινὴ τ. Men. Mon. 617; νὺξ ἄστρων τ. E. El. 54; τὴν γεωργίαν τῶν ἄλλων τεχνῶν μητέρα καὶ τ. X. Oec. 5.17, cf. Pl. Plt. 267d; of Miletus, τ. τοῦ . . Ἀπόλλωνος SIG 906A5 (iv A. D.).

data.quote: Συράκοσαι, ἀνδρῶν ἵππων τε δαιμόνιαι τροφοί
μήτηρ ἁπάντων γαῖα καὶ κοινὴ τ.
τὴν γεωργίαν τῶν ἄλλων τεχνῶν μητέρα καὶ τ.

children.definition: τὸ τροφόν that which nourishes, Pl. Plt. 289a.
τροφός, ἡ, name of a plaster, Orib. Fr. 99.

children.label: II
children.definition: Pass., nursling, τροφοί· ἀντὶ τοῦ θρέμματα (Meineke τροφαί), Hsch.
Paul.Aeg. 7.17.82.
bring one nourishment, sustain, LXX De. 1.31, 2 Ma. 7.27, Act.Ap. 13.18 (v.l. ἐτροποφόρησε).
nourishing, Eust. 773.50, 1401.45.
nurse, IG 12(1).454 ( Rhodes), Ath.Mitt. 51.5 (ibid.), Annuario 2.128 (ibid.).
nutritious, Arist. Pr. 871b19, Xenocr. ap. Orib. 2.58.40, 50; τ. τῆς σαρκός Arist. Pr. 893a29.

children.label: II
children.definition: Hsch. explains σῦφαρ by τὸ ἐπὶ τοῦ γάλακτος τ.
h.Ap. 296; afterwards himself the possessor of a celebrated oracle, Pi. Fr. 2, Hdt. 1.46, 8.134; καταβαίνων ὥσπερ ἐς Τροφωνίου (sc. ἄντρον) Ar. Nu. 508 :— Ζεὺς τ. Str. 9.2.38.

data.ref: h.Ap. 296; afterwards himself the possessor of a celebrated oracle,

children.label: II
children.definition: Τροφώνεια, τά, his festival, IG 7.49.10 ( Megara, ii A. D.), 22.3169.18 ( Athens, iii A. D.); written Τροφώνια in IG 2(2).3147 (ii B. C.), Poll. 1.37 (v.l. -ωνίαι): both prob. contr. fr. Τροφωνίεια. (An older form Τρεφώνιος in Boeot. Inscrr., IG 7.3055 (Lebad.), 3080 (ibid.), 4136 (Ptoön, ii B. C.), al.)
shoemaker, IG 3.3463.
running, βαίνειν Epigr.Gr. 288 ( Cyprus), A.D. Adv. 198.4.
walking-shoes, Edict.Diocl. 9.12.

run quickly, Hdt. 9.66, X. An. 7.3.46, etc.; τ. στάδια πλείω Σωτάδου Philetaer. 3; ἵπποις τ., of a charioteer, E. Hel. 724; of a horse, Arist. HA 604b12; τ. ἐν τοῖς ὅπλοις Plb. 10.20.2; τὸν μακρὸν τ. δρόμον Inscr.Prien. 112.111 (i B. C.); τροχάσαι τὴν λαμπάδα run the torch-race, OGI 764.54 ( Pergam., ii B. C.); make a forced march, App. BC 3.88; Astrol., of the moon, τὰ μεγάλα, τὰ μείζονα, τὰ ἥττονα τ., Gal. 19.556,562; ἐπὶ τὰ μείζονα τ. ibid.—The Verb was rejected by the Atticists, AB 114.

data.ref: App. BC 3.88; Astrol., of the moon,

children.definition: trochaic, Anon.Rhythm. 3.13, Heph. 3.3, al., Hermog. Id. 1.3, 2.1, etc. Adv. -κῶς ibid., Eust. 11.36. (The form τροχαιικός is recommended by Phryn. 28.)
trochaic, Aristid.Quint. 1.17.
running, spinning, πανία ( spools) AP 6.288 ( Leon.).

children.label: II
children.definition: τροχαῖος (sc. πούς), ὁ, a trochee or foot consisting of a long and a short syllable (also called χορεῖος), Pl. R. 400b, etc.; used in quick time, Arist. Rh. 1408b36, cf. Po. 1452b24, and v. τροχερός :—hence,

data.ref: Pl. R. 400b, etc.; used in quick time,

children.definition: οἱ σαλπικταὶ τροχαῖόν τι συμβοήσαντες playing a brisk march, D.C. 56.22; τ. νόμος a tune in trochaic time, invented by Terpander, Plu. Mus. 2.1132d, cf. Poll. 4.65.
tribrach (⏑⏑⏑), Quint. Inst. 9.4.82.
τ. σημαντὸς ὁ ἐξ ὀκτασήμου θέσεως καὶ τετρασήμου ἄρσεως (⏘ ⏘ – –) Aristid.Quint. 1.16; τ. ἀπὸ ἰάμβου (⏑–|–⏑–⏑–⏑) ibid.

children.label: III
children.definition: τροχαῖα· μέσα ἐν κύβοις, ἢ ὁδός, ὡς Ῥίνθων ( Fr. 26), Hsch. (perh. τρόχια and τροχιά).
trochee and tribrach (_⏑|⏑⏑⏑), Tz. in An. Ox. 3.307.
trochaic metre, Eust. 1647.26.
globe or sphere, Arat. 530.
roll along, in Pass., δίσκος -ισθείς Pherecyd. 12J.
running, τροχαλὸν δὲ γέροντα τίθησιν makes him run quick, Hes. Op. 518 (but v. infr. II); Μοιράων τροχαλώτερε AP 7.681 ( Pall.); τ. ὄχοι swift-rolling, E. IA 146 (anap.). Adv. -λῶς Gloss.

children.label: II
children.definition: round, AP 5.34 ( Rufin.), Nic. Th. 589, etc.; and in Hes. l.c., Eust. and others interpret it by κυρτός, bowed, bent; cf. τρόχμαλος.
trochanter, i. e. either of two processes at the head of the thigh bone, Gal. UP 15.8, cf. Id. 2.309, 312, Epigr. ap. S.E. M. 1.316 sq.

children.label: II
children.definition: Hsch.

children.label: III
children.definition: LXX 4 Ma. 8.13 (v.l. -τήρια).
Hsch., cf. Edict.Diocl. in IG 2(2).1120: sg., = gallicula, Gloss.
course, running, App.Anth. 6.193 (pl.): also τροχ-ασμός, ὁ, Hippiatr. 42 (pl.), Hsch. s.v. ὑπὸ δρόμον.
one who works a water-wheel, PKlein.Form. 1197 (vi A. D.).
Att. θρεκτικός ( Moer. p.187 P.), ἡ τ. ἕξις or δύναμις Arr. Epict. 2.18.1.

definition: τροχάω, Ep. form of τροχάζω, Arat. 1105, APl. 16.275 ( Posidipp.), Anacreont. 29.6, etc.; of the stars,

children.definition: revolve, Arat. 227.
Nic. Th. 658.
running, tripping, τ. ῥυθμὸς τὰ τετράμετρα Arist. Rh. 1409a1; cf. τροχαῖος II.
= Lat. rotor, Dosith. p.432K.
course, Trag.Adesp. 261.
locomotion, metaph. of the mutability of human life, Hp. Ep. 17.
drive a chariot: metaph., drive hither and thither, τροχηλατεῖν τινα μανίαισι E. Or. 36; Κῆρες τροχηλατήσουσʼ ἐμμανῆ πλανώμενον Id. El. 1253.
charioteer, formed like ἱππηλάτης, S. OT 806, E. Ph. 39.
τ. ἵππος, = currilis equus, Gloss.
wheel-drawn, σκηναί A. Pers. 1001 (lyr.); δίφροι S. El. 49.
dragged by or at the wheels, σφαγαὶ Ἕκτορος τροχήλατοι E. Andr. 399.
ploughed with wheels, κελεύθου τρίοδος A. Fr. 173.
formed on the potterʼs wheel, λύχνος Ar. Ec. 1, cf. Xenarch. 1.9.
hurried along like a wheel or chariot, E. HF 122 (lyr.); τ. μανία whirling madness, Id. IT 82.
wheel-track, rut, Hsch., Phot., etc.

children.label: II
children.definition: the round of a wheel, AP 7.478 ( Leon.), 9.418 (Antip.), Nic. Th. 816.

children.label: III
children.definition: path, LXX Pr. 4.26 ( = Ep.Hebr. 12.13).

children.label: IV
children.definition: elastic strand in the τόνος of a torsion-engine, Ph. Bel. 54.41, prob. for τριχέα in Hero Bel. 108.3.
roto, rotor, Gloss.
worked by a wheel, σφήν (perh. = τροχαντήρ III) LXX 4 Ma. 11.10.
consisting of trochee and iambus, Sch. Heph. pp. 137,360C.
courier, messenger, Hsch.

children.label: II
children.definition: τ. χαλκός cast brass (less correct for χυτός), Poll. 7.105.
wheel-work, Bito 66.10.

definition: τροχίζω, fut. Att. -ιῶ AP (v. infr.): ( τροχός) :—

children.definition: break on the wheel, torture, D.S. 20.71, AP 5.180 ( Asclep.) :— Pass., Antipho 1.20, Arist. EN 1153b19; = ὑπὸ τροχοῦ κατατμηθῆναι ἢ καταθραυσθῆναι, Phryn. PS p.114B.

granulated, χαλκός PLeid.X. 82.

block-and-tackle equipment, pulley or system of pulleys, roller of a windlass, and the like, IG 1(2).313.112, 314.123, 374.142, 22.1666.91, 1672.205, al., 11(2).161 A 98 ( Delos, iii B. C.); the later spelling τροχιλία is found in codd. of Hp. Art. 43, Ar. Lys. 722 (where τροχιλείας is metrically prob.), Plb. 1.22.5, 8.4.5, Plu. Aud.poet. 2.18c, Eum. 11, Gal. UP 7.14; the word is variously corrupted in Archipp. 33; the form τροχιλέα occurs in Arist. Mech. 851b19, Ath.Mech. 14.8, Suid. (citing Socr. ap. D.L. 2.36, where τροχιλία); τροχειλέα prob. in PLond. 3.1177.216 (ii A. D.); τροχαλία, Arist. Mech. 853a36, b2; τροχηλιά (oxyt.), Thphr. HP 4.3.5, Gal. UP 7.14 (as v.l.); τροχελλέα, POxy. 502.35 (ii A. D.); τροχιλλέα, BGU 1116.24 (i B. C.), Gloss.; τροχαρέα, PLond. 1821.194: metaph., μετά τινος τροχιλίας with a certain ease or glibness, Ath. 13.587f (s. v.l.).

data.ref: Gal. UP 7.14; the word is variously corrupted in

children.definition: pulley-block, pulley, IG 42(1).102.49 ( Epid., iv B. C.); for the gen. pl. τροχιλιῶν (v.l. τροχίλων) in Pl. R. 397a, and τροχιλίων in Moschio ap. Ath. 5.208e, Hero Spir. 1.27 (v.l.), τροχιλείων shd. perh. be read.

definition: τροχιλίδιον, τό, Dim. of foreg., Hero Spir. 1.27 (fort. τροχιλείδιον).

children.definition: Egyptian plover, Charadrius melanocephalus (or perh. spur-winged plover, Hoplopterus spinosus), said to pick leeches from the crocodileʼs throat by Hdt. 2.68; or to pick the crocodileʼs teeth by Arist. HA 612a21; cf. Ar. Av. 79, Ach. 876, Pax 1004 (anap.), Clearch. 73, Ael. NA 3.11, 8.25, 12.15.

like a pulley, Orib. 25.16.3 (quoted from Gal. 2.769), Gal. 18(2).349 (ubi τραχηλώδης), UP 2.15.
heap of stones, Ar. Fr. 876 (s. v.l., cf. τρόχμαλος).
running, hastening, S. Fr. 240 (lyr.).

round, φθοΐς AP 6.258 (Adaeus).

PMasp. 139 ( p.53) (vi A. D.).

round like a wheel, circular, λίμνη, of the lake of Delos, Thgn. 7, Hdt. 2.170; of the lake of Gennesaret, J. BJ 3.10.7; πόλις τ., of Athens, Orac. ap. Hdt. 7.140; of leaves, arranged in a whorl, Dsc. 3.27. Adv. -δῶς in a whorl, ib. 103.

shaven or shorn all round, Choeril. 4 ( τροχοκουράδες ap. Eus., τροχοκούριδες (f.l.) ap. J. Ap. 1.22).

the drag or brake of a wheel, Herodes Atticus ap. Ath. 3.99c.

wheel, Il. 6.42, 23.394, etc.; γῆ ἐπημαξευμένη τροχοῖσιν S. Ant. 252; ἐν πτερόεντι τ . . . κυλινδόμενον, of Ixion, Pi. P. 2.22; τροχοὺς μιμεῖσθαι to imitate wheels, of one who bends back so as to form a wheel, X. Smp. 2.22, 7.3: metaph. of fortune, πότμος ἐν . . θεοῦ τροχῷ κυκλεῖται S. Fr. 871; also μανίας τροχῷ E. Pirith.Oxy. 2078 Fr. 1.14.
potterʼs wheel, Il. 18.600; τροχῷ ἐλαθεὶς [λύχνος] (cf. τροχήλατος) Ar. Ec. 4; τροχοῦ ῥύμαισι τευκτὸν . . κύτος Antiph. 52.2, cf. Pl. R. 420e.

large pill (cf. τροχίσκος 2), Sor. 1.65, POxy. 2144.25 (iii A. D.).
