children.label: II
children.definition: sharp fellow, sly knave, Ar. Nu. 448.

wine not yet fermented and racked off, must, Anacr. 41, Ar. Nu. 50, al.: hence, new, raw wine, Cratin. 250, PTeb. 555 (ii A. D.): prov., κατʼ ὀπώρην τρύξ must in autumn, i. e. a state of ferment, Cic. Att. 2.12.3.

children.label: II
children.definition: lees of wine, dregs, οἶνος ἀπὸ τρυγός Archil. 4; ἐπειδὴ καὶ τὸν οἶνον ἠξίους πίνειν, συνεκποτέʼ ἐστί σοι καὶ τὴν τ. Ar. Pl. 1085, cf. Pherecr. 249; συὸς τρύγα προσενεγκαμένης καροῦται . . τὰ γαλουχούμενα Sor. 1.88, cf. 2.41 (s. v. l.); = στέμφυλα, Gal. 6.576; κυλίκεσσι καὶ ἐς τρύγα χεῖλος ἐρείδων Theoc. 7.70; ἐν τῇ τ. τοῦ πίθου Luc. Tim. 19; of other liquors, τ. [τοῦ ἄσχυ] Hdt. 4.23; ἐλαίου Poll. 1.245; ὄξευς Nic. Th. 932; γῆ ὑπόστασις καὶ τ. τοῦ ὕδατος Metrod. ap. Placit. 3.9.5.

data.quote: ἐπειδὴ καὶ τὸν οἶνον ἠξίους πίνειν, συνεκποτέʼ ἐστί σοι καὶ τὴν τ.
συὸς τρύγα προσενεγκαμένης καροῦται . . τὰ γαλουχούμενα
κυλίκεσσι καὶ ἐς τρύγα χεῖλος ἐρείδων
γῆ ὑπόστασις καὶ τ. τοῦ ὕδατος

children.definition: dross, σιδηρήεσσα τρύξ Nic. Al. 51; χαλκοῦ Dsc. 5.103.
faecal matter in the stomach, Hp. Epid. 5.79; αἵματος Gal. 18(1).730.
ἠχὼ . . , φωνῆς τρύγα APl. 16.155 ( Euod.): metaph. also of an old man or woman, Ar. V. 1309, Pl. 1086.

children.label: III
children.definition: τρύγες στεμφυλίτιδες second wine pressed out of the husks, poor wine, Hp. Vict. 2.52; ἡ ἐκ [στεμφύλων] τρύξ Gp. 6.13.2; without any addition, Gal. 6.580; cf. τρυγηφάνιος.

children.label: IV
children.definition: τ. οἴνου κεκαυμένη, = φέκλη, salt of tartar, obtained from the matter deposited on the bottom and sides of wine-vats, Dsc. 5.114, Eup. 2.164, Gal. 12.490; τροχίσκοι τρυγὸς ᾗ ῥυπτόμεθα scouring balls of this substance, Thphr. HP 9.9.3.
distress, toil, labour, Call. ap. Et.Gen. ( = Powell Coll.Alex. p.96).
hole, Eust. 1069.19 (ubi τρύπα), Gloss.; ἡ τοῦ μυὸς τ. Hdn. Epim. 89; but τρύπη, ib. 136, AP 14.62; αἱ τῶν αὐλῶν τρῦπαι Hsch. s.v. παραπλασμός.
a fox that penetrates anywhere, sly knave, Com.Adesp. 1170.
Hdn.Gr. 2.924, Hsch.
thong for working a τρύπανον (cf. τρυπάω), Poll. 10.146.
bore through, Hsch. ( Pass.).
of trepanning, τέχνη Pall. in Hp.Fract. 12.275 C.
Dim. of τρύπανον, Archig. ap. Gal. 12.821, Phot. s.v. τέρετρον.
boring, piercing, Aq. Is. 54.12.
like an auger, κίνησις Sch. Ptol. Tetr. 19. Adv. -δῶς ibid.
borer, auger, rotated by a thong (cf. τρυπάω), Od. 9.385, cf. Pratin.Lyr. 1.14, E. Cyc. 461, Pl. Cra. 388a, Nicoch. 9, AP 6.205 ( Leon.); the boring-point of a siege-engine, Aen.Tact. 32.5.

children.label: II
children.definition: trepan, Hp. VC 18; τ. ὀξὺ καὶ εὐθύ the straight-pointed trepan, Gal. 19.129; τ. ἀβάπτιστον, another kind with a guard to prevent its piercing to the brain, Id. 10.447.

children.label: III
children.definition: fire-drill (v. πυρεῖον 1), ἀχάλκευτα τρύπανα S. Fr. 708, cf. Thphr. HP 5.9.7, Ign. 64.

children.label: IV
children.definition: τρύπανα, τά, metaph., fellows who will do nothing without driving, Crates ap. Stob. 3.4.50.
Call. Fr. 412.
handle of a borer, Poll. 7.113, 10.146.
piercing, συναίσθησις Paul.Aeg. 3.43.

bore, pierce through, ὡς ὅτε τις τρυπῷ (opt.) δόρυ νήϊον ἀνὴρ τρυπάνῳ, οἱ δέ τʼ ἔνερθεν ὑποσσείουσιν ἱμάντι (cf. τρυπανία) Od. 9.384, cf. Hp. VC 18, Pl. Cra. 387e; ἐτρύπησεν τῷ ποδὶ τὴν βελόνην (of a very thin man) AP 11.102 ( Ammian. or Nicarch.), 308 ( Lucill.); with double acc., πόνος με τὸν πόδα τ. is stabbing into, Luc. Ocyp. 169; cf. ἁλία (B) :— Pass., τετρυπήσθω τὸ τρῆμα let the hole be bored, Hp. Steril. 222; διʼ ὠτὸς . . τρυπωμένου through well-bored ear, i.e. open to hear, S. Fr. 858 (codd. Plu., but ῥυπωμένου is prob. cj.); τὰ ὦτα τετρυπημένος having oneʼs ears pierced for ear-rings, X. An. 3.1.31; ψῆφος τετρυπημένη the pebble of condemnation which had a hole in it, opp. πλήρης, Aeschin. 1.79, Arist. Ath. 68.2, 69.1; ἐτετρύπητο ἄλλη ἔξοδος Luc. Alex. 16.
Theoc. 5.42, APl. 16.243 ( Antist.).

that which is bored, a hole, Eup. 354; in the ψῆφος, Arist. Ath. 69.1; τ. νεώς, i. e. one of the holes through which the oars worked, Ar. Pax 1234; in the flute, Archyt. 1, Plu. E apud Delph. 2.389d; in a gate-fastening, the hole for the βάλανος, Aen. Tact. 18.3; ῥαφίδος (cf. τρυμαλιά) Ev.Matt. 19.24; μυρμήκων AP 11.78 ( Lucill.); sens. obsc., Ar. Ec. 624, Hermog. Id. 2.3, Procop. Arc. 9.

data.ref: Plu. E apud Delph. 2.389d; in a gate-fastening, the hole for the

definition: τρυπημάτιον, τό, Dim. of foreg., Hero Spir. 1.7, al.

children.definition: boring, Arist. EE 1242a18, Thphr. HP 5.3.3; τῶν αὐλῶν Aristox. Harm. p.37 M., cf. Apollod. Poliorc. 149.2.
one must bore, Paul.Aeg. 6.90.
pierced vessel, Ph. Bel. 90.28.
borer, Pl. Cra. 388d.
pierced, Arist. Ath. 69.1.

definition: τρυσάνωρ [ ᾱ], ορος, ὁ, ἡ, ( τρύω)

children.definition: of a weary man, αὐδά S. Ph. 209 (lyr.).
Ar. Nu. 421.

a mark branded on the jaw of a horse superannuated in the public service, Eup. 318, cf. Zen. 4.41: the metre of Eup. shows that τρυσίππειον, as written in Ael.Dion. Fr. 311, Poll. 7.186, EM 771.16, is incorrect.—The horse was τρύσιππος, ὁ, Theognost. Can. 24.
Hsch.
gurgling, Hp. Mul. 1.7, Gal. 7.79, al.; synonym of τρισμός, both denoting a thin sound, ib. 242; = γογγυσμός, Hsch.

definition: τρυσσόν νοσερόν, λεπτόν, ἀσθενές, Hsch.: written τρυσόν in Theognost. Can. 24.

children.definition: balance, pair of scales, Ar. V. 39, D. 5.12, Lyc. 270, Herod. 2.90, D.Chr. 22.5, Plu. Crass. 17, Luc. Hist.Conscr. 49, Am. 4 :— hence τρῡτᾰνεύω, weigh, Gloss.

helmet, Il. 3.372, 12.22, al.; τρίπτυχος 11.352; αὐλῶπις 13.530; ἵππουρις 19.382; λευκολόφους τ., as an exaggerated Ep. phrase, Ar. Ra. 1016. ( τρῠ- does not stand for τρι- ‘three’ as supposed by Hsch. (v. sq.); -φάλεια is perh. related to φάλος, ἀμφίφαλος, ἄ-φαλος.)

definition: τρυφάλη περικεφαλαία, τρεῖς ἔχουσα λαμπροὺς ἀστέρας, ἢ ἥλους, Hsch. τρυφαλίς, v. τροφαλίς.

children.definition: a wanton, debauchee, Hippod. ap. Stob. 4.1.95.

live softly, luxuriously, fare sumptuously,, ἐν ἀγκάλαις μητρὸς τρυφῆσαι, of a child, E. Ion 1376, cf. Ba. 969; τ. ἐν ταῖς ἐσθῆσι Isoc. 2.32; τ. καὶ μεγαλοπρεπῶς διαιτᾶσθαι X. Ath. 1.11; λευκὸς ἄνθρωπος, παχύς, ἀργός . . , εἰωθὼς τρυφᾶν Sosicr. 1, cf. Ep.Jac. 5.5, Gal. 6.416, etc.; παῖσον, τρύφησον, ζῆσον· ἀποθανεῖν σε δεῖ Epigr.Gr. 362.5 ( Cotiaeum, ii/iii A. D.).

data.quote: λευκὸς ἄνθρωπος, παχύς, ἀργός . . , εἰωθὼς τρυφᾶν
παῖσον, τρύφησον, ζῆσον· ἀποθανεῖν σε δεῖ

children.definition: part. τρυφῶν as Adj., effeminate, luxurious, Ar. Nu. 48, etc.; τ. καὶ ἀμελής Pl. Lg. 901a; τὸ τρυφῶν effeminacy, Ar. V. 1455 (lyr.); also of things, dainty, delicate, βασιλικὴ καὶ τρυφῶσα παιδεία Pl. Lg. 695d; ἀσπίδα . . τρυφῶσαν Aristopho 14, cf. Antiph. 52.10 (troch.); ἄρτοι τ. Alc.Com. 5.

children.label: II
children.definition: to be licentious, run riot, wax wanton, Ar. Lys. 405, etc.; to be extravagant, opp. γλίσχρως ζῆν, Arist. Pol. 1266b26.
revel in, ἐν τοῖς ἀγαθοῖς τινος LXX Si. 14.4; delight in, ἐν ἀγαθωσύνῃ σου ib. Ne. 9.25.

children.label: III
children.definition: give oneself airs, be dainty, fastidious, ἆρʼ οὐ τρυφῶμεν . . . , οἷσιν οὐκ ἀρκεῖ τάδε; E. Supp. 214; τ. δʼ ὁ δαίμων is fickle, ib. 552; ἐπειδή μοι δοκεῖς σὺ τρυφᾶν to hang back, Pl. Euthphr. 11e, cf. La. 179d, Alc. 1.114a; οἱ τρυφῶντες spoiled pets, Id. Men. 76b; ἐν ταῖς ἐκκλησίαις τ. καὶ κολακεύεσθαι, of the people, D. 8.34; οὐκ ἀνεκτὸν εἶναι . . αἰχμάλωτον οὖσαν τρυφᾶν Id. 19.197; τρυφῶσιν ἕτεροι πρὸς ἑτέρους, of philosophers, Alex. 221.14; followed by a modifying clause, νῦν δὲ τρυφᾷς διότι . . Pl. Prt. 327e; ἐν ταῖς . . ἑτέρων . . ἀτυχίαις τ. Euphro 12; later, τ. κατά τινος make sport of . . , Him. Ecl. 12.2.

data.quote: ἆρʼ οὐ τρυφῶμεν . . . , οἷσιν οὐκ ἀρκεῖ τάδε;
οὐκ ἀνεκτὸν εἶναι . . αἰχμάλωτον οὖσαν τρυφᾶν

data.ref: Alex. 221.14; followed by a modifying clause,

children.definition: to be fastidious, τρυφερανθείς with a coxcombʼs air, Ar. V. 688 (anap.).
with soft garments, of the Ionians, Antiph. 91 (anap.).
LXX Es. 15.6:—hence τρῠφέρ-ευμα, ατος, τό, in pl., gloss on βαυκίσματα, AB 225.
tenderness, γλώττης, etc., Sor. 1.10, al.; voluptuousness, Aq. Ge. 18.12.
living delicately, luxurious, Φαίακες Phld. Hom. p.23O., cf. AB 322, Procl. Par.Ptol. 232.

delicate, dainty, αὐχήν Batr. 66; πλόκαμος E. Ba. 150 (lyr.); χεῖρες, χρώς, σάρξ, AP 5.65 ( Rufin.), 150 ( Mel.), 12.136; of a soft material, BGU 1080.19 (iii A. D.); of almonds, Arist. Fr. 277; of fish, tender, soft-fleshed, Xenocr. ap. Orib. 2.58.5 ( Comp.), Sor. 2.15 ( Comp.); of an infant, Id. 1.82: τὸ τ. dainty softness, Ar. Ec. 901 (lyr.); Θεσσαλικὸς δὲ θρόνος, γυίων -ωτάτη ἕδρα Critias 2; ὀθόνια Sor. 1.49; τελαμῶνες ib. 83; φύλλα -ώτερα Dsc. 2.161:— τρυφερόν, τό, name of a medicine, Gal. 12.757, cf. 844.

children.label: II
children.definition: effeminate, luxurious, voluptuous, Ar. V. 551 ( Comp.), etc.; ἡ τ. Ἰωνία Call.Com. 5 (anap.); ἡ τ. Λέσβος Antiph. 174.5 (lyr.); τ. βίῳ σύνεστιν Men. Kith.Fr. 1.9; τ. τρόποι Pl.Com. 178: τὸ τ. effeminacy, ἐς τὸ -ώτερον μετέστησαν Th. 1.6. Adv., ἀκολάστως καὶ -ρῶς ζην Arist. Pol. 1269b23: neut. as Adv., τρυφερόν τι διασαλακώνισον voluptuously, Ar. V. 1169; τ. καλέειν call softly, Theoc. 20.7, cf. 21.18: Comp. -ώτερον more wantonly, D.C. 60.31.
with soft, tender flesh or body, Xenocr. ap. Orib. 2.58.33.
of delicate warp or texture, Sch. Lyc. 863.
luxury, Arist. EE 1221a9, LXX De. 28.56, Ath. 12.544f.
with weak eyes, Aët. 7.108.
of tender skin or hue, Dsc. 1.69, Orib. Fr. 118.
delicately, Phot. s.v. νοσακερῶς.

softness, delicacy, daintiness, E. Fr. 892.4, Pl. Lg. 900e, etc.; στολίδος κροκόεσσαν . . τρυφάν (sic leg. pro στολίδα . . τρυφᾶς) E. Ph. 1491 (lyr.): pl., luxuries, daintinesses, τ. Τρωϊκαί Id. Or. 1113; τρυφὰς τοιάσδε [τρυφᾶν] Id. Ba. 970; αἱ ἄγαν τ. Id. Fr. 54.2; εἰς πλούτους ἀποβλέψαι καὶ τ. Pl. Alc. 1.122c, cf. Lg. 637e.

children.label: II
children.definition: luxuriousness, wantonness, τῶν γυναικῶν ἡ τ. Ar. Lys. 387; τ. καὶ ἀκολασία, τ. καὶ μαλθακία, Pl. Grg. 492c, R. 590b; ἡ ἐν ἡμέρᾳ τ. 2 Ep.Pet. 2.13; ὑπερτεταμένη τ. Sor. 2.54: personified, Τρυφῆς πρόσωπον Ar. Ec. 973 (lyr.), cf. Alex. 230.3.

children.label: III
children.definition: daintiness, fastidiousness, ὑπὸ τρυφῆς Ar. Pl. 818; ὕβρις ταῦτʼ ἐστὶ καὶ πολλὴ τ. Id. Ra. 21, cf. Pl. Grg. 525a, Arist. Pol. 1295b17.

data.quote: ὕβρις ταῦτʼ ἐστὶ καὶ πολλὴ τ.

children.definition: τρυφερός, σάρκες AP 7.48, cf. Rhetor. in Cat.Cod.Astr. 8(4).168, Pall. in Hp. 2.19D. Adv. -λῶς Jul. Or. 6.181d, Suid. s.v. Συβαριτικαῖς.

the object in which one takes pride or pleasure, λέκτρων τ. E. IA 1050 (lyr.); of some kind of garment, Ar. Fr. 320.7, Polyzel. 11, IG 2(2).1518.69, 1524.199: in pl., generally, luxuries, Alciphr. 1.12, al.
Vett.Val. 10.10.
voluptuary, D.S. 8.18, Ptol. Tetr. 162, Ath. 1.7a, Heph.Astr. 1.1: also τρῠφ-ητίας, ου, ὁ, Hdn. Epim. 137.
voluptuous, Eust. 1910.39.
a soft, costly womanʼs garment, Ar. Fr. 320.6.

that which is broken off, morsel, lump, Od. 4.508; ἄρτου AP 6.105 ( Apollonid.), Anon.Hist. Oxy. 1798 Fr. 44iv5 ( FGrH 148 p. 817 J.): pl., Hdt. 4.181, Pherecr. 108.5; κύλικος τρύφος a pot sherd, Choeril. 9; τ. τῆς Κῶ Str. 10.5.16.
ragged, tattered, worn out, τρυχηρὰ περὶ τρυχηρὸν . . χρόα λακίσματα E. Tr. 496.

children.label: II
children.definition: wearing, tormenting, grievous, τρυχηρᾷ καὶ πολυμερίμνῳ βασάνῳ περιπεσόντες Vett.Val. 109.1.
of rags, ragged, J. AJ 5.1.16, Gal. Thras. 18, Alciphr. 1.36.
Dim. of τρῦχος, tatter, shred, Hp. Art. 47, 78, Aret. CA 1.2 (cj.), 2.2.

Nic. Th. 878 cod. Π, cf. Gal. 12.145; also τρύχνος, ἡ, Phot., EM 771.31; used as a symbol of sweetness, μουσικώτερος τρύχνου Com.Adesp. 605; ἁ φωνὰ δὲ τρύχνος Theoc. 10.37 (v.l. τρύχνα, also v.l. in Sch. in lemmate).

definition: τρυχνόω, f.l. for τρυχόω (q.v.) in Gal. 19.147.

children.definition: worn out, tattered garment, τρύχει καλυφθεὶς Θεσσαλῆς ἁπληγίδος S. Fr. 777; τρύχει πέπλων E. El. 501, cf. Thphr. HP 3.8.6: pl., rags, tatters, E. El. 185 (lyr.), Ph. 325 (lyr.), Ar. Ach. 418.

children.label: II
children.definition: rent, διʼ ἱματίων . . οἷον τ. ἐποίησεν Arist. Mete. 371a28.

wear out, emaciate, τὸ πᾶν σῶμα Gal. 6.488; τὴν Ἑλλάδα Hdn. 3.2.8; τρυχνοῦν (fort. τρυχοῦν), = καταπονεῖν, ἰσχναίνειν, Hp. ap. Gal. 19.147:— Pass., οἶκος τρυχοῦται Mimn. 2.12; mostly in pf. part. τετρυχωμένος, Th. 4.60, Hp. Mul. 1.61, Pl. Lg. 807b (v.l.), etc.; τῷ πολέμῳ κατὰ πάντα τετρ. Th. 7.28; ὑπὸ τῶν πολέμων Plb. 1.11.2; παλαιὸν καὶ τετρ. δίκτυον Alciphr. 1.14; also τρυχωθῆναι τὸ σῶμα, viz. by disease, Hp. Mul. 1.5.

definition: τρύχω [ῡ], Od. 1.248, etc.: Ion. impf. τρύχεσκεν A.R. 2.473: fut. τρύξω Od. 17.387:— Pass., pres. and impf., v. infr.: the pf. is supplied by τρύω and τρυχόω: cf. κατατρύχω:—

children.definition: wear out, waste, consume, τρύχουσι δὲ οἶκον Od. 1.248, 16.125; οἵ τε [κηφῆνες] μελισσάων κάματον τ. Hes. Op. 305; πτωχὸν οὐκ ἄν τις καλέοι τρύξοντα ἓ αὐτόν no one would invite a beggar to eat him out of house and home, Od. 17.387; τρύχω βίον ἐν κακότητι Thgn. 913; τρύχει τὰ νουσήματα, i.e. get the better of, cure, the disease, Hp. Morb.Sacr. 18; τρύχουσιν ἔρωτες, τρύχει πόθος, AP 12.88, 143; γᾶ φθίνουσα τρύχει ψυχάν distresses, afflicts, S. OT 666 (lyr.); τρύχουσα σαυτήν E. Hel. 1286; τ. στρατείαις τὴν πόλιν X. HG 5.2.4:— Pass., to be worn out, τρυχόμενος Od. 1.288, 2.219, cf. Thgn. 752; τρύχεσθαι λιμῷ Od. 10.177; εὐναῖς ἀνανδρώτοισι τρύχεσθαι S. Tr. 110 (lyr.); χρόνῳ Id. Aj. 605 (lyr.); ἀμπλακίαις E. Hipp. 147 (lyr.); τῇ προσεδρείᾳ Th. 1.126; κατʼ οἶδμʼ ἅλιον E. Hel. 521 (lyr.); ἐτρυχόμεσθα . . ὁδοιπλανοῦντες Ar. Ach. 68; δυσμενέων ἄστυ τ. Sol. 3.22: c. gen., σου τρυχόμεθʼ ἤδη τρία καὶ δέκʼ ἔτη we have pined for thee . . , Ar. Pax 989 (anap.).
exhaustion, distress, Max.Tyr. 34.2 (pl.).

definition: τρύω [ῡ], Keil-Premerstein Erster Bericht p.9 ( Troketta), cj. in Orph. Fr. 270.5: fut. τρύσω [ῡ] A. Pr. 27:—used mostly in pf. Pass. τέτρῡμαι (v. infr.), other tenses being borrowed from τείρω and perh. τρύχω, τρυχόω: but aor. Med. κατα-τρύσαιο Nic. Al. 593: pres. Pass. τρύομαι Call. Fr. 5.4P., IGRom. 4.360.21 ( Pergam., ii A. D.): cf. ἀποτρύω:—

children.definition: wear out, distress, ἀχθηδὼν κακοῦ τρύσει σε A. l.c.:— Pass., to be worn out, τέτρυσαι Simon. 144; τετρῦσθαι ἐς τὸ ἔσχατον κακοῦ Hdt. 1.22, cf. 2.129; δάκρυσιν τετρύμεθα AP 9.549 ( Antiphil.): mostly in part. τετρυμένος (freq. with v.l. τετριμμένος) , τετρ. ταλαιπωρίῃσί τε καὶ ἡλίῳ Hdt. 6.12; πόνοις τετρυμένα σώματα Pl. Lg. 761d; γήρᾳ AP 6.228 (Adaeus); γήραϊ καὶ πενίῃ ib. 7.336; τετρ. . . εὗδεν Ἔρως AP 9.627 ( Marian.); ἐκ πορείας Plu. Eum. 15; συνειδέναι τοῖς σφετέροις πράγμασι τετρυμένοις Plb. 1.62.7, cf. 1.71.3; ὑπὸ τῆς κακοπαθείας Id. 10.13.11; τετρυμένη κλίνη, = τρυφερῶς ἐστρωμένη, Sor. 1.68 (s. v.l.). ( τρῡ-, found also in ἄ-τρῡ-τος, τρύ-χ-ω, τρῦχος, is the weak grade of τερῠ-, found in τερύσκεται, τέρυ (qq.v.); cf. also τείρω, ἀ-τερά-μων.)
dweller in the Troad, St.Byz.:— Adj. Τρῳᾰδικός, ή, όν, Eust. 313.26.

fruits eaten at dessert, figs, nuts, etc., like τραγήματα (which is the older word, acc. to Arist. Fr. 104 (where sg. -αλίου)), Ar. Pax 772, Pl. 798, IG 12(5).647.12 ( Ceos, iii B. C.), Poll. 6.79:—sg. also in Pi. Fr. 124, Phld. Mus. p.76 K., Plu. Sanit. 2.133c.— Adj. τρωγ-άλιος, = τρωκτός, Hsch.

definition: τρώγανα, τά, = foreg., IG 5(1).363.13,16 ( Sparta, i A. D.).

children.definition: hole formed by gnawing, esp. a mouseʼs hole, Batr. 52, Babr. 31.17: generally, hole, Arist. HA 552b28, al.; of a serpent, Herod. 4.90: pl., caves, LXX 1 Ki. 14.11; holes (gnawed) in clothes, Batr. 184; of canals in the flesh, Hp. Carn. 9.

data.ref: Arist. HA 552b28, al.; of a serpent,

children.definition: Hdn. Epim. 136, Eust. 228.36.
myrrh, Edict.Diocl. Delph. 21, al., Gp. 7.36.1, Alex.Trall. 1.12: also τρωγλοδύτις [ῠ], ἡ, Gal. 14.68, Alex.Trall. 5.4; ἶρις τ. Gp. 7.30.1; and τρωγλοδῠτική, Dsc. 1.64.
creeping into a hole, of a mouse, Batr. 52.
dwell in holes, Arist. PA 669b7, IA 713b20.
one who creeps into holes, of foxes and snakes, Arist. HA 610a12; of crabs, Id. IA 713b28:—for οἱ Τρωγλοδύται, Troglodytes, Cave-men, v. Τρωγοδύται.

children.label: II
children.definition: wren, Troglodytes europaeus, Ruf. Fr. 117, Philagr. ap. Aët. 11.11.
of or for dwellers in holes, ζῷα τ. animals that dwell in holes, Arist. HA 488a23, al.

children.label: II
children.definition: of or belonging to the Troglodytes, v. Τρωγοδυτικός.

children.label: III
children.definition: τρωγλοδυτική, v. τρωγλῖτις.
Arist. PA 691a26.
Dim. of τρώγλη, a small hole, Hdn.Gr. 1.366.
Philox. 3.11 (pl.).

definition: τρωγμός τὸ ἐπιθέσθαι τὴν ὕλην τρωγμόν, Hsch.

children.definition: Hdt. 4.183 (codd.ABC), LXX 2 Ch. 12.3 (cod. B), Pap. in Class.Phil. 19.233,234 (iii B. C.), OGI 70 ( Egypt, iii B. C.), PTheb.Bank 9.2 (i B. C.), Sammelb. 4050, Cic. Div. 2.44.93, Plin. HN 6.173, al., Mela 1.23, Mart.Cap. 6.593, al., v.l. in D.S. 1.37: sg. in PCair.Zen. 40.2 (iii B. C.), PSI 4.332.14 (iii B. C.): hence

senses.definition: Τρωγοδῠτικός, ή, όν, belonging to the Τρωγοδύται, σμύρνα, cf. τρωγλῖτις (where Τρωγλ-) ; -κή, ἡ, their country, D.S. 1.30 (cf. p.lxxi Vogel), Plin. HN 6.169, al.; also ἡ Τρωγοδύτις [ῠ] ( Τρωγλ-codd.), ιδος, Plu. Fac.lun. 2.939d, Ael. NA 17.3:—the spelling Τρωγλο- (as if Cave-dwellers) is known to Str. 1.2.34 (unless the passage is interpolated) and is freq. f.l. in codd. (so always in codd. Str., as 16.4.4, 17.1.13, al., although he wrote it ἄνευ τοῦ λ acc. to Str. Chr. 16.55), cf. Arist. HA 597a9, Dsc. 2.160, Hsch.

data.ref: Str. 1.2.34 (unless the passage is interpolated) and is freq.

definition: τρώγω, Od. 6.90, etc.: fut. τρώξομαι Ar. Ach. 806, X. Smp. 4.8: aor. 1 ἔτρωξα ( κατ-) Batr. 182, Hp. Nat.Mul. 8, Timo 66.6 [840]: aor. 2 ἔτρᾰγον, 3 sg. subj. τράγῃ Pherecr. 67.5 (elsewh. only in compos. with ἐν- (q. v.), κατα-, παρα-):— Pass., pf. τέτρωγμαι ( δια-) Ar. V. 371, ( παρεν-) Eub. 15.8:—

children.definition: gnaw, nibble, munch, esp. of herbivorous animals, as mules, τ. ἄγρωστιν Od. 6.90; of swine, ἐρεβίνθους τ. Ar. Ach. 801, cf. 806; of cattle, τὸν θαλλόν, κόμαρον τ., Theoc. 4.45, 9.11; rarely of dogs, Εὐριπίδην ἔτρωγον Sotad. 15.15; of human beings in disease, λίθους τε καὶ γῆν τρώγουσι Hp. Prorrh. 2.31.

children.label: II
children.definition: eat vegetables or fruit, τοὺς γενομένους [κυάμους] οὔτε τρώγουσι οὔτε ἕψοντες πατέονται Hdt. 2.37; τὸ κάτω [τῆς βύβλου] ib. 92; τὸν καρπὸν τοῦ λωτοῦ Id. 4.177; τ. βότρυς Ar. Eq. 1077; βολβοὺς τρώγων, τυροὺς κάπτων Anaxil. 18.3 (anap.); of dessert, eat fruits, as figs, almonds, etc., Hdt. 1.71, Ar. Pax 1324, Pherecr. 159 (v. τρωγάλια) ; ἴτρια, μελίπηκτα, Sol. 38.1, Antiph. 140.4; of small fish as hors-dʼoeuvres, κἀν ποίᾳ πόλει τοσοῦτος < ὢν > τὸ μέγεθος ἰχθῦς τρώγεται; Eup. 23 D.: abs., πίνειν καὶ τ. drink and eat dessert, D. 19.197: Com. metaph., γνώμας τ. Πανδελετείους Ar. Nu. 924 (anap.):— Pass., τρώγεται ἁπαλὰ ταῦτα καὶ αὖα Hdt. 2.92.

data.quote: τοὺς γενομένους [κυάμους] οὔτε τρώγουσι οὔτε ἕψοντες πατέονται

data.ref: Antiph. 140.4; of small fish as hors-dʼoeuvres,

data.quote: κἀν ποίᾳ πόλει τοσοῦτος < ὢν > τὸ μέγεθος ἰχθῦς τρώγεται;

children.label: III
children.definition: eat, serving as pres. to ἔφαγον instead of ἐσθίω, ὁ τρώγων μου τὴν σάρκα καὶ πίνων μου τὸ αἷμα Ev.Jo. 6.54 (cf. aor. φάγητε . . πίητε ib. 53); τρώγοντες καὶ πίνοντες Ev.Matt. 24.38; never in LXX ( ὁ ἐσθίων ἄρτους μου LXX Ps. 40(41).10 becomes ὁ τρώγων μου τὸν ἄρτον when cited in Ev.Jo. 13.18); δύο τρώγομεν ἀδελφοί is dub. l. in Plb. 31.23.9; ἔδωκεν εὔζωμον νήστῃ τρώγειν SIG 1171.9 (Crete, perh. i B. C.); ἡ νὺξ τὴν ἡμέραν τ. (of a black man eating white bread) Diog.Cyn. ap. Sammelb. 5730 (iv/v A. D.); ψυχρὰ τρώγοντα κατακαίεσθαι PMag.Lond. 121.177; ἔμοιγε, ὅσσα παρʼ ἀνθρώποις, τρώγειν ἔθος Batr. 34; this usage is mentioned by AB 114, censured by Phot.

data.quote: ἐσθίω, ὁ τρώγων μου τὴν σάρκα καὶ πίνων μου τὸ αἷμα
ἔμοιγε, ὅσσα παρʼ ἀνθρώποις, τρώγειν ἔθος

children.definition: from Troy, Pi. N. 7.41.

definition: Τρωϊάς, contr. Τρῳάς (freq. written Τρωάς), άδος, fem. of Τρώϊος,

children.definition: Trojan, Od. 13.263; Τρωϊάδας γυναῖκας Il. 9.139, al.; Τρωϊάδες alone, 18.122, al.; Τρῶας καὶ Τρῳάδας Trojan men and Trojan women, 22.105.

children.label: II
children.definition: γῆ Τρῳάς the Troad, S. Aj. 819, al.; ἡ Τρωάς alone, Hdt. 5.122.
Trojan, Il. 10.11, S. Aj. 862, etc.; Τρωϊκὴν ἀνὰ χθόνα A. Myrm. in PSI 11.1211.3; τὰ T. the times of Troy, the Trojan war, Hdt. 2.145, al., Th. 1.3, etc.
of Tros, οἷοι Τρώϊοι ἵπποι Il. 5.222; ἵππους δὲ Τρῳοὺς ὕπαγε ζυγόν 23.291 (here oxyt. acc. to Hdn.Gr. 2.122).

children.label: II
children.definition: Trojan, Il. 13.262:—cf. Τρώς, Τρωϊκός.
D.H. 1.52, St.Byz.
native of Troia in Egypt, PCair.Zen. 133.8 (iii B. C.).
EM 770.53: vulg. τρακταΐσαι, v. τρακταΐζω.

gnawer, nibbler: but in Od. 14.289, 15.416, Phoenician traffickers are called τρῶκται, greedy knaves; so τ. σφόδρʼ ἐστίν Com.Adesp. 606; and Gramm. explain τρώκτης by φάγος, φιλοκερδής, πανοῦργος, ἀπατεών, Hsch., Phot., Eust. 1757.51; φιλοχρήματοι καὶ τ. Philostr. Her.Prooem. 1.
Adj., τρῶκται χεῖρες greedy hands, of a usurer, AP 9.409 ( Antiphan., dub. cj.).

children.label: II
children.definition: a sea-fish with sharp teeth, = ἀμία (q.v.), Ael. NA 1.5.
greedy, Ph. 2.269, Tz.ad Lyc. 213: pecul. fem. τρωκ-τίς, ίδος, Id. ad Hes. Op. 702.
to be gnawed or eaten raw; eatable, Hdt. 2.92; κῆποι τ. kitchen gardens, Philostr. VA 3.56; τ. λάχανα Artem. 1.67.

children.label: II
children.definition: τρωκτά, τά, = τρωγάλια, fruits eaten at dessert, ὅσα ἐστὶ τ. X. An. 5.3.12; τρωκτὰ σησάμου τε καὶ μέλιτος sweatmeats of sesame and honey, Hdt. 3.48.

definition: τρῶμα, τρωματίζω, τρωματίης, τρωμάτιον, Ion. for τραυμ- (q.v.).
τρώμα, ἡ, Dor. for *τραύμη, τραῦμα, τ. ἕλκεος a festering

children.definition: wound, Pi. P. 4.271.
gnawer, name of the weevil, Stratt. 80.

children.label: II
children.definition: Hsch.
grasshopper or locust, Alex. 15.12; ἀκρὶς τ. Dsc. 2.52; troxallis ( v.l. trixallis, etc.), Plin. HN 30.117; τρωξαλλίς (also τριξελλας, τοξαλλίς) = grillus, Gloss.
twig, Thphr. CP 3.2.2; cf. τραύξανα.
Bread-gnawer, name of a mouse in Batr. 28, al.
σταφυλάν) eating-grapes, Theoc. 1.49, cf. Dig. 50.16.205: τρώξιμα, τά, vegetables eaten raw, Hp. Int. 30; λαχανοφαγίη τρωξίμων πολλῶν ib. 34, cf. PTeb. 213 (ii B. C.), 117.74 (i B. C.).
gnawing, biting, ὀνύχων τρώξεις Arist. EN 1148b28; λίθων, γῆς, Hp. Prorrh. 2.31.
destructive to the Trojans, AP 9.62 ( Even.).

turn, change, ἥ τε θαμὰ τρωπῶσα χέει πολυηχέα φωνήν, of the nightingale, Od. 19.521:— Med., turn oneself, turn about, πάλιν τρωπᾶσθαι Il. 16.95; πρὸς πόλιν Od. 24.536; φόβονδε Il. 15.666; Ep. Iterat., τρωπάσκετο φεύγειν 11.568; cf. τρωπασκέσθω· μεταβαλλέσθω, ἐπιστρεφέσθω, Hsch.
Tros, the mythic founder of Troy, Il. 5.265, 20.230, h.Ven. 207; also Τρῶος, ου, ὁ, Hes. Fr. 205 (b).

children.label: II
children.definition: Τρῶες, Τρώων, οἱ, Trojans, Il. 1.152, etc.; Τρῶας καὶ Τρῳάς Trojan men and Trojan women, 22.57; cf. Τρώϊος.
wounding, mostly pl., Hp. VC 2, Arist. Po. 1452b13, Plu. Aud.poet. 2.20e, Sammelb. 6003.13 (iv A. D.): sg., Phld. Herc. 1251.6; injury to a tree, Thphr. HP 4.16.1.
miscarriage, Hp. Coac. 532: pl., Id. Septim. 9, Dsc. 5.72.
one must wound, Sor. 2.64.
vulnerable, Il. 21.568, E. Hel. 810, X. An. 3.1.23, Eub. 107.8, Phld. Sign. 38; cf. τρωτός· παθητός (leg. πληκτός), Hsch.; τετρωτος (sic) = vulnerarius, Gloss.
run, gallop, ἵπποι ῥίμφα μάλα τρωχῶσι Il. 22.163, cf. Od. 6.318, A.R. 3.874.
τσανγάριος, v. τζαγκάριος.
salad, celery pickled in vinegar, Poll. 6.71.

definition: τυβίον, τό, Dim. of τύβος, sine expl., Sch.D.T. p.195H. (Perh. connected with ἡμιτύβιον.)
τυγάτριον, for θυγάτριον, barbarism in Ar. Th. 1184, 1210.

τυγχάνω, Thgn. 253, Pi. P. 3.104, O. 2.47, etc.: Ep. impf. τύγχανον Od. 14.231, ( παρετ-) Il. 11.74: fut. τεύξομαι 16.609, Od. 19.314, Ar. Eq. 112, Lys. 18.23 (also as fut. Med. of τεύχω): aor. 2 ἔτῠχον, Ep. τύχον, Il. 5.287, 587, etc.; Ep. subj. τύχωμι, -ῃσι, 7.243, 11.116; later also τετύχῃσι, Max. 577; late Ep. opt. τετύχοιμι Man. 3.299: Ep. also aor. 1 ἐτύχησα Il. 15.581, al., Hes. Fr. 15: pf. τετύχηκα (intr.) Od. 10.88 ( part. τετυχηκώς, v.l. τετυχηώς. Il. 17.748), Th. 1.32, (trans.) X. Cyr. 4.1.2, Isoc. 3.59; later also τέτευχα, D. 21.150 (cod. S), Arist. EN 1119a10, PA 647b15, freq. later, PEnteux. 6.7 (iii B. C.), UPZ 123.30 (ii B. C.), PStrassb. 98.10 (ii B. C.), Inscr.Prien. 108.287 (ii B. C.), etc.; Dor. pf. inf. τετεύχεν SIG 398.5 ( Cos, iii B. C.); but Ion. plpf. ἐτετεύχεε Hdt. 3.14; τέτυχα v.l. in Ep.Hebr. 8.6, v.l. in J. BJ 7.5.4, ( συν-) Aristeas 180, etc.; part. τετυχώς Jahresh. 29 Beibl. 163 (Stara Zagora):— Med., aor. 1 τεύξασθαι LXX 2 Ma. 15.7:— Pass., impf. ἐτυγχάνετο Ant.Lib. 39.3 (dub.): elsewh. in compds, aor. 1 ἐτεύχθην ( ἐν-) Plb. 35.6.1: pf. τέτευγμαι ( ἐπι-) Id. 6.53.2.

children.label: A
children.definition: happen to be at a place, εἴ πέρ τε τύχῃσι μάλα σχεδόν even if she be quite near, Il. 11.116; μὴ σύ γε κεῖθι τύχοις mayʼst thou not be there, Od. 12.106; πέτρη τετύχηκε διαμπερὲς ἀμφοτέρωθεν 10.88; πεδίοιο διαπρύσιον τετυχηκώς Il. 17.748 (but in these last two places the meaning may be ‘has been made’ (though not by human agency), cf. [ γαῖα] οὐδʼ εὐρεῖα τέτυκται Od. 13.243; γυναικὸς ἄρʼ ἀντὶ τέτυξο Il. 8.163, etc.; v. ad fin.).

happen to one, befall one, come to oneʼs lot, c. dat. pers., οὔνεκά μοι τύχε πολλά because much fell to me, Il. 11.684; καί μοι μάλα τύγχανε πολλά Od. 14.231; θέλοιμʼ ἂν ὡς πλείστοισι πημονὰς τυχεῖν A. Pr. 348, cf. Pers. 706 (troch.); οἷʼ αὐτοῖς τύχοι S. Ph. 275; εἴ τι δεσπόταισι τυγχάνει E. Alc. 138: abs., εἰ δʼ αὖθʼ, ὃ μὴ γένοιτο, συμφορὰ τύχοι A. Th. 5, cf. Ag. 347, etc.; ἄριστα πρὸς τὸ τυγχάνον E. Hel. 1290, cf. Ion 1511.

data.quote: θέλοιμʼ ἂν ὡς πλείστοισι πημονὰς τυχεῖν
εἰ δʼ αὖθʼ, ὃ μὴ γένοιτο, συμφορὰ τύχοι

children.label: b
children.definition: aor. part. ὁ τυχών, the first one meets, any chance person, Hes. Th. 973, Pl. R. 539d, etc.; οἱ τ. everyday men, the vulgar, X. Mem. 3.9.10, etc.; εἷς ἦν τῶν τ. Isoc. 10.21; οὐχ ὁ τ. ἀνήρ, of Moses, Longin. 9.9: so of things, τὸ τυχόν any chance result, Pl. Ti. 46e; ὃν ἐξαλείφει πρόφασις ἡ τυχοῦσʼ ὅλον E. Fr. 1041; οὐχ ὁ τ. λόγος no common discourse, Pl. Lg. 723e; σύνεσιν οὐ τὰν τυχοῦσαν Archim. Spir. Praef.; οἱ τ. φόβοι trifling fears, Lycurg. 37; καίπερ τὸ τ. καταβαλοῦσιν though they may have paid a trifling sum, Str. 5.2.7:—Math., τυχὸν σημεῖον any point (at random), Euc. 1.5, cf. 6.9; ἄλλα, ἃ ἔτυχεν, ἰσάκις πολλαπλάσια any other equimultiples taken at random, Id. 5.4.

data.quote: ὃν ἐξαλείφει πρόφασις ἡ τυχοῦσʼ ὅλον

children.definition: 3 sg. aor. or impf., impers. (sts. also pers.) in relat. clauses, as (when, where, etc.) it (he, she, etc.) happened ( may happen, etc.), i.e. anyhow, at any time, place, etc., καὶ ἀρχομένοις καὶ μεσοῦσι καὶ ὅπως ἔτυχέ τῳ at the beginning, middle, or any other point, Th. 5.20; ὡς ἔτυχε ζημιοῦσθαι to be penalized just anyhow, X. Mem. 3.9.13; οὐχ ὡς ἔτυχεν in no ordinary manner, Men. Sam. 79, BMus.Inscr. 4.481*.340 ( Ephesus, ii A. D.); τὴν μὲν δικαίαν, τὴν δʼ ὅπως ἐτύγχανεν just anyhow, E. Hipp. 929; ἀποτετμάσθω δύο τμάματα ὡς ἔτυχεν let two segments be cut off at random, Archim. Con.Sph. 24; χώρᾳ γʼ ἐν ᾗ ἔτυχε X. Oec. 3.3; ὅπου ἔτυχεν Id. Cyr. 8.4.3; ὅπου ἂν τύχῃ Pl. Prt. 342e; ὁπότε τύχοι sometimes, Pl. Phd. 89b; ὅταν τύχῃ sometimes, E. El. 1169 (lyr.); but, at any odd time, Th. 1.142; ἡνίκʼ ἂν τ. D. 1.3; ἂν τύχῃ, εἰ τύχοι, it may be, Pl. Cra. 430e, Hp.Mi. 367a; τὸ δέ, εἰ ἔτυχεν, οὐχ οὕτως ἔχει Id. Cra. 439c; εἰ οὕτως ἔτυχεν Arist. Cat. 8b12; τὸ ὅπῃ ἔτυχεν mere chance, Pl. Phlb. 28d: with attraction of the relat. Pron., τὸ οἷς ἔτυχε προσκρούειν Plu. Cic. 27; ὡμίλει ᾧ τύχοι Plb. 26.1.3; ὧν ἔτυχε πιμπλάμενος Luc. Vit.Auct. 9; οὐδὲ γὰρ ὧν ἔτυχʼ ἦν they were not just any acts, D. 18.130.

data.quote: τὸ δέ, εἰ ἔτυχεν, οὐχ οὕτως ἔχει

children.label: b
children.definition: inf., ἔτυχε ὄμβρον συνεργῆσαι Plu. Alc. 28, cf. Ael. NA 5.6; ἔτυχεν ὥστε . . D.C. 39.12.

ἀπαίροντες ἀπὸ τῆς Πελοποννήσου ὁπόθεν τύχοιεν, for ὁπόθεν τύχοι, Th. 4.26, cf. 93, 5.56, 7.70, Pl. Tht. 179c; ὅ τι ἂν τύχωσι, τοῦτο λέγουσι they say just anything, Id. Prt. 353a; ὅ τι ἂν τύχωσι, τοῦτο πράξουσιν Id. Cri. 45d, cf. Grg. 522c, Smp. 181b; ἀναφύονται ὁπόθεν ἂν τύχῃ ἕκαστος Id. Tht. 180c; ὡς ἐτύγχανον ἕκαστοι, ηὐλίζοντο X. An. 2.2.17, cf. 3.1.3; τάχʼ ἄν, εἰ τύχοιεν, σωφρονέστεροι γένοιντο D. 15.16; δουλεύειν μᾶλλον ἢ μεθʼ ὁποτέρου ἂν τύχωσι τούτων ἐλευθέρους εἶναι Th. 8.48; πρὸς ὀργὴν ἥν τινα τύχητε ἔστιν ὅτε σφαλέντες τὴν τοῦ πείσαντος μίαν γνώμην ζημιοῦτε yielding to the impulse of the moment, Id. 3.43; εἶτʼ οὐκ ἐλήρουν ὅ τι τύχοιμʼ Ar. Ra. 945: with attraction of the relat. Pron., οὓς ἂν τύχῃς ἐπαινῶν Isoc. 12.206.

data.quote: ὅ τι ἂν τύχωσι, τοῦτο πράξουσιν
τάχʼ ἄν, εἰ τύχοιεν, σωφρονέστεροι γένοιντο
δουλεύειν μᾶλλον ἢ μεθʼ ὁποτέρου ἂν τύχωσι τούτων ἐλευθέρους εἶναι
εἶτʼ οὐκ ἐλήρουν ὅ τι τύχοιμʼ

children.definition: part. τυχόν, used abs. like ἐξόν, παρόν, etc., since it so befell, οὕτως τ. Luc. Symp. 43.

children.label: b
children.definition: Adv., perchance, perhaps, Isoc. 4.171, X. An. 6.1.20, Pl. Alc. 2.140a, 150c, D. 18.221, 21.41, Men. Pk. 184, 1 Ep.Cor. 16.6; τ. ἴσως Epich. 277, E. Fr. 953.9, Men. Epit. 287, Plb. 2.58.9; τυχὸν μὲν . . , τυχὸν δὲ . . Arr. An. 1.10.6, etc.

children.label: II
children.definition: part. of another Verb to express a coincidence, τύχησε γὰρ ἐρχομένη νηῦς a ship happened to be, i.e. was just then, starting, Od. 14.334; ξεῖνος ἐὼν ἐτύχησε παρʼ ἱπποδάμοισι Γερηνοῖς Hes. Fr. 15.3, cf. Semon. 7.19, Pi. N. 1.49; πρυτανεία ἣ ἂν τυγχάνῃ πρυτανεύουσα IG 1(2).63.27, cf. 52; τὰ νοέων τυγχάνω what I happen to have, i.e. have at this moment, in my mind, Hdt. 1.88, cf. 8.65, 68.αʹ; ἐτετεύχεε ἐπισπόμενος Id. 3.14; ὃ τυγχάνω μαθών which I have just learnt, S. Tr. 370; παρὼν ἐτύγχανον I was by just then, Id. Aj. 748; τυγχάνει καθεύδων he is sleeping just now, Ar. V. 336 (troch.); ἔτυχον στρατευόμενοι they were just then engaged in an expedition, Th. 1.104; ἔτυχε κατὰ τοῦτο καιροῦ ἐλθών he came just at this point of time, Id. 7.2; ἥτις δέ τοι μάλιστα σωφρονεῖν δοκεῖ, αὕτη μέγιστα τυγχάνει λωβωμένη she is just the one who . . , Semon. 7.109; but freq. τυγχάνω cannot be translated at all, esp. in phrase τυγχάνω ὤν, which is simply = εἰμί, S. Aj. 88, Ar. Pl. 35, Pl. Prt. 313c, etc.

data.quote: ξεῖνος ἐὼν ἐτύχησε παρʼ ἱπποδάμοισι Γερηνοῖς

children.definition: part. ὤν is sts. omitted, ὁ γὰρ μέγιστος τυγχάνει δορυξένων S. El. 46; εἴ σοι χαρτὰ τυγχάνει τάδε ib. 1457; νῦν δʼ ἀγροῖσι τυγχάνει ib. 313; ἔνδον γὰρ ἄρτι τυγχάνει Id. Aj. 9; εἴ τις εὔνους τυγχάνει Ar. Ec. 1141; εἰ σὺ τυγχάνεις ἐπιστήμων τούτων Pl. Prt. 313e, cf. Grg. 502b, R. 369b, al.: sts. τυγχάνειν is used much like εἶναι, Σωτὴρ γένοιτʼ ἂν Ζεὺς ἐπʼ ἀσπίδος τυχών A. Th. 520; οὐκ ἀποδάμου τυχόντος not being absent, Pi. P. 4.5 (cf. τόσσαις) ; ποῦ χρὴ τηνικαῦτα τυγχάνειν; E. IA 730; τ. ἐν ἐμπύροις to be engaged in . . , Id. Andr. 1113; freq. in Arist., δύο μέρη τετύχηκεν ἐξ ὧν ἡ πόλις Pol. 1318a31, cf. 1289b16, Top. 151b11; also in later Gr., τὰ ἑπτάμηνα γόνιμα τυγχάνειν Sor. 1.55, cf. 69, al.; νέος πάνυ τυγχάνων PLips. 40 ii 7 (iv A. D.), etc.:— Phryn. 244 rejects this usage in Attic.

data.quote: δύο μέρη τετύχηκεν ἐξ ὧν ἡ πόλις

children.label: b
children.definition: τυγχάνον, = τὸ ἐκτὸς ὑποκείμενον, the external reality, e. g. αὐτὸς ὁ Δίων as distd. both from the word ( φωνή) Δίων and its meaning, Stoic. 2.48.

children.label: c
children.definition: τὰ πράγματα τυγχάνοντα καλοῦσι (sc. οἱ Στωϊκοί) , τέλος γὰρ τὸ τυχεῖν τούτων, ib. 77.

inf., τυγχάνομεν ἐπιδεδωκέναι we happen to have handed in . . , we have just handed in . . , PTeb. 796.13 (ii B. C.), cf. PSI 10.1118.8 (i A. D.), 1.39.4 (ii A. D.), Heliod. et Antyll. ap. Orib. 44.8.21, 25, 44.23.21, Gal. 18(2).394.

children.label: B
children.definition: gain oneʼs end or purpose, succeed, οὐκ ἐτύχησεν ἑλίξας Il. 23.466; εἰ τύχῃ τις ἔρδων Pi. N. 7.11, cf. 55; τὸ τυχεῖν, = νίκη, Id. O. 2.51; πείθειν . . τυγχάνειν θʼ ἅμα E. Hec. 819; εἰ τύχοιμεν Th. 4.63; τυχόντες if successful, opp. σφαλέντες, Id. 3.39, cf. 82, Pi. P. 10.62; τυγχάνουσι καὶ ἀποτυγχάνουσι Arist. Po. 1450a3; ὀρθῶς πράττειν καὶ τ. Pl. Euthd. 280a; gain oneʼs request, Hdt. 1.213 (so τυχόντα γνώμης in Th. 3.42); in speaking, to be right, τί νιν καλοῦσα . . τύχοιμʼ ἄν; A. Ag. 1233, cf. Ch. 14, 317 (lyr.), S. Ph. 223, OC 1580; Δίκαν νιν προσαγορεύομεν τυχόντες καλῶς A. Ch. 950 (lyr.):— Pass., impers., αὐτῷ πρὸς τὸ ἔργον οὐδὲν ἐτυγχάνετο nothing went right, dub. in Ant.Lib. 39.3:—in part. τυχήσας or τυχών, combined with νύξε, βάλε, οὖτα, etc., pierce, wound, etc., successfully, so that the whole phrase means hit, ἔγχεϊ νύξε κατὰ κληῗδα τυχήσας Il. 5.579, cf. 858, 12.394; βάλε δουρὶ κατὰ ζωστῆρα τυχήσας ib. 189; ὑπὸ στέρνοιο τυχήσας βεβλήκει 4.106, cf. 5.98, 582, 13.371, 397, Od. 19.452, al.; also conversely, θηρητὴρ ἐτύχησε βαλών Il. 15.581; βαλὼν τύχω Hdt. 3.35; also apart from such combinations, hit, c. gen., προβιβάντος Il. 16.609; μηρίνθοιο 23.857; τ. τοῦ σκοποῦ Pl. Lg. 717b, cf. R. 523b, Th. 2.35, X. An. 3.2.19, Ap. 1: c. dupl. gen., εἰ . . τοῦ παιδὸς . . τύχω μέσης τῆς καρδίης Hdt. 3.35: abs., ἤμβροτες οὐδʼ ἔτυχες Il. 5.287; αἰ κε τύχωμι 7.243, Od. 22.7.

data.quote: εἰ . . τοῦ παιδὸς . . τύχω μέσης τῆς καρδίης

children.label: II
children.definition: hit upon, light upon:

meet, fall in with persons, Λακεδαίμονι . . τυχήσας having met [him] in Lacedaemon, Od. 21.13: c. gen., θρηνητοῦ A. Ag. 1075; τριακτῆρος ib. 172 (lyr.); ἀγαθῶν ἀνδρῶν Lys. 2.5; γυναικῶν X. Smp. 9.7: with a predicate added, μή τευ μελαμπύγου τύχῃς Archil. 110; προφρόνων Μοισᾶν τ. Pi. I. 4(3).43(61); θεῶν ἀμεινόνων τ. E. Heracl. 351; ἐμοῦ . . οἰκητοῦ S. OT 1450, cf. 677; ἡμῶν τ. οἵων σε χρή E. Hel. 1300, cf. Lys. 18.23; ἐρωτᾶτε αὐτοὺς ὁποίων τινῶν ἡμῶν ἔτυχον X. An. 5.5.15; τοῦ δαίμονος . . κακοδαίμονος Ar. Eq. 112.

data.quote: ἐρωτᾶτε αὐτοὺς ὁποίων τινῶν ἡμῶν ἔτυχον

children.definition: light on a thing, τύχε γάρ ἀμάθοιο βαθείης Il. 5.587; attain, obtain a thing, c. gen., πομπῆς καὶ νόστοιο Od. 6.290; αἰδοῦς Thgn. 253, cf. 256; [ οἴκτου] A. Pr. 241; ξυγγνώμης Th. 7.15; τῆς ἀξίας Ar. Av. 1223; of meeting with misfortunes, βίης τυχεῖν meet with, suffer violence, Hdt. 9.108; τραυμάτων, κακῶν, A. Ag. 866, E. Hec. 1280; δίκης, κρίσεως, Pl. Grg. 472d, Phdr. 249a, cf. Lg. 869b: abs., have the lot or fate, ἄλλος μὲν ἀποφθίσθω ἄλλος δὲ βιώτω, ὅς κε τύχῃ Il. 8.430; τὴν παρὰ Δαρείου αἰτήσας ἔτυχε μισθόν Hdt. 5.23 (where τὴν is governed by αἰτήσας).

data.quote: ἄλλος μὲν ἀποφθίσθω ἄλλος δὲ βιώτω, ὅς κε τύχῃ
τὴν παρὰ Δαρείου αἰτήσας ἔτυχε μισθόν

children.label: b
children.definition: Hom. also c. acc. of neut. Adj. or Pron., τὰ πρόσφορα A. Ch. 711, cf. Eu. 30, S. OC 1106, Ph. 509 (lyr.), E. Med. 758, Hec. 51: later the acc. is used more freely, τ. ἐπίστασιν Sammelb. 5235.15 (i A. D.); ὑπογραφήν BGU 615.23 (ii A. D.); βοήθειαν PGoodsp.Cair. 15.14 (iv A. D.); εὐκαιρίαν PSI 9.1082.5 (iv A. D.); τὰ γυναίκια δεσμὸν οὐδένα βούλεται τυγχάνειν Sor. 1.70b.

data.ref: Hec. 51: later the acc. is used more freely,

data.quote: τὰ γυναίκια δεσμὸν οὐδένα βούλεται τυγχάνειν

children.label: c
children.definition: obtain a thing from a person, ὧν δέ σου τυχεῖν ἐφίεμαι S. Ph. 1315; σου τοῦτο τ. Id. OC 1168; or the pers. may be added with a Prep., τ. ἐπαίνου ἔκ τινος Id. Ant. 665; παρὰ σεῖο τ. φιλότητος Od. 15.158; τιμίαν ἕδραν παρʼ ἀνδρῶν A. Eu. 856 (dub.); αἰδοῦς ὑπό τινος X. Cyr. 1.6.10, cf. Mem. 4.8.10, etc.: abs., χρὴ πρὸς μακάρων τυγχάνοντʼ εὖ πασχέμεν Pi. P. 3.104.

data.quote: χρὴ πρὸς μακάρων τυγχάνοντʼ εὖ πασχέμεν

children.label: d
children.definition: inf., οἶμαί σου τεύξεσθαι μεθεῖναί με Pl. Phlb. 50d; ἐὰν ψαῦσαι τοῦ νεκροῦ τύχωμεν Plu. Pel. 33; οὐ τυχὼν ἐπιδείξειν ( = ἐπιδεῖξαι) not having succeeded in proving, PPetr. 3p.153 (iii B. C.). ( Τυ-γ-χ-άνω, with ἐτύχησα, τετύχηκα, is formed from the aor. τυχ-εῖν, which was orig. the aor. Pass. (with act. form) of τεύχω ‘makeʼ; ἔτυχε = factum est, as ἔτραφον = I was nourished (v. τρέφω); senses A.I.1-3 are the oldest and are parallel to τεύχω II (esp. Pass.); many of the forms belong equally to both verbs; τιτύσκομαι likewise belongs to both verbs; τ(ε)υχ- from *θ(ε)υχ-, cf. ἀποθύσκειν, ἐνθύσκει, συνθύξω, and perh. Germ. taugen ‘to be capable, useful’, Engl. dow, doughty.)

definition: τύδαι ἐνταῦθα, Αἰολεῖς, Hsch. (f. l. for τυῖδε).
Τυδεύς, ὁ, gen. Τυδέως, Ep. -έος (never -ῆος) Il. 2.406, al.: acc. -έα (never -ῆα) 6.222, also -ῆ 4.384:—

children.definition: Tydeus, one of the Seven against Thebes, ll. cc.

definition: τυΐ ὧδε, Κρῆτες, Hsch. (Cf. υἷ.) τύϊγγα· ὀρνιθάριόν τι, Id. (Cf. τρύγγας ? or leg. ἴϋγγα.)

children.definition: hither, τυῖδʼ ἔλθʼ Sapph. 1.5, cf. Supp. 1.2, 96.2 L.-P., Theoc. 28.5, Epigr.Gr. 988.3 ( Balbilla), Sch.T Il. 14.298.

definition: τύϊον, τό, f.l. for θυῖον in Thphr. HP 5.2.1.

children.definition: an instrument for threshing, Theognost. Can. 24, Eust. 967.18; = tribula, trahea, Gloss.; written τυτάνη in Hsch., and τρυγάνη (q. v.): also Dim. τυκάνιον, PLond. 5.1657.7 (iv/v A. D.), Gloss. ( -νιν).
work stones, λίθους Ar. Av. 1138.

definition: τυκίον, τό, Dim. (only in form) of τύκος, Eust. 136.23.

children.definition: a working of stones, in pl., κανόνων τυκίσματα, i.e. walls of stone worked by rule, E. Tr. 814 (lyr.); λαΐνων τυκις μάτων Id. Fr. 125.3, cf. HF 1096.

definition: τῦκον, τό, Boeot. for σῦκον, Stratt. 47.5, cf. Luc. Jud.Voc. 8.

C.), Supp.Epigr. 2.569.27 ( Didyma, ii B. C.); τύχοι· λιθοξοϊκὰ ἐργαλεῖα, Hsch., cf. Paus.Gr. Fr. 62 ( τοιχοι Poll. 10.147 codd.); = ὄρυξ, Theognost. Can. 4.
τύχους καὶ τοὺς σφῆνας καλοῦσιν Hsch. s.v. τύχων πυλῶν: cf. eund. s.v. τύφοι.

Dim. of τύλος I, Aret. SD 2.9. (As if from a form τύλαινα, like φλύκταινα.)

τῠλᾰρόω, = μανδαλόω, Hsch.
thrush, also ἰλλάς, Eust. 947.10; = bubo or charadrius, dub. in Gloss.
Dim. of sq. 3, S. Fr. 468, PRev.Laws 94.10 (iii B. C.), Ael. NA 2.11, Hsch. s.v. κνέφαλλον.

swelling, callus, esp. a porterʼs shoulder, which has grown callous from carrying weights, ἔκαμόν γα τὰν τύλαν κακῶς, says the Boeotian laden with his wares, Ar. Ach. 860; ὑπόκυπτε τὰν τύλαν ib. 954, v. Sch. ad ll.; τραχήλου τύλα Telecl. 50 (so Dor. acc. τύλαν Dura4 155 (iii A. D.)); of the hump of a camel, Hsch.: also, in pl., blisters on the hands, Id.
pad for carrying burdens on, porterʼs knot, invented by Protagoras, acc. to Arist. Fr. 63.

cushion, mattress, Sapph. 50, Eup. 170, Antiph. 214, PTeb. 765.2 (ii B. C.), PLond. 2.402v. 15 ( ii B. C., prob.), D.S. 13.84, AP 11.14 ( Ammian.), 315 ( Lucill.), Artem. 5.8, etc. ( = Att. κνέφαλλον acc. to Phryn. 151). [ ῠ prob. in Eup. and Antiph. ll. cc., cf. τῠλος: but ῡ later, AP ll. cc.]
callous, cj. Wimmer in Thphr. HP 3.18.11.
Hsch.
wrapping, ὑμενοειδὴς τ., of the diaphragm, Sch.rec. A. Pr. 881.
Dim. of τύλος, small pin or peg, Hero Spir. 1.6, Eutoc. ad Archim. iii p.70H.
Theognost. Can. 24.
twist or roll up, ἠλακάτη τὸ ξύλον ἐν τυλίσσονται τὰ ἔρια Sch. Od. 6.53.
οἴμας τυλίσσων ( = ὁδοὺς ἐρευνῶν paraphr.) perh. unravel, Lyc. 11.

box, chest, D.C. 79.20.
like a lump or callus, Asclep.Jun. ap. Gal. 13.537, Hsch. s.v. κηλάς; cf. τυλώδης.
callous, knobby, Nic. Th. 272.
mattress-maker, Aegyptus 15.224 (v A. D.).
capitale pilentum, Gloss. (s.v.l.).
callus, X. Mem. 1.2.54, Nic. Th. 178, Dsc. 3.80; inside the hands, τὼ χεῖρε τύλων ἀνάπλεως Luc. Somn. 6; on the knees, Sch. Ar. Ach. 553, etc.; cf. τυλόω II.

knob or nose on which the thread of a screw works, Hero Spir. 1.5; peg on which a string is looped, Eutoc. ad Archim. iii p.60 H.; knob on an axle to which a cord is attached, Heliod. ap. Orib. 49.3.3, 49.4.25, 51, 49.8.4, Sor. 1.68. [ ῠ Nic. l.c.; cf. τύλη.]

children.definition: one who beats the τύμπανον, drummer, Str. 15.1.52, BGU 630 iv 1 (ii A. D.); Τυμπανισταί, name of a play by Sophocles:—fem. τυμπᾰν-ίστρια, of a priestess of Sabazius, D. 18.284, Luc. Somn. 12.

children.label: II
children.definition: -ιστῶν (from -ιστός) = membraneorum, Gloss.
Cels. 3.21.2, Gal. 14.746, Gloss.
sounding with drums, Orph. H. 14.3.
like a drum, Arist. Cael. 293b34, D.L. 9.30 (Cobet, for -ῶδες), Placit. 3.10.4.

definition: τυμπανόεις, εσσα, εν, = foreg.; ὕδρωψ τ.,

children.definition: Nic. Al. 342.

definition: τύμπανον, τό, also in the form τύπανον (q.v.): ( τύπτω):—

children.definition: kettledrum, such as was used esp. in the worship of the Mother Goddess and Dionysus, Hdt. 4.76, E. HF 892; τυμπάνων ἀλαλαγμοί, ἀράγματα, Id. Cyc. 65 (lyr.), 205; τύμπανα, Ῥέας τε μητρὸς ἐμά θʼ εὑρήματα, says Dionysus, Id. Ba. 59, cf. 156 (lyr.), IG 42(1).131.9, 10 (Epid.); in Corybantic rites, Ar. V. 119; τ. ἀράσσειν, ῥήσσειν, AP 6.217 ( Simon.), 7.485 ( Diosc.); καταυλήσει χρῆται καὶ τυμπάνοις Sor. 2.29.
τύμπανον φυσᾶν, of inflated eloquence, AP 13.21 ( Theodorid.).

children.label: II
children.definition: Ar. Pl. 476 ( ξύλα ἐφʼ οἷς [ἐν οἷς Suid.] ἐτυμπάνιζον· ἐχρῶντο γὰρ ταύτῃ τῇ τιμωρίᾳ· ἢ βάκλα, παρὰ τὸ τύπτειν Sch.); τινῶν μὲν εἰς δεσμωτήριον, τινῶν δὲ ἐπὶ τύμπανον ἀπαγομένων S.E. M. 2.30; τοὺς ἐκ τυμπάνου καὶ τοὺς ἀνεσκολοπισμένους Luc. Cat. 6; ἐπὶ τὸ τ. προσῆγε LXX 2 Ma. 6.19, cf. 28; cf. τύπανον.

data.quote: τινῶν μὲν εἰς δεσμωτήριον, τινῶν δὲ ἐπὶ τύμπανον ἀπαγομένων
τοὺς ἐκ τυμπάνου καὶ τοὺς ἀνεσκολοπισμένους

children.definition: = tumix, sirimpio (dub. sens.), Gloss.
cudgel, τὰς πολλὰς ἐπὶ τοῦ νώτου διὰ τῶν τ. πληγάς Dam. Isid. 185; so perh. in LXX ll. cc.

data.quote: τὰς πολλὰς ἐπὶ τοῦ νώτου διὰ τῶν τ. πληγάς

children.label: III
children.definition: drum, Hero Bel. 86, cf. Orib. 49.4.43; in Verg. G. 2.444, tympana are wagon-wheels made of a solid piece of wood, rollers; similarly perh. in PLond. 1821.204, possibly of the wheel of an irrigating machine: cf. τυμπάνιον.

children.label: IV
children.definition: the sunken triangular space enclosed by the cornice of the pediment, Lat. tympanum fastigii, Vitr. 4.7.5; the square panel of a door, Id. 4.6.4.
to be stretched tight like a drum, Hippiatr. 71.
Hero Spir. 2.36; = τύμπανον I.1, dub. in AP 6.220 ( Diosc.).

data.ref: Hero Spir. 2.36; = τύμπανον I.1, dub. in

children.definition: delighting in drums, Orph. H. 27.11.
drummer, esp. used of the Galli in the worship of Cybele, in Lat. form tympanotriba, Plaut. Truc. 611.
carry drums, Clearch. 10.
drum-like, as of a drum, ἦχος Sor. 2.31, 37; v. τυμπανοειδής.

definition: Τυμωλίς, Τυμωλ-ῑτική, Τυμωλ-ιτίκιον, Τύμωλ-ος, v. Τμῶλος.

children.definition: Tyndareos, husband of Leda, Od. 11.298, 24.199 (cf. Hdn.Gr. 2.151), and E. in lyr. passages ( El. 117, 989) acc. to codd. (prob. f.l.); Att. Τυνδάρεως, [ᾰ], εω, ὁ, A. Ag. 83 (anap.), Th. 1.9, title of tragedy by S. (gen. -εω also in Hes. Fr. 94.7, but -έου Fr. 96.21):—hence Patron. Τυνδᾰρίδης [ῐ], Dor. -δας, Pi. N. 10.73, etc.; pl. οἱ Τυνδαρίδαι, of Castor and Pollux, h.Hom. 17.2, Hdt. 4.145, etc. — Adj. Τυνδάρειος [ᾰ], α, ον, E. Hel. 137, IT 5; also ος, ον Id. Or. 1512 (troch.), Ar. Th. 919:—fem. Patron. Τυνδᾰρίς, ίδος, ἡ, παῖς E. Hel. 1546, etc.

definition: τυννός, ά, όν, Dor. for μικρός,

children.definition: so small, so little, Call. Fr. 420, Theoc. 24.139, IGRom. 4.235.2 ( Mysia); ἐκ τυννῶν ( ἐκ τιτυννῶν codd., corr. Ruhnken) from childhood, Suid. s.v. ἐκ τιτυννῶν.

definition: τυννοῦτος, ον, and ο, lengthd. form of τυννός,

children.definition: so small, so little, Ar. Th. 745; commonly with ι demonstr., τυννουτοσί, -ονί, Id. Ach. 367, Eq. 1220; gen. and dat. τυννουτουί, -ῳί, Id. Nu. 392 (anap.), Ra. 139.
βωλοκοπέω (acc. to Sch.), or = σκάπτειν ἀμπέλους (acc. to Hsch.), Ar. Pax 1148 (troch.); = ἐπιρραίνειν πηλῷ, Phot.:—metaph. in Pass., ὁ δʼ ἀγνοῶν ταῦτʼ εἰκότως -άζεται Sosip. 1.35.
mud, Men. 1078, Sch. Ar. Pax 1148.
muddy, λόγος ( οἷον πεπατημένος καὶ κοινός) Com.Adesp. 909.
artifice, Μενανδρείων ἐπέων δεδαηκότα πάσας τύξιας Ath.Mitt. 17.272 ( Athens, ii A. D.); τύξιν· τεῦξιν, παρασκευήν, Hsch.
Opp. C. 1.458 ( Pass.).

children.label: II
children.definition: τυπή) = κόπτω, Hsch.

Arist. Ath. 45.1, Phld. Mus. p.49 K.), drum, h.Hom. 14.3, A. Fr. 57.10 (anap.), E. Hel. 1347 (lyr.), Diog.Ath. 1.3, AP 6.165.5 ( Phal.). [ τυμπ- is read against the metre in E. l.c., A. l.c. codd. Str., Diog. l.c. codd. Ath.]

children.label: II
children.definition: ὁ ἀπὸ τοῦ τ. nickname of one Lysimachus who at the last moment escaped execution, Arist. l.c.; ἄξιοί εἰσι τυχεῖν πάντες ἑνὸς τ. AP 11.160 ( Lucill.); τύπανα is metrically possible in Ar. Pl. 476, and is required there by the alphabetical order in Suid., as is τύπανον in Hsch.

data.quote: ἄξιοί εἰσι τυχεῖν πάντες ἑνὸς τ.

data.ref: Ar. Pl. 476, and is required there by the alphabetical order in

children.label: III
children.definition: = crusta, Gloss.

children.label: IV
children.definition: BGU 9 i 7 (iii A. D.).

definition: τύπανος, ὁ, an unknown bird, Arist. HA 609a27 (perh. f.l. for τύραννος).

children.definition: Dim. of τύπος, small figure, image, Tz. H. 11.473.
mallet, hammer, S. Fr. 844, cf. Hsch.

definition: τυπαστήριον τὸ τῶν ἁλιέων στυμνίον, Hsch. ( τυμπ- cod., τυπ- poscit ordo).

children.definition: beating the breast for grief, mourning, D.H. 4.67.
blow, wound, in pl., Il. 5.887, A.R. 3.848, etc.: sg., Nic. Th. 129, 673.
striker, Hsch., Theognost. Can. 24.
beating of the breast, Supp.Epigr. 4.573.12 (Notium, metr.).
hammered, wrought, χαλκός, opp. τροχίας, Poll. 7.105.
a little model, IG 2(2).1534.66 (pl.).
impressionable, Plu. Virt.mor. 2.442c; conforming to type ( τύπος vii. 3), Gal. 7.471. Adv. -κῶς, νοσεῖν Ruf. ap. Orib. 8.47.11.
typicum, = figuratum, Gloss.; τὰ τ. perh. seals on a will, PMasp. 154v. 20 (vi A. D.).
Adv. -κῶς by way of example, 1 Ep.Cor. 10.11.
Dim. of τύπος III, small model, IG 2(2).1534.205, al., 11(2).161 B 119 ( Delos, iii B. C.).
hammer, A.R. 4.762, al., Call. in PSI 9.1092.50, Agatharch. 25.
certified copy, -γράφου γαμικοῦ copy of marriage lines, Jahresh. 18 Beibl. 287 ( Ephesus, i B. C.).
blow, τ. ἀντίτυπος Orac. ap. Hdt. 1.67; beat of horses’ hoofs, v.l. for κτύπος in X. Eq. 11.12; αἰθερίου πατάγοιο τ. βρονταῖον ἀκούων Nonn. D. 20.351; so perh. νάβλα τ. Sopat. 16.

children.label: II
children.definition: the effect of a blow or of pressure:

impression of a seal, τύποι σφενδόνης χρυσηλάτου E. Hipp. 862, cf. Pl. Tht. 192a, 194b, Chrysipp.Stoic. 2.23, Luc. Alex. 21; τ. ἐνσημήνασθαί τινι Pl. R. 377b; stamp on a coin, τὰ ἀκριβῆ τὸν τ. Luc. Hist.Conscr. 10, cf. Hero *Mens. 60, Hsch. s.v. Κυζικηνοι στατῆρες; on a branding-iron, ὄ τ. τοῦ καυτῆρος ἔστω ἀλώπηξ ἢ πίθηκος Luc. Pisc. 46: generally, print, impression, χύτρας τύπον ἀρθείσης ἐν σποδῷ μὴ ἀπολιπεῖν, ἀλλὰ συγχεῖν Plu. QConv. 2.727c, cf. Sollert. 982b, Iamb. Protr. 21. κθʼ, Gp. 2.20.1; στίβου γʼ οὐδεὶς τ. no foot print, S. Ph. 29 (v.l. κτύπος) ; ὡς ἡδὺς ἐν πόρπακι σὸς (sc. τοῦ βραχίονος) κεῖται τύπος thy imprint, (O arm), E. Tr. 1196 ( σῷ cj. Dobree); τ. ὀδόντων imprint of teeth, AP 6.57.5 ( Paul.Sil.); print, βάλω τὸν δάκτυλόν μου εἰς τὸν τ. τῶν ἥλων Ev.Jo. 20.25; οἱ τ. τῶν πληγῶν Ath. 13.585c.

data.quote: ὄ τ. τοῦ καυτῆρος ἔστω ἀλώπηξ ἢ πίθηκος
χύτρας τύπον ἀρθείσης ἐν σποδῷ μὴ ἀπολιπεῖν, ἀλλὰ συγχεῖν
βάλω τὸν δάκτυλόν μου εἰς τὸν τ. τῶν ἥλων

children.label: b
children.definition: impressions supposed by Democr. and Epicur. to be made on the air by things seen, and to travel through space, Thphr. Sens. 52, Epicur. Ep. 1p.9U., Nat. 2.6, al.; ὁ θεὸς . . πνεῦμα ἐνεκέρασεν [τοῖς ὀφθαλμοῖς] οὕτως ἰσχυρὸν καὶ φιλότεχνον ὥστε ἀναμάσσεσθαι τοὺς τ. τῶν ὁρωμένων Arr. Epict. 2.23.3.

data.quote: ὁ θεὸς . . πνεῦμα ἐνεκέρασεν [τοῖς ὀφθαλμοῖς] οὕτως ἰσχυρὸν καὶ φιλότεχνον ὥστε ἀναμάσσεσθαι τοὺς τ. τῶν ὁρωμένων

children.definition: hollow mould or matrix, καθάπερ ἐν τύπῳ τὰ σχήματα πλασθῆναι Arist. PA 676b9, cf. Pr. 892b2; used by κοροπλάθοι, D.Chr. 60.9, Procl. in Ti. 1.335, 394 D., cf. Hsch. s.v. χοάνη; by fruit-growers, to shape the fruit while growing, Gp. 10.9.3; die used in striking coins, metaph., Κύπριος χαρακτήρ τʼ ἐν γυναικείοις τύποις εἰκὼς πέπληκται τεκτόνων πρὸς ἀρσένων A. Supp. 282.

data.quote: καθάπερ ἐν τύπῳ τὰ σχήματα πλασθῆναι
Κύπριος χαρακτήρ τʼ ἐν γυναικείοις τύποις εἰκὼς πέπληκται τεκτόνων πρὸς ἀρσένων

children.definition: engraved mark, engraving, δέλτον χαλκῆν τύπους ἔχουσαν ἀρχαίων γραμμάτων engravings of letters, i. e. engraved letters, Plu. Alex. 17, cf. Pl. Phdr. 275a; τὰ γεγραμμένα τύποις Id. Ep. 343a; τὸ μέτρον τοῦ ποδὸς ὑποτέτακται τούτοις τοῖς τ. the length of the foot is subjoined in this engraving, Rev.Bibl. 35.285 ( Jerusalem).
the depression between the underlip and chin, Poll. 2.90.
pip on dice, Id. 9.95.

children.label: III
children.definition: cast or replica made in a mould, τ. κατάμακτος IG 2(2).1534.87; τ. ἔγμακτος ib. 64.

children.label: IV
children.definition: figure worked in relief, whether made by moulding, modelling, or sculpture, αἱμασιὴ ἐγγεγλυμμένη τύποισι Hdt. 2.138, cf. 106, 136, 148, 153; θεοῦ τ. μὴ ἐπίγλυφε δακτυλίῳ Iamb. Protr. 21. κγ; σιδηρονώτοις ἀσπίδος τύποις E. Ph. 1130; χρυσοκόλλητοι τ. Id. Rh. 305; τ. ἀργυροῦς IG 2(2).1533.30, 11(2).161 B 77, cf. 115 ( Delos, iii B. C.); τύπους ἐργάσασθαι καὶ παρέχειν ib. 42(1).102.36 ( Epid., iv B. C.); tablet bearing a relief, καθελέσθαι τοὺς τ. καὶ εἴ τι ἄλλο ἐστὶν ἀργυροῦν ἢ χρυσοῦν ib. 22.839.30, cf. 56, al.; τ. Ἔρωτα ἔχων ἐπειργασμένον Paus. 6.23.5; τῶν τʼ ἄλλων ὧν τύπος εἰκόνʼ ἔχει IG 2.2378, cf. 22.2021.8, 3.1330.5; ἐνταῦθά εἰσιν ἐπὶ τύπου γυναικῶν εἰκόνες Paus. 9.11.3; πεποιημένα ἐν τύπῳ in relief, Id. 2.19.17; typos scalpsit, Plin. HN 35.128; impressā argillā typum fecit, ib. 151; πρὸς Ναυσίαν περὶ τοῦ τ., title of speech by Lysias, Suid. s.v. λιθουργική; Γάλλοι . . ἔχοντες προστηθίδια καὶ τύπους Plb. 21.37.6, cf. 21.6.7.

data.quote: τῶν τʼ ἄλλων ὧν τύπος εἰκόνʼ ἔχει
ἐνταῦθά εἰσιν ἐπὶ τύπου γυναικῶν εἰκόνες

children.label: V
children.definition: carved figure, image, ποιεῦνται ξύλινον τ. ἀνθρωποειδέα, ποιησάμενοι δὲ ἐσεργνῦσι τὸν νεκρόν Hdt. 2.86; τ. ποιησάμενος λίθινον ἔστησε· ζῷον δέ οἱ ἐνῆν ἀνὴρ ἱππεύς Id. 3.88; χρυσέων ξοάνων τύποι, periphr. for χρύσεα ξόανα, E. Tr. 1074 (lyr.); γραφαῖς καὶ τ. paintings and statues, Plb. 9.10.12; γραπτοὶ τ. prob. painted pediment- figures, E. Fr. 764, cf. Isoc. 9.74, AP 7.730 ( Pers.); idol, graven image, LXX Am. 5.26, J. AJ 1.19.10.

data.quote: ποιεῦνται ξύλινον τ. ἀνθρωποειδέα, ποιησάμενοι δὲ ἐσεργνῦσι τὸν νεκρόν
τ. ποιησάμενος λίθινον ἔστησε· ζῷον δέ οἱ ἐνῆν ἀνὴρ ἱππεύς

children.definition: exact replica, image, as children are called the τύποι of their parents, Artem. 2.45; τ. λογίου Ἑρμοῦ, of Demosthenes, Aristid. 2.307 J.

children.label: VI
children.definition: form, shape, οὐλῆς Arist. GA 721b32; σώματος Id. Phgn. 806a32; προσώπου Id. Mir. 832b15; ἀγγείου Crates Gramm. ap. Ath. 11.495b; τὸν ἄρτον ἔχειν ἴδιον τ. OGI 56.73 ( Canopus, iii B. C.); οἱ τ. τῶν γραμμάτων D.H. Dem. 52; ὁ τ. τῶν χαρακτήρων Plu. Gen.Socr. 2.577f; τοὺς τ. τῶν συλλαμβανομένων Sor. 1.39; Ἱππομέδοντος σχῆμα καὶ μέγας τ., periphr. for H. himself, A. Th. 488; Γοργείοισιν εἰκάσω τ. Id. Eu. 49; ὄμφακος τ., = ὄμφαξ, S. Fr. 255.5; βραχιόνων ἡβητὴς τ. E. Heracl. 858; κάλλος ἔχουσα τύποισι features, IG 14.2135 ( Rome), cf. (Max.Tyr. 31.3, Adam. 1.4.

thing having a shape, οὐλοφυεῖς . . τ. χθονὸς ἐξανέτελλον undifferentiated forms rose from the earth, Emp. 62.4; τ. τις πορφυροῦς κατὰ χρόαν, τῷ σχήματι ἐμφερὴς κιβωρίου θύλακι (viz. the placenta) Sor. 1.57.

form of expression, style, ὁ πραγματικὸς τ. [τοῦ Ξενοφῶντος] D.H. Pomp. 4; ὁ τ. τῆς γραφῆς Longin. ap. Porph. Plot. 19; ὁ τ. ὁ πολιτικός Hermog. Id. 2.11; οὐδʼ ἀληθινοῦ τύπου μέτεστι τῷ ἀνδρί ibid.; ὁ διὰ τῶν συμβόλων προτρεπτικὸς τ. Iamb. Protr. 21; ὁ αἰνιγματώδης τ. Id. VP 23.103.

data.quote: ὁ διὰ τῶν συμβόλων προτρεπτικὸς τ.

children.definition: mode of formation, form, τ. πατρωνυμικῶν D.T. 634.29; τ. παθητικός A.D. Synt. 278.25.

children.label: VII
children.definition: archetype, pattern, model, capable of exact repetition in numerous instances, αὑτὸν ἐκμάττειν . . εἰς τοὺς τῶν κακιόνων τ. Pl. R. 396e; οἰκισταῖς (sc. πόλεως) τοὺς μὲν τ. προσήκει εἰδέναι, ἐν οἷς δεῖ μυθολογεῖν τοὺς ποιητάς . . , οὐ μὴν αὐτοῖς γε ποιητέον μύθους· . . οἱ τ. περὶ θεολογίας τίνες ἂν εἶεν; ib. 379a, cf. 380c.

data.quote: αὑτὸν ἐκμάττειν . . εἰς τοὺς τῶν κακιόνων τ.

children.definition: character recognizable in a number of instances, general character, type, πάντα ὅσα τοῦ τ. τούτου Id. Tht. 171e; τοῦ αὐτοῦ μετέχοντα τύπου Id. R. 402d; τοῦτον τὸν τ. ἔχοντα Id. Phlb. 51d.
type or form of disease (esp. fever) with reference to the order and spacing of its attacks and intervals, Gal. 7.463, cf. 475,490,512.

children.label: VIII
children.definition: general impression, vague indication, γίνεται ἀμυδρὸς ὁ τ. τῆς ῥάχεως (in the foetus) Diocl. Fr. 175; τ. ἀμυδροί, opp. ἀκριβὲς εἶδος, Gal. 6.5; ἕως ἂν ὁ τ. ἐνῇ τοῦ πράγματος as long as there is an approximate indication of the thing, Pl. Cra. 432e; of the general type or schema corresponding with a name, Epicur. Fr. 255.

outline, sketch, general idea, ὅσον τοὺς τ. ὑφηγεῖσθαι Pl. R. 403e; περιγραφὴ καὶ τύποι Id. Lg. 876e; ἔχεις τὸν τ. ὧν λέγω Id. R. 491c; τοὺς τ. μόνον εἰπόντες περὶ αὐτῶν Arist. Pol. 1341b31; ἐξηγεῖσθαι τύποις Pl. Lg. 816c; ὁ τ. τῆς φιλοσοφίας τοιοῦτός τίς ἐστιν Isoc. 15.186, cf. Phld. Rh. 2.166 S.; ὁ τ. τῆς ὅλης πραγματείας Epicur. Ep. 1p.3U.; pl., ib. p.4 U.; δέονται . . ὑγρᾶς διαίτης, ἧς τὸν τ. ἀρτίως ὑπέγραψα Gal. 6.397; τύπῳ, ἐν τύπῳ, in outline, in general, ὡς ἐν τύπῳ, μὴ διʼ ἀκριβείας, εἰρῆσθαι Pl. R. 414a; ἵνα τύπῳ λάβωμεν αὐτάς ib. 559a; ἐν ἑνὶ περιλαβόντα εἰπεῖν αὐτὰ οἷόν τινι τύπῳ Id. Lg. 718c; τύπῳ, καὶ οὐκ ἀκριβῶς Arist. EN 1104a1; παχυλῶς καὶ τ. ἐνδείκνυσθαι ib. 1094b20; τ. καὶ ἐπὶ κεφαλαίου λέγομεν ib. 1107b14; ὡς ἐν τ. Id. Pol. 1323a10; ὅσον τύπῳ in outline only, Id. Top. 101a22; ὡς τύπῳ λαβεῖν Thphr. Char. 1.1.

data.quote: τοὺς τ. μόνον εἰπόντες περὶ αὐτῶν
ὁ τ. τῆς φιλοσοφίας τοιοῦτός τίς ἐστιν
δέονται . . ὑγρᾶς διαίτης, ἧς τὸν τ. ἀρτίως ὑπέγραψα
ὡς ἐν τύπῳ, μὴ διʼ ἀκριβείας, εἰρῆσθαι
ἐν ἑνὶ περιλαβόντα εἰπεῖν αὐτὰ οἷόν τινι τύπῳ

children.definition: outline, ταῦτα ὅσα εἴρηται καθάπερ ἐν γραφαῖς ἀχρόοις γραμμῇ μόνῃ τύποι ἀνδρῶν εἰκασμένοι εἰσί Adam. 2.61.

data.quote: ταῦτα ὅσα εἴρηται καθάπερ ἐν γραφαῖς ἀχρόοις γραμμῇ μόνῃ τύποι ἀνδρῶν εἰκασμένοι εἰσί

children.label: IX
children.definition: prescribed form, model to be imitated, ἢν ἁμάρτωσι τοῦ πατρικοῦ τ. τοῦ ἐπιμελέος Democr. 228; οὗτος . . εἷς ἂν εἴη τῶν περὶ θεοὺς νόμων καὶ τύπων, ἐν ᾧ δεήσει τοὺς λέγοντας λέγειν καὶ τοὺς ποιοῦντας ποιεῖν Pl. R. 380c, cf. 383c; ἐν τοῖς τ. οἷς ἐνομοθετησάμεθα ib. 398b; εἰς ἀρχήν τε καὶ τ. τινὰ τῆς δικαιοσύνης ib. 443c; τ. εὐσεβείας . . παισὶν . . ἐκτέθεικα OGI 383.212 (Nemrud Dagh, i B. C.); ὥστε γενέσθαι ὑμᾶς τύπον πᾶσι τοῖς πιστεύουσιν ἐν τῇ Μακεδονίᾳ 1 Ep.Thess. 1.7; κατὰ τὸν τ. τὸν δεδειγμένον σοι LXX Ex. 25.39(40), cf. Act.Ap. 7.44.

data.quote: ἢν ἁμάρτωσι τοῦ πατρικοῦ τ. τοῦ ἐπιμελέος
οὗτος . . εἷς ἂν εἴη τῶν περὶ θεοὺς νόμων καὶ τύπων, ἐν ᾧ δεήσει τοὺς λέγοντας λέγειν καὶ τοὺς ποιοῦντας ποιεῖν
ὥστε γενέσθαι ὑμᾶς τύπον πᾶσι τοῖς πιστεύουσιν ἐν τῇ Μακεδονίᾳ
κατὰ τὸν τ. τὸν δεδειγμένον σοι

children.definition: general instruction, δόντες τοὺς τ. τούτους ὑπὲρ τῆς ὅλης διοικήσεως, ἐξέπεμπον τοὺς δέκα Plb. 21.24.9; general principle in law, τ. ἐστὶν καθʼ ὃν ἔκρεινα πολλάκις PRyl. 75.8 (ii A. D.).

data.quote: δόντες τοὺς τ. τούτους ὑπὲρ τῆς ὅλης διοικήσεως, ἐξέπεμπον τοὺς δέκα
τ. ἐστὶν καθʼ ὃν ἔκρεινα πολλάκις

children.label: b
children.definition: rule of life, religion, ἐξεταστέον ποταπῷ χρῆται τύπῳ ὁ νοσῶν (e. g. whether Jewish or Egyptian) Erot. Fr. 33.

rough draft of a book, βιβλίον γεγραμμενον ἐν τύποις Gal. 18(2).875, cf. 15.587,624, Anon. ap. Phot. Bibl. p.491 B.; draft of an official letter, τύπον ποιεῖ he drafted a letter, UPZ 14.135 (ii B. C.); τ. χειρογραφίας PMich.Teb. 123r ii 38 (i A. D.); τ. ἐπιστολικοί models of letters, Epist.Charact. tit.

form of a document, ἔστιν δὲ ὁ τ. τῆς εἰθισμένης διαγραφῆς ὁ ὑποκείμενος PMich.Zen. 9v. 3 (iii B. C.); σωματισθῆναι . . τύπῳ τῷδε· τί ἑκάστῳ ὑπάρχει κτλ. POxy. 1460.12 (iii A. D.); κατὰ τὸν αὐτὸν τ. PFlor. 279.16 (vi A. D.).

data.quote: ἔστιν δὲ ὁ τ. τῆς εἰθισμένης διαγραφῆς ὁ ὑποκείμενος
σωματισθῆναι . . τύπῳ τῷδε· τί ἑκάστῳ ὑπάρχει κτλ.

children.definition: text of a document, ὁ μὲν τῆς ἐπιστολῆς τ. οὕτως ἐγέγραπτο LXX 3 Ma. 3.30, cf. Aristeas 34, Act.Ap. 23.25, prob. cj. in LXX 1 Ma. 15.2.

data.quote: ὁ μὲν τῆς ἐπιστολῆς τ. οὕτως ἐγέγραπτο

children.definition: written decision, θεῖος τ. an imperial rescript, Cod.Just. 1.2.20, al., Just. Nov. 113 tit., cf. PMasp. 32.41 (vi A. D.); αἰτῆσαι θεῖον καὶ πραγματικὸν τ. Mitteis Chr. 319.47 (vi A. D.); given by a bishop, Sammelb. 7449.14 (v A. D.); by the ἔκδικος, PSI 9.1075.11 (v A. D.); by others, χρὴ . . δοῦναι τ. εἰς τὴν συγχώρησιν POxy. 1911.145 (vi A. D.): in pl., of the acta of a πάγαρχος, ib. 1829.2, 12 (vi A. D.).

data.quote: χρὴ . . δοῦναι τ. εἰς τὴν συγχώρησιν

children.label: X
children.definition: summons, writ, οἱ τ. γράμμα εἰσὶν ἀγορᾶς, ἐρήμην ἐπαγγέλλον τῷ οὐκ ἀποδιδόντι Philostr. VS 1.25.9; δίκης λῆξις εἴη ἂν ὁ νῦν καλούμενος τ. Poll. 8.29.

data.quote: οἱ τ. γράμμα εἰσὶν ἀγορᾶς, ἐρήμην ἐπαγγέλλον τῷ οὐκ ἀποδιδόντι
δίκης λῆξις εἴη ἂν ὁ νῦν καλούμενος τ.

children.definition: forming, modelling, Greg.Cor. in Rh. 7(2).1126 W.
form by impress, κόνιν τυπόων Nonn. D. 6.21:— Pass., γράμμα τυπωθέν Maiist. 28.

impress, stamp, ἐπιστολὴν σφραγῖδι App. Hann. 51; σφραγῖδες τ. κηρόν Ph. 1.326; σφραγὶς τ. εἴδη ib. 47:— Med. or Pass., to be stamped with an impression, metaph. of perception, Zeno Stoic. 1.39, cf. PMag.Lond. 121.562.
stamp a coin, Poll. 3.86; τοῦ νομίσματος ἐπὶ μὲν θατέρου Ἄμμωνα . . ἐτύπωσαν Suid. s.v. Βάττου σίλφιον:— Pass., ἀὴρ φθόγγοις ἐνάρθροις τυπωθείς Plu. Gen.Socr. 2.589c, cf. Thphr. Sens. 50.

data.quote: τοῦ νομίσματος ἐπὶ μὲν θατέρου Ἄμμωνα . . ἐτύπωσαν

children.definition: seal up, PGiss. 54.14 (iv A. D.).

children.label: II
children.definition: form, mould, model, τυποῦσι [θνητὰ γένη] θεοί Pl. Prt. 320d:—in Med., ἡ πειθὼ τὴν ψυχὴν ἐτυπώσατο Gorg. Hel. 13; Κύπριδος παῖδα τυπωσάμενος AP 12.56 ( Mel.), cf. 15.51 ( Arch.):— Pass., receive a form, be modelled, of sculpture, opp. painting, τὰ γεγραμμένα καὶ τὰ τετυπωμένα Pl. Sph. 239d; μιμήματα τυπωθέντα ἀπὸ . . Id. Ti. 50c; τοῦ τυποῦντος καὶ τοῦ τυπουμένου Plu. An.procr. 2.1024c; of the foetus, Sor. 1.43, cf. 82; τυπωθεὶς χαλκός Supp.Epigr. 3.441 ( Stratos).
Pass., of diseases, assume a certain type (cf. τύπος VII. 3), Gal. 7.463, al.; of treatment, Id. 6.92.

children.label: III
children.definition: ordain, decree, PLond.ined. 2142 (iv A. D.), Cod.Just. 1.3.38.6 ( Pass.), PMasp. 353.14 (vi A. D.).

children.label: IV
children.definition: execute in due form, POxy. 67.11 ( Pass., iv A. D.), PLips. 35.19 ( Pass., iv A. D.).
to be beaten, D. 54.44.

definition: τύπτω, Il. 11.561, etc.: fut. τύψω Nonn. D. 44.160, Hierocl. Facet. 200: aor. 1 ἔτυψα, Ep. τύψα, Il. 13.529, al., Emp. 43, Hdt. 3.64, but rare in Trag. and Att., as A. Eu. 156 (lyr.), [ Lys.] Fr. 20 S.: Att. fut. τυπτήσω Ar. Nu. 1443, Pl. 21. Pl. Grg. 527a, D. 21.204: aor. 1 ἐτύπτησα first in Arist. Pol. 1274b20 (as v.l.), then Philostr. VS 2.1.8, Aesop. 66, Hierocl. Facet. 86: aor. 2 ἔτῠπον E. Ion 766 (lyr.); Ep. part. τετυπόντες Call. Dian. 61 (perh. pf. τετύποντες): pf. τέτῠφα only in Theodos. Can. p.47 H.; τετύπτηκα Poll. 9.129, Philostr. VS 2.10.3:— Med., Hdt. 2.61, Plu. Alex. 3, etc., ( κατ-) Sapph. 62: aor. 1 ἐτυψάμην Luc. Asin. 14, ( ἀπ-) Hdt. 2.40: fut. (in pass. sense) τυπτήσομαι Ar. Nu. 1379:— Pass., aor. 1 ἐτύφθην Plu. Galb. 26, Gp. 18.17.7, Hierocl. Facet. 138, Zen. 2.68; ἐτυπτήθην Ph. 2.323: aor. 2 ἐτύπην [ῠ] Il. 11.191, Pi. N. 1.53, A. Pr. 363, Ar. Ach. 1194 (lyr.), Alciphr. 3.57: pf. τέτυμμαι Il. 13.782, A. Th. 889 (lyr.), Eu. 509 (lyr.), inf. τετύφθαι Hdt. 3.64; τετύπτημαι Luc. Demon. 16, Arg. D. 54:—In Att. and LXX the fut. and aor. are supplied by πατάσσω, e.g. τύπτει . . καὶ καταβάλλει πατάξας Lys. 13.71; later sts. by παίω, e.g. ὁ δὲ παίσας ἐπερωτᾷ ποτέρᾳ τετύπτηκεν Poll. 9.129; the pf. by πλήσσω; the Pass. partly (esp. in pf. and aor.) by πλήσσω: a complete paradigm of this verb is given by Theodos. Can. p.43 H., al.:—

data.quote: ὁ δὲ παίσας ἐπερωτᾷ ποτέρᾳ τετύπτηκεν

children.definition: beat, strike, smite, τύπτουσιν ῥοπάλοισι (sc. τὸν ὄνον) Il. 11.561; ἀμφὶ δέ μιν σφυρὰ τύπτε καὶ αὐχένα δέρμα 6.117; ἴχνια τύπτε πόδεσσι πάρος κόνιν ἀμφιχυθῆναι 23.764; χθόνα τύπτε μετώπῳ Od. 22.86; ἅλα τύπτον ἐρετμοῖς 4.580, 9.104, al.; but in Hom. mostly with weapons of war, [ ξίφει], δουρί, ἄορι, Il. 4.531, 13.529, 20.378; ἐγχείῃσιν 13.782 ( Pass.); φασγάνῳ Od. 22.98; σκήπτρῳ τυπεὶς ἐκ τῆσδε χειρός S. OT 811; μάστιγι Lex ap. Aeschin. 1.139 ( Pass.): c. acc. cogn., τ. τινὰ σχεδίην (sc. πληγήν) Il. 5.830; πληγὰς τ. τινά Antipho 4.3.1, v. infr. III.2: the part struck is sts. in acc., γαστέρα γάρ μιν τύψε παρʼ ὀμφαλόν Il. 21.180, cf. Pi. N. 9.26, E. Andr. 1150, etc.: with a Prep., Φόρκυνα . . κατὰ γαστέρα τύψε Il. 17.313; ἐγκύμονά τις ἔτυψε κατὰ γαστρός [ Lys.] l.c.; τ. τινὰ εἰς τὸν ὦμον X. Cyr. 5.4.5; ἐπὶ κόρρης Pl. Grg. 527a; ἐπὶ τὴν σιαγόνα Ev.Luc. 6.29; τ. χαλκώματα beat pots and pans (to make a noise), Sor. 2.29: abs., strike, τύπτε δʼ ἐπιστροφάδην Il. 21.20, cf. Od. 22.308, Ar. Ra. 610; τ. καὶ πνίγων Antipho 4.1.6; Ζέφυρος λαίλαπι τύπτων beating with fury, Il. 11.306, cf. Pi. P. 6.14 (s. v.l.).

data.quote: ἀμφὶ δέ μιν σφυρὰ τύπτε καὶ αὐχένα δέρμα
ἴχνια τύπτε πόδεσσι πάρος κόνιν ἀμφιχυθῆναι
γαστέρα γάρ μιν τύψε παρʼ ὀμφαλόν

data.ref: E. Andr. 1150, etc.: with a Prep.,

children.definition: ἐκ χειρὸς τοῖς λίθοις τύπτοντες Plb. 3.53.4; whereas Hom. opposes τύπτειν to βάλλειν, δουρὶ τυπεὶς ἢ βλήμενος ἰῷ Il. 11.191 = 206, cf. 15.495, al.

data.quote: βάλλειν, δουρὶ τυπεὶς ἢ βλήμενος ἰῷ

children.definition: sting, ὄφις μʼ ἔτυψε μικρός Anacreont. 33.10; ὑπὸ σφηκῶν τύπτεσθαι X. HG 4.2.12, cf. Gp. l.c.; πόδα κάκτος τ. Theoc. 10.4; οἱ βασιλεῖς [μελιττῶν] . . οὐ τύπτουσιν Arist. HA 553b6.

τὸν δʼ ἄχος ὀξὺ κατὰ φρένα τύψε βαθεῖαν sharp grief smote him to the heart, Il. 19.125; Καμβύσεα ἔτυψε ἡ ἀληθείη Hdt. 3.64; ἔτυπεν ὀδύνα με πλευμόνων ἔσω E. Ion 766 (lyr.); ξυμφορᾷ τετυμμένος A. Eu. 509 (lyr.); ἀνίαισι τυπείς Pi. N. 1.53; τύπτειν τὴν συνείδησίν τινος ἀσθενοῦσαν wound his conscience, 1 Ep.Cor. 8.12; of divine punishment, ἐγώ εἰμι Κύριος ὁ τύπτων LXX Ez. 7.6(9); τύπτειν σε μέλλει ὁ θεός Act.Ap. 23.3.
strike a coin, ἐξ ἀργύρου τυπτόμενον νόμισμα Hero *Mens. 60.

children.label: II
children.definition: Med. τύπτομαι, beat, strike oneself, esp., like κόπτομαι, beat oneʼs breast for grief, Hdt. 2.61: c. acc. pers., mourn for a person, ib. 42, 132.

children.label: III
children.definition: Pass., to be beaten, struck, or wounded, δουρὶ τυπείς Il. 11.191; ὑπὸ δουρί ib. 433; δορὸς ὕπο Ar. Ach. 1194 (lyr.); κράτων τυπτομένων Od. 22.309.

receive blows or wounds, ἕλκεα . . ὅσσʼ ἐτύπη Il. 24.421; τύπτομαι πολλάς (sc. πληγάς) I get many blows, Ar. Nu. 972 (anap.), cf. Pax 644 (troch.), Ra. 636, Lex ap. Aeschin. 1.139: c. dat., καιρίῃ (sc. πληγῇ) τετύφθαι Hdt. 3.64; v. supr. I.1.
like an outline, ὡς εἰς τ. μάθησιν so far as belongs to general or superficial knowledge, Arist. Mu. 397b12. Adv. -ωδῶς summarily, Cic. Att. 4.13.2, Str. 2.1.24, 4.1.1, 2: Comp. -ωδέστερον Ph. 2.419.
that which is formed or moulded, τ. χαλκόπλευρον, of a brazen urn, S. El. 54; figure, outline, μορφῆς τ. E. Ph. 162.
seal-impression, Anon. in Gött.Nachr. 1922.35 (cf. 40): hence,

children.label: b
children.definition: impression received in perception, = φάντασμα, Plu. Col. 2.1121c.
forming, moulding, impression, Thphr. Sens. 53; modelling, S.E. M. 9.197; of the foetus, Hp. Alim. 42.
delineation, sketching in outline, Phld. Rh. 2.34 S.

children.label: II
children.definition: the making of a τύπωμα 2b, φαντασία τύπωσις ἐν ψυχῇ Stoic. 2.229, cf. Cleanth. ib. 1.108, al., Plot. 4.3.26; the impression made, Plu. Brut. 37.
one who forms or moulds, κόσμοιο τ. Orph. Fr. 247.8:—fem. τῠπ-ῶτις, ιδος, σφρηγὶς τ. seal-ring, Id. H. 34.26.
able to form or mould, formative, Euryph. ap. Stob. 4.39.27: c. gen., S.E. M. 7.383, 8.407, Ath. 9.392a.

children.label: II
children.definition: ‘sketchy’, περίληψις ( outline) Eustr. in EN 14.32.

children.label: III
children.definition: τυπωτικοὶ λόγοι, i.e. λόγοι which are copies of the things which are seen, Procl. in R. 2.177 K. Adv. -κῶς, μετέχειν τὰ αἰσθητὰ τῶν εἰδῶν Id. in Prm. p.657 S.
fashioned, moulded, Lyc. 262.
cheese-cake, Philox. 3.17.
cheese-cake, Wien.Sitzb. 132(2).23 ( Caria).
a tyrantʼs dwelling, Str. 13.1.67, J. BJ 4.3.7, Plu. Dio 13, etc.: pl., D.S. 16.70, Plu. Tim. 13.

definition: τυραννεύω and τῠρανν-έω, the former always in Hdt. (v. infr.) and found in Alc. Supp. 28.12 (prob.); both in Trag. and Com., as the metre required, cf. S. OT 408 with OC 449; E. Med. 967, Ph. 560 with Hel. 786; Ar. Av. 483 (anap.) with Lys. 631 (troch.), Fr. 357; and X. used both, cf. Cyr. 1.1.1 with HG 4.4.6; Pl. has -έω in Lg. 693a, R. 580c, al., -εύω in Men. 76b, more freq. in aor.: fut. -εύσω E. El. 877 (lyr.), Ar. Lys. l.c., -ήσω first in Plu. Pyth. 2.403c, App. BC 2.139: aor. ἐτυράννευσα Sol. 33.6, Hdt. 1.14, Th. 6.55, 59, Pl. R. 576c, Grg. 473d, Phdr. 238b, etc., -ησα E. HF 29, X. HG 2.2.24: pf. τετυράννευκα Isoc. 8.113, -ηκα first in Plb. 2.59.1:— Pass., fut. -ηθήσομαι Sopat. in Rh. 8.335 W.; but Med. τυραννήσομαι in pass. sense, D. 20.161: aor. ἐτυραννεύθην Th. 1.18, Pl. (v. infr.), -ήθην D.H. 4.82, Str. 8.6.25:—

children.definition: to be a monarch, absolute ruler, and in aor. to become such, Hdt. 1.14, 5.92.εʹ, Th. 6.55, etc.; ὡς χρὴ τυραννεῖν, Ἰσοκράτους ἠκούσατε Isoc. 3.11; τυραννεύσασα ἡ ἐπιθυμία Pl. Phdr. 238b: in Poets, to be a prince or princess, E. Med. 967.

to be ruler of a people or place, τ. Ἀθηνῶν Sol. 33.6; Σαρδίων, Μιλήτου, Ἀθηναίων, Μήδων, Hdt. 1.15, 20, 59, 73; χθονός, γαίας, S. OC 449, E. El. 877 (lyr.), etc.; τῶν κακιόνων Id. Fr. 1048.6; Σάμου Th. 1.13; τᾶς πόλιος (sc. Eresus) IG 12(2).526d20 (iv B. C.): metaph., [ Κύπρις] Διὸς τυραννεῖ πλευμόνων S. Fr. 941.15.

τὸ συμπόσιον Luc. DMeretr. 3.2 codd.; Μεσσήνην f.l. (cod. S) in D. 17.7:— Pass., to be under the sway of τύραννοι, Hdt. 5.55, 78, Th. 1.18, etc.; τυραννουμένη πόλις Pl. R. 545c, cf. Hdt. 4.137, 5.92.αʹ, X. HG 2.3.48; ὑπό τινος τυραννήσεσθαι D. 20.161; τυραννευθεὶς ὑπὸ Ἔρωτος Pl. R. 574e.

children.label: II
children.definition: to be of a tyrannical disposition, be imperious, Id. Alc. 1.135a, Men. 76b.
aspire to sovereignty, Sol. ap. D.L. 1.65.
tyranny, Ptol. Tetr. 197.
one must be tyrant, Sol. ap. D.L. 1.64.
Xenoph. 3 (with penult. long); tyrannous conduct, Wilcken Chr. 20 ii 12 (ii A. D.), PAmh. 2.142.15 (iv A. D.).
smack of tyranny, οἱ λόγοι σου τ. D.L. 3.18:— Med., behave tyrannously, PSI 6.686.5 (vi A. D.).

children.label: II
children.definition: J. BJ 4.7.1, Heraclid. Pol. 4, Suid.
take the part of tyrants, D. 17.7.

of or for a τύραννος, royal, αἷμα A. Ag. 828; τρόποισιν οὐ τυραννικοῖς Id. Ch. 479; κράτος τ. S. OC 373; λῆμα E. Med. 348; δόμος, στέγαι, ib. 740, Andr. 882; κύκλος τ. the circle or assembly of kings, S. Aj. 749; τ. θέαμα (in good sense) Phalar. Ep. 122.1.

befitting a tyrant, despotic, τυραννικόν τοι πόλλʼ ἐπίστασθαι λέγειν E. Fr. 335; συμφοραὶ τ. that befall a tyrant, Isoc. 8.91; smacking of tyranny, τὸ σῦκον (sc. τὸ Λακωνικὸν) ἐχθρόν ἐστι καὶ τ. Ar. Fr. 108 (troch.); φρονῶν τυραννικά Id. V. 507 (troch.); ξυνωμοσία τ. in favour of tyranny, Th. 6.60; νόμοι Pl. R. 338e; τι δρᾶσαι τῶν τ. ib. 574b; μαθὼν ἀντὶ τοῦ βασιλικοῦ τὸ τ. X. Cyr. 1.3.18; τὰ τ. the period of the tyrants, Arist. Pol. 1303a38.

data.quote: μαθὼν ἀντὶ τοῦ βασιλικοῦ τὸ τ.

children.definition: tyrannical, of persons, Pl. R. 574c, Phdr. 248e, etc.; Sup. -ώτατος Id. R. 575d, 580c; fit for tyrannical government, οἱ τ., opp. οἱ δημοτικοί, X. HG 2.3.49; τυραννικὸν [δίκαιον] οὐκ ἔστι κατὰ φύσιν Arist. Pol. 1287b39.

children.label: II
children.definition: Adv. -κῶς, ζῆν Pl. R. 575a; opp. βασιλικῶς, Isoc. 5.154; opp. πολιτικῶς, Arist. Ath. 16.2: Comp. -ώτερον Id. Pol. 1313a2.

definition: τυραννίς, ίδος, ἡ, voc. τυραννί S. OT 380:—

children.definition: monarchy, sovereignty, μεγάλης οὐκ ἐρέω τ. Archil. 25, cf. Pi. P. 2.87, 11.53 (pl.), S. OT 535, E. Ba. 43, etc.; of the sovereignty of Zeus, ἡ Διὸς τ. A. Pr. 10, al., cf. infr. II.2:—but more freq.

children.label: II
children.definition: despotic rule, obtained by force or fraud, tyranny, Simon. 71, Hdt. 3.53, 81, Ar. V. 417, Th. 1.13, etc.; τυραννίδα ἔχετε τὴν ἀρχήν (of the Athenians) Id. 3.37; τ. ὑμῶν lordship over you, D. 2.30: metaph., ἡ ἐπιθυμιῶν ἐν ψυχῇ τ. Pl. Lg. 863e.
ἡ Διὸς τ. royal Zeus, S. Fr. 345: pl., αἱ τυραννίδες, = οἱ τύραννοι, Hdt. 8.137; ἴδεσθε χώρας τὴν διπλῆν τ. A. Ch. 973.
territory or resources of a princeling, Liv. 38.14.12.

children.label: III
children.definition: τύραννος, princess, LXX Es. 1.18.
tyrant more than human, perh. referring to Aspasia, Com.Adesp. 99.
teacher of tyrants, Pl. Thg. 125a, D.C. 59.24.
Hermog. in Rh. 7(1).400 W.
slay a tyrant, Plu. Lat.viv. 2.1128f, Luc. Tyr. 21, Rhet.Anon. in PLit.Lond. 138 ix 9:— Pass., to be slain as a tyrant, Luc. Tyr. 20.
the slaying of a tyrant, Ph. ap. Eus. PE 8.14, J. AJ 19.1.10, Plu. Pel. 34, Luc. Tyr. 22.
of or for the slaying of a tyrant, γέρα App. BC 4.94.
slayer of a tyrant, D.S. 16.14, Plu. Mul.virt. 2.256f, Luc. Tyr. 1, Lib. Decl. 43.32:—as Adj., πάθος, τιμαὶ τ., of slaying a tyrant, Phalar. Ep. 70.1.
maker of tyrants, Pl. R. 572e.
citizen under a tyranny, Sidon.Apoll. Ep. 5.8 ( -tarum, v.l. -tanorum).

definition: τύραννος [ῠ], ὁ, also ἡ (v. infr. I.2),

children.definition: an absolute ruler, unlimited by law or constitution, first in h.Mart. 5 (unless the hymn is late), where it is used of a god, Ἆρες, . . ἀντιβίοισι τύραννε; so ὁ τῶν θεῶν τ., of Zeus, A. Pr. 736, cf. Ar. Nu. 564 (lyr.); ὦ τύραννε τᾶς ἐμᾶς φρενός, i.e. Apollo, S. Tr. 217 (lyr.); σὺ δʼ ὦ τύραννε θεῶν τε κἀνθρώπων Ἔρως E. Fr. 136; Μὴν Τύραννος, a Phrygian deity worshipped in Attica, IG 2(2).1366.2 (i A. D.), al.; οὔ, τὴν τ. (perh. Hera), in an oath, Herod. 5.77: first used of monarchs in the time of Archil. (cf. τυραννίς I) acc. to Hippias 9 D.; Φίττακον ἐστάσαντο τ. Alc. 37 A; ἢν μή τις ἢ τ. ἢ σκηπτοῦχος ᾖ Semon. 7.69; λαγέτας τ. Pi. P. 3.85; interchangeable with βασιλεύς in Isoc. 2.4 (cf. 1), 35 (cf. 36); later, chief, princeling, OGI 654.8 ( Egypt, i B. C.); τ. ἴδιοι καθʼ ἕκαστον ἐμτπόριον Peripl.M.Rubr. 14: c. gen., Κροῖσος . . τ. ἐθνέων τῶν ἐντὸς Ἅλυος Hdt. 1.6; Κλεισθένης ὁ Σικυῶνος τ., Ἱστιαῖος ὁ Μιλήτου τ., etc., Id. 5.67, 7.10.γ, etc.; ὁ τῶν Κυπρίων τ. Sor. 1.39; οἱ τ., of the Sicilian tyrants, Th. 1.14; of the Pisistratidae, X. HG 6.5.33, Arist. Ath. 13.5, Pol. 1275b36, cf. Th. 6.54, Pl. Smp. 182c; τὸν τ. κτανέτην Scol. 9.3; οἱ τ. the monarchical party, προδιδοὺς τοῖς τ. τὴμ πόλιν τὴν Ἐρυθραίων IG 1(2).10.32: freq. in a bad sense, δημοφάγος τ. Thgn. 1181, cf. 823, Hdt. 3.80, Pl. Grg. 510b, Plt. 301c, R. 569b, etc.; ὕβρις φυτεύει τύραννον S. OT 873 (lyr.).

data.ref: h.Mart. 5 (unless the hymn is late), where it is used of a god,

data.quote: σὺ δʼ ὦ τύραννε θεῶν τε κἀνθρώπων Ἔρως
ἢν μή τις ἢ τ. ἢ σκηπτοῦχος ᾖ
Κροῖσος . . τ. ἐθνέων τῶν ἐντὸς Ἅλυος
προδιδοὺς τοῖς τ. τὴμ πόλιν τὴν Ἐρυθραίων

children.definition: members of the rulerʼs family, οἱ τ. ‘the royal house’, Id. Tr. 316, cf. OC 851, Charito 1.2: ἡ τύραννος is used both of the queen herself and the kingʼs daughter, princess, E. Hec. 809, Med. 42, 877, 1356, cf. infr. II; πρέπει γὰρ ὡς τ. εἰσορᾶν, of Clytemnestra, S. El. 664; αὐτὴ . . τ. ἦ Φρυγῶν E. Andr. 204.
ἵνα Δίκη τ. ᾖ that Justice may be supreme, Critias 25.6D.; Ἔρως τ. ἀνδρῶν E. Hipp. 538 (lyr.); Πειθὼ τὴν τ. ἀνθρώποις μόνην Id. Hec. 816.
golden-crested wren, Regulus cristatus, Arist. HA 592b23; cf. τροχίλος I.2.

children.label: II
children.definition: τύραννος, ον, as Adj., kingly, royal, τύραννα σκῆπτρα A. Pr. 761; τ. σχῆμα S. Ant. 1169; τύραννα δρᾶν to act as a king, Id. OT 588; ἡ τύραννος κόρη E. Med. 1125; τύραννον δῶμα the kingʼs palace, Id. Hipp. 843 (lyr.), etc.; τ. ἑστία Id. Andr. 3; τ. δόμος the royal house, Id. Hel. 478, etc.; ἐς τύραννʼ ἐγημάμην into the royal house, Id. Tr. 474.
imperious, despotic, τ. πόλις Th. 1.122, 124; αἱ τ. φύσεις Luc. Ner. 2. (Loan-word, prob. from Phrygian or Lydian.)
slaying tyrants, AP 7.388 ( Bianor), D.C. 44.35.

definition: τυράσιον, τό, dub. sens. in PSI 6.606.6 (iii B. C.).

children.definition: pell-mell, in confusion, [ ὗς] τρέπουσα τύρβʼ ἄνω κάτω A. Fr. 311.3; also σύρβα, Hsch., cf. συρβάβυττα.

trouble, stir up, τὸν πηλὸν ὥσπερ ἀτταγᾶς τυρβάσεις βαδίζων Ar. V. 257; τυφλὸς . . Ἄρης συὸς προσώπῳ πάντα τυρβάζει κακά S. Fr. 838:— Pass., πολὺς δὲ πηλὸς ἐκ πίθων τυρβάζεται bursts in turbid stream from . . , ib. 783: c. dat. pers., jostle against . . , Ar. Pax 1007 (anap.); τ. περὶ πολλά (v. l. for θορυβάζῃ) to be troubled about . . , Ev.Luc. 10.41.

data.quote: τὸν πηλὸν ὥσπερ ἀτταγᾶς τυρβάσεις βαδίζων
τυφλὸς . . Ἄρης συὸς προσώπῳ πάντα τυρβάζει κακά

children.label: II
children.definition: revel, enjoy oneself, Alex. 25.6.
Poll. 4.104, Hsch.; cj. Rzach for τυρβάξας in Hes. Fr. 96.60.
trouble, confusion, dub. in Anon. Herc. 418 Fr. 2.4.
disorder, confusion, tumult, τύρβην παρέχειν τινί Hp. Fract. 22; τὴν τύρβην ἐν ᾗ ζῶμεν Isoc. 15.130, cf. X. Cyr. 1.2.3, Plb. 1.67.3, etc.

children.label: II
children.definition: ἡ ποιητικὴ τ. the poetic rout, Epicur. Fr. 228; so of a Bacchic festival and its dance, Paus. 2.24.6: hence, acc. to Suid., = ἀπόλαυσις, revelry. [Oxyt. in some codd. of Hp. l.c.; the form σύρβη is cited by Suid., Eust. 871.60.] (Cf. Lat. turba, ONorse þyrpask ‘crowd together’.)
cheese-making, Arist. HA 523a6.
cheese-press, Tab.Heracl. 1.71.
a cheese as an offering, φέρειν τυρείην τῷ Ἑρμῇ Schwyzer 721.9, cf. 11 ( Mycale, iv B. C.).

children.label: II
children.definition: intrigue, roguery, Eust. 620.13, Zonar.
that which is curdled, cheese, in pl., E. El. 496, Cyc. 162, 190.

children.label: II
children.definition: intrigue, Com.Adesp. 706.
Arist. HA 522a26.
one who makes cheese, Ἑρμῆς τυρευτήρ Hermes as god of goatherds, and giver of goatʼs-milk cheese, AP 9.744 ( Leon.).
make cheese, make into cheese, Com.Adesp. 1173:— Pass., τυρεύεται τὸ γάλα Arist. HA 522b2: impers., τυρεύεται cheese is made, ib. 521b30.

children.label: II
children.definition: mix up cunningly, contrive by trickery and intrigue, κακόν τινι τ. Luc. Asin. 31, cf. Nic.Dam. 136.6J., Adam. 1.3,17: abs., concoct mischief, D. 19.295:— Pass., ἡ ἐπί τινι τυρευθεῖσα ἐπιβουλή Ph. 2.66.
= foreg., τυρὸν ἐτύρησας Alcm. 34.6.

definition: τυρηνίς, ίδος, ἡ, a Persian plaster, Aët. 15.15.

children.definition: of Tyrian-purple dye, Mart. 1.53; pallium tyrianthinum, Vopisc. Carin. 20.5: written τῡρ-άντινος, PHamb. 10.23, 30 (ii A. D.).

definition: τυρίδιον [ρῐ], τό, Dim. of τυρός, dub. cj. in Epich. 92, D.L. 6.36 (Cobet).

children.definition: Τύριμνος at Thyatira, Ath.Mitt. 24.238, BCH 11.105, Keil-Premerstein Zweiter Bericht 62; Ἀπόλλων Τύριμνος, JHS 37.108, etc.; Τυριμναῖος, Keil-Premerstein Zweiter Bericht 115; Σεβαστείου καὶ Τυριμνήου πανηγύρεως Ath.Mitt. 19.535.
of Tyrian purple, [ χρῶμα] POxy. 1739.4 (ii/iii A. D.).
Dim. of τυρός, small cheese, Chionid. 7 (cj. for τυρόν), Telecl. 25, Chrysipp.Tyan. ap. Ath. 14.647c, POxy. 1684v (iv A. D.), etc.
Tyrian, Hdt. 2.112, etc.; πορφύρα PHolm. 26.8, 23.
Ael. NA 8.5, Longus 1.19.
scriblita, Gloss.
= Lat. turma, IGRom. 1.1334,1346, al. ( Egypt); also τούρμα, ib. 1332, al. (ibid., i A. D.).
luciolus, a kind of fish, prob. f.l. in Gloss.
cheese-basket, Sch. Ar. Ra. 568, Sch. Theoc. 11.37.

definition: τυροβόλος, ὁ, or τῡρο-βόλον, τό, = foreg., PSI 6.606.4 (iii B. C.).

children.definition: Cheese-scooper, name of a mouse in Batr. 137.

definition: τυρόεις, εσσα, εν, contr. τῡροῦς, οῦσσα, οῦν, Dor. τῡρῶς, ῶσσα, ῶν ; ( τυρός):—

children.definition: cheesy, like cheese, ἄρτον τυρῶντα Sophr. 14: ὁ τ. (sc. ἄρτος or πλακοῦς) cheese-bread, cheese-cake, or simply cheese, Theoc. 1.58, Hegem. ap. Ath. 15.698f. [τῡρόεντα is trisyll. in Theoc. l.c.]
cheese-thief, Hdn.Gr. 1.246.

definition: τυρόκνηστις, ἡ, acc. ιν Ar. V. 938, etc., gen. ιδος Id. Lys. 231 sq.: ( κνάω):—

children.definition: cheese-scraper, cheese-grater, Ar. V. l.c., 963, Av. 1579, Pl.Com. 8, IG 11 (2).154 A 69 ( Delos, iii B. C.):— τῷ τυροκνηστεῖ (as if from -τεύς) Gal. 19.112.
cheese-crate, cheese-rack, Poll. 1.251, 7.175.
make cheese, Poll. 1.251, Sch. Od. 9.219.
cheese-cake, Chrysipp.Tyan. ap. Ath. 14.647f.
one who divines from cheese, Artem. 2.69.
cheese-backed, i.e. spread with cheese, πλακοῦντος κύκλος Ar. Ach. 1125 (cf. τυροφόρος) —parodied from Γοργόνωτος.
scraping cheese, Sch.D Il. 11.639.
make cheese, Str. 3.5.4, 4.5.2, Nic.Dam. 104J., Longus 3.33.
cheese-making, Gp. 18.19, Eust. 620.10.
of or for cheese-making, Apollon. Lex. s.v. τάλαροι.
cheese-maker, J. BJ 5.4.1, Gal. 4.632.
sale of cheeses, Stud.Pal. 20.96.4 (iv A. D.).
sell like cheese, ποιητῶν τ. τέχνην Ar. Ra. 1369: lit., sell cheese, Men. Pk. 100.
cheesemonger, Ar. Eq. 854, Critias 70, Lib. Or. 29.30.
like a cheesemonger, Sch. Ar. Ra. 1416.

cheese, ἐπὶ δʼ αἴγειον κνῆ τυρόν Il. 11.639; οὐκ ἐπιδευὴς τυροῦ Od. 4.88; τ. ἐξ Ἀχαΐης Semon. 23; τ. Σικελικός Ar. V. 896, etc.; for Sicilian cheese, cf. Hermipp. 63.9, Antiph. 236, Philem. 76: pl., PCair.Zen. 110.25 (iii B. C.), al.
ὁ χλωρὸς τ. the fresh cheese, hence the cheese-market, Lys. 23.6.—Cf. βούτυρον.
a dish of cheese and salt fish, in Lat. form tyrotarichum, Cic. Att. 4.8.1, Fam. 9.16.7.
cutting cheese, Sch. Il. 11.639, Eust. 871.60.
Cheese-eater, name of a mouse in Batr. 223.
stand for cheese-racks, Poll. 1.251, 7.175, 10.130.
with cheese on it, πλακοῦς AP 6.155 ( Theodorid.).
make into cheese, curdle, in Pass., Sopat. 8, Dsc. 2.83, Gal. 6.683, Sch. Theoc. 5.86: metaph., ἐτύρωσάς με ἴσα τυρῷ LXX Jb. 10.10; ἐτυρώθη ὡς γάλα ἡ καρδία αὐτῶν ib. Ps. 118(119).70.
make a mess of (cf. τυρεύω II), τυροῦντες ἅπαντα Archestr. Fr. 45.13; τυρωθέντα· ταραχθέντα, Hsch.

children.label: II
children.definition: make or season with cheese, πλακοῦντες τετυρωμένοι Artem. 1.72.
imitate the Tyrrhenians, τῇ φωνῇ Polyaen. 8.8.
Tyrrhenian, Etruscan, σανδάλια T. Cratin. 131; κρατῆρες IG 2(2).1648.36, 11(2).161 B 122,219 B 69 ( Delos, iii B. C.): Τ. λόγος, a speech by Dinarchus: cf. Τυρσηνικός.
of Tyrrhenian or Etruscan work, Poll. 7.93.
νῆες] Thphr. HP 5.8.3.
destroyer of Tyrrhenians, AP 9.524.20.
Tyrrhenian, IG 2(2).1629.223, Plb. 1.6.4, etc.; cf. Τυρσηνικός.

definition: τυρρίδιον, τό, Dim. of τύρρις (v. τύρσις), IG 14.352ii65, 77 ( Halaesa).
Τυρσηνός, ή, όν, Ion. for Att. Τυρρηνός; Dor. Τυρσᾱνός Pi. P. 1.72, SIG 14 ( Delph., vi/v B. C.), also Τυρρᾱνός (v. infr.):—

children.definition: Tyrrhenian, Etruscan, h.Hom. 7.8, Hes. Th. 1016, E. Med. 1359, etc.; τῷ Δὶ Τυράνʼ ἀπὸ Κύμας SIG 35 (Olympia, V B.C.), cf. Τυρρανοί ib. 24 (Delph.):— the people were Τυρσηνοί, Τυρρηνοί, Hdt. 1.57, etc.; Τ. Πελασγοί S. Fr. 270 (anap.):— Adj. Τυρσηνικός, ή, όν, σάλπιγξ, κώδων, A. Eu. 567, S. Aj. 17; cf. κηρός I.3: also fem. Τυρσηνίς, ίδος, Σκύλλα E. Med. 1342.

data.ref: S. Aj. 17; cf. κηρός I.3: also fem.

definition: τύρσις, ἡ, gen. ιος Hp. Art. 43, X. An. 7.8.12; ιδος IG 12(7).115.4 ( Amorgos, ii/i B. C.); acc. τύρσιν Pi. O. 2.70, Hp. l.c., X. An. 7.8.13: nom. and acc. pl. τύρσεις, gen. εων, dat. εσι, ib. 4.4.2, HG 4.7.6, Cyr. 7.5.10; acc. pl. τύρσιας Lyc. 834, Maiist. 2:—also τύρρις, Hsch. (whence Lat. turris is borrowed):—

children.definition: tower, Pi. l.c., Hp. l.c. (cf. Gal. 18(1).518); esp. tower on a wall, bastion, X. ll.cc.; opp. προμαχών, J. BJ 5.4.3 sq.; also, walled city or fortified house, Nic. Al. 2; = villa rustica, πύργος, IG l.c.
furca, Gloss.; τ. διόδους ξυλίνη Edict.Diocl. 15.47.
